PARA.TAB: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Mr Simmons:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: Yesterday at the Press Club we heard the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) give one of the most extraordinary addresses ever heard at that institution by a Prime Minister totally bereft of policy guidelines to solve the problems facing the Australian people. The legislation before us today, in many respects, is merely a continuum of that attitude. It is worth quoting from A National Employment and Training Plan For YOUNG AUSTRALIANS which resulted from the national meeting on 22 July of this year when the Government endeavoured to do something to help young people, in particular young people who are unemployed. On page 3 of that document, the opening paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Delegates at the National Meeting on 22 July argued strongly that assistance was needed immediately for the young unemployed people who are facing hardship, low self-esteem and a feeling that they have been let down by the community.

Sadly, those words have been echoed across the length and breadth of this continent for many months now and relatively little has taken place to demonstrate the Government's direction or sense of purpose to solve these fundamental problems which have been caused absolutely by the failure of its own economic and social policies.

PARA.TAB: Effectively, the legislation before us today is the result of the Government trying to ease access to welfare payments to the people, to the young people in particular, most hard hit by this self-made recession. This legislation is directed at families and at youth. Sadly, it simply adds up to the reality that the Government is once again fiddling around the edges of the problem instead of addressing the causes. At the eleventh hour it is endeavouring to do something to ease, to some small degree, the pain, but it fails utterly to examine why we are where we are and what are the best solutions to those problems.

Perhaps this is the fundamental difference between the approach taken by the Opposition, by the coalition, and the approach taken by this Government. The family allowance lump sum payment represents a consideration of considerable social value to most Australian families. There are now 1.25 million Australians dependent on unemployment payments. This includes over 800,000 claimants and their 245,000 spouses and 330,000 children. More than 41 per cent of these have been relying on unemployment benefits now for well over 12 months. Overall, more than 680,000 children are living in a family where neither parent has employment. Not only was this an increase of 63,000 since early 1992 but, as is pointed out in the Catholic Bishops Common Wealth for the Common Good statement to be released today, it means that every day another 500 children under the age of 14 are being added to this horrendous total.

General economic statistics show that the total stock of national savings was reduced last year as reserves were run down. Consequently, our demand on overseas borrowing rose inexorably. Households have responded to falling incomes by saving less to maintain their consumption levels. As also pointed out by the bishops, the pattern of wealth distribution in Australia is one of growing inequality. Moreover, inequality of income has also increased considerably over the past 10 years. Those with middle incomes have suffered a significant drop in the proportion of the national income reaching them.

Sadly, Australia's middle income earners have been the vast majority and the ones who, to a large degree, have carried the brunt of the massive retrenchments we have seen take place in recent months. In the year to March, 180,000 jobs disappeared from Australia's private sector—a contraction of 4.2 per cent in the private sector work force alone. Employment in the private sector has fallen to 4.1 million people, a decrease of about 450,000 jobs since private sector employment peaked in late 1989.

The FAS statistics also tell a very sad story. The number of families receiving FAS increased by more than 24 per cent in 1991-92. In June 1992 there were 241,000 families receiving FAS, for some 565,000 Australian children—an absolute record. The number of families in crisis demonstrates another set of sad statistics. Welfare agencies like the Salvation Army are experiencing an unprecedented demand for their services. They state, `Families in crisis are seeking assistance at a rate exceeding the capacity and ability of these agencies to respond. Many Australians who in the past have been able to support their family by holding down stable jobs are no longer able to do so and consequently families on low incomes are struggling to make ends meet'. I quote once again from Commonwealth for the Common Good. This is what the bishops said:

SPEECH.PARA: The type of poverty this enquiry has concentrated on is that in which people lack material goods, employment and career prospects, so that they suffer real disadvantage in relation to other members of the community. When, for these reasons, groups or individuals cannot participate fully and freely in the life and decision making of the community, they can be said to be suffering from relative if not absolute poverty. When, for the same reasons, their situation is one of real destitution and apparent hopelessness, they can be regarded as being in a state of absolute poverty.
According to ACOSS:
The gap is widening between those who are secure with a roof over their heads and those who are left out of society and are at the margins.
Certainly, all of the major welfare organisations providing aid had had a doubling in the amount of people seeking help since the onset of this recession.
The numbers seeking temporary shelter have also doubled as a large proportion of those seeking help have never had to do so before.

The Government's solution to date has been limited to these two pathetic pieces of legislation. Its solution is to give families bonus payments out of the blue and to allow them to access some of their family allowance in one lump sum—in other words, the point I made earlier—desperately, to try to treat the effects of the problem but not its causes. Family allowances were intended as a supplement to wages policy because wages do not of themselves take account of family responsibilities. It was a coalition government which first introduced the concept of the family allowance. It is a concept which we have continued to support, on both sides of the House, over those years. Consequently, we certainly support this legislation today.

PARA.TAB: It is important to remember that the allowance was not intended as a series of lump sum payments. We supported a Bill a few months ago, passed through this Parliament in May, which enabled the family allowance payments to be paid on alternate weeks to payments of pensions or benefits. The Government claimed at that time, and we supported that claim, that this would ensure that poorer families with children would have access to four cash payments during each month.

This proposal provides a better cash flow and assists people who may have some difficulty in budgeting for household expenditure over a two-week period. Consequently, while we acknowledge that many families especially on welfare often face one-off debts, for example health costs or preparing children for school and so forth, nevertheless we caution the Government that any further extension of this tendency which appeared a few months ago, when the Government gave people accessing the family allowance a one-off payment—perhaps in the belief that it could bribe people by giving them a continuum of one-off payments—would result in a cutting away at the very basis of the family allowance concept as it currently works. It is meant to be a supplement to wage; it is not meant to be a series of one-off payments.

While we are not opposing these amendments, and while we accept that there are certain circumstances, especially at times like this, when low income families in particular may face points of crisis and would like access to a lump sum—in this case quite a small one; it is only for six months at the single rate—nevertheless we would not want this to be merely the thin edge of the wedge of a general weakening of the system, as has occurred in New Zealand over recent years where the family allowance was offered for a whole host of reasons other than the purpose for which it was created. I understand that the New Zealand Government has now had to wind back that system.

As far as the Opposition is concerned, the best form of welfare by any stretch of the imagination is the capacity to offer people a job, precisely to overcome the problems noted in the Government's own paper: the perception of young people who are facing hardship. They have the difficulty of low self-esteem and they have a feeling that they have been let down by the community. We can give people supplementary support till the cows come home; the fundamental fact is that young people, in fact all people within the work force age, want to feel that their lives have some meaning, that as individuals they have some capacity to control events in their own lives. They know too well that the only effective way that can be done is to have employment and, through employment, be able to achieve that self-esteem which so many thousands of young Australians have been totally devoid of and lacking because of government policy in recent months. That is why we will be introducing measures to help business get back onto its feet, with the fundamental objective of creating more jobs.

Our Fightback plan will be to cut taxes, improve education, restart business and therefore to create more secure jobs, both for parents and for their children. We believe that the family must be the central building block of our society. That is why we propose doubling the family allowance for families earning under $30,000 per year; for those earning between $30,00 and $40,000, family allowances will increase by 50 per cent; while families earning more than $40,000 will receive a 6 per cent increase.

I refer now to the waiting periods for access to JSA and for education leavers, which is part of the amendments before the House today. Approximately 30,000 youth under the age of 18 are on Job Search allowance. In August of this year youth unemployment—those unemployed between the ages of 15 and 19—was a horrendous 34 per cent, an absolute record since statistics have been kept in this country. That represents over three times the general level of unemployment. The sad fact is that 49,700 of last year's school leavers did not get into universities in Australia this year because there were not sufficient places.

Youth unemployment as a proportion of youth population is still less than it was in the early 1980s. While this reflects a smaller youth labour force due to the desirable increase in youth participation in full time education, it clearly signifies a significant amount of hidden unemployment. Many young people are enrolling in school or staying in school due to the lack of available work. In the last two years the Government has made a virtue of the fact that it has increased substantially the school retention rates. Nobody disputes that. I accept the need for children to be well educated. That is a fundamental objective of the policy of the Liberal and National parties, but having kept children at school for an additional two or three years, the inevitable fact still remains that when they finally complete their secondary education, for far too many of them, some 30 per cent, there is nowhere to go. That is a reflection of the total failure of this Government's education, employment and economic policies over recent years.

The key characteristic of the youth labour market is the collapse of full time job opportunities. This has threatened the opportunities for young Australians to gain skills and experience. As the Sydney Morning Herald's Peter Hartcher noted recently:

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental problem confronting Australia is that it cannot grow its economy fast enough to make serious inroads into its unemployment problem.

Members of the Government know, as we know, that there has to be an absolute minimum of 3 per cent economic growth a year just to create enough jobs for the natural population growth and for the school leavers. The estimates contained in this year's Budget are exactly that: they are directed at 3 per cent and they anticipate a growth of 800,000 jobs over the next four years. Sadly, that is not enough to take up the slack of the million people who are currently out of the work force, of at least an additional half a million people who have simply dropped out of the system but who otherwise would be available for work, and it significantly does not take account of the fact that an additional 140,000 to 160,000 people are coming onto the labour market each year, the majority of whom are young Australians who ask nothing more of this nation than that they should have the opportunity to make a contribution to its growth, to its success and to its standing in the world, as did their parents.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Opposition are saying time and time again that the saddest thing before this nation is that we are passing on to our children a lower standard of living than that which was inherited by us or by our parents. That is the most diabolical demonstration of the failure of this Government over the last 10 years. The Prime Minister can stand here as he does on occasions and tell us that job participation over the last 10 years has increased. And well it might have, considering that the population over that period has grown by a couple of million people. The sad fact is that in terms of economic growth, which is the engine which drives the economy—there is no other form of growth except economic growth which creates jobs for the Australian people—the Government's solution is found to be absolutely wanting.

Australia's record high unemployment, the highest level at any time since the Great Depression, has been caused by Labor's engineered recession. It is also due to wages costs and inappropriate wage relativities. The Government and the ACTU continue to deny the relevance of wage costs and those rigidities in creating the current crisis, a crisis which, above all, has kept out of the labour market thousands upon thousands of school leavers and is driving out of the labour market thousands upon thousands of middle-aged Australians aged 45 and above. They are the people who are demonstrating the period of longest unemployment and they are the people which government policy continues to ignore. Sadly, therefore, the Government continues not to address the wages issue in planning an overall solution to these problems. For that reason the Government's Youth Forum, which is the basis for some of this legislation, was virtually useless. It talked about increasing training positions, increasing subsidised jobs and funding for environmental programs.

Another proposal was earlier access to unemployment benefits, and that is contained in one of the Bills we are debating today. But ultimately these are nothing more than quick fix measures. They do nothing to change the fundamental structural causes of our current massive unemployment problem.

Let us now examine the solutions put forward by the coalition. As I said earlier, we are not opposing this legislation because, in some of these amendments in particular, the Government is following in our direction. For example, the proposal that the conditions relating to the education leavers deferment period be relaxed by part time work is consistent with our policies of encouraging part time work while on Job Search allowance. I would hope to see the Government extend this approach to middle aged unemployed people as well, because that is not the case now.

This matter was covered in detail in our own employment statement released some two months ago, where we relaxed a number of the criteria covering access to benefits specifically to identify the fact that we are no longer in the relatively luxurious position of saying that the world consists of two classes: those who are unemployed on benefits and those in full time employment. We are now going through a period of Australia's economic cycle, which could go on indefinitely, when a significant proportion of the population will have access at best to part time or temporary work. That is the work which we now have to identify and relate to the mix of our welfare programs. Regrettably, the Government has not yet taken that on board adequately. However, we have urged the Government to take up longer term structural changes to Australia's attitudes to employment.

The coalition will end the discrimination against young people in the labour market by establishing a minimum youth training wage of $3 an hour for 15- to 17-year-olds and $3.50 for 18- to 20-year-olds. We expect that in our first two years of office we should be able to create at least 100,000 jobs with wages at that youth training wage level. We will also supplement this training wage by issuing training vouchers and guaranteeing that no young person will be worse off than if he or she had stayed on Job Search allowance. These proposals will create real jobs and give employers an opportunity to give young school leavers that first job opportunity which is so critical to getting one's feet on the ladder of economic self-sufficiency. They will also reduce the need of young people to have faster access to Job Search allowance, which the Social Security Amendment Bill is proposing.

These Bills are a result of the Government trying to ease access to welfare payments to people most hard hit by the recession: families and youth. But again, as I said, the Government is essentially only fiddling around the edges instead of addressing the real cause of the problem. There are nearly 1.25 million Australians dependent on unemployment benefits, and that represents 800,000 claimants, their 240,000 spouses and 330,000 children.

The package we put to the Australian people in July this year was the most comprehensive addressing of these issues that any Opposition has presented in Australia's recent history. This is because the magnitude of Australia's unemployment problem is of such fundamental concern to all of us. I often wonder how members on the Government side, who claim to be representing a Party that looks after the interests of the working people of Australia, are able to look at themselves in the mirror of life and look at their own constituents and honestly say that in the last 10 years they have governed this country in the interests of those people. Quite clearly, the evidence is there for all to see. It has been the failure of this Government over that period that has led to this situation.

If we compare Australia with the rest of the world, in particular with the OECD, we see that the sad fact is that in 1970 we had an unemployment rate equal to half the OECD average and that today it is one of the highest in the OECD. We know there has been a collapse in full time employment, affecting males more than females, and since July 1990 the number of part time jobs for full time work has been much greater than in previous recessions. This is not surprising given that the recession is the worst, as I said, for 60 years and that on-costs, which have a fundamental effect on whether one employs that extra marginal unit of labour, have continued to increase in recent years.

Sadly, in that context, youth unemployment reached a record of 35.8 per cent in June 1992. As I said earlier, it is three times the unemployment rate for those aged 20 and over. Sadly, there is further hidden youth unemployment with many young people who would prefer to work being forced to stay at school or in training institutions. Around 300,000 Australians have been unemployed for over a year, and half of this number are over 35 years of age.

In February 1992, the 797,000 people receiving unemployment benefits had about 546,000 dependants, including 327,500 relying on unemployment benefits. It has approximately doubled over the past two years to 1.3 million people or 7 per cent of the total Australian population. We know what the causes of the unemployment crisis are: Labor's engineered recession, wage costs and inappropriate wage relativities. They are the two fundamental problems and they are the two issues on which this Government, linked as it is with the ACTU and the trade union movement, demonstrates yet again the tendency of the last 10 years to work on the basic principle of big government, big business and big unions. But between those three legs of its fundamental support base lies the vast majority of the Australian people. Of that vast majority now the Government has at least 1 1/2 million people who are not in the labour market but wish to be there. They wonder what the future is going to hold for their children if current policies continue. It is perfectly clear that it cannot be a successful future unless there is a fundamental change in the direction of this nation—a change which this Government has demonstrated more than clearly its inability and its unwillingness to address.

As I said earlier, there are now 167,000 young Australians aged between 15 and 20 receiving the Job Search allowance or Newstart allowance. We believe that it is necessary to provide appropriate welfare and support arrangements to ensure that those on youth training wages and the Austrain program which we will initiate in government are not disadvantaged in terms of their transition from the social welfare system. For those living at home, the minimum youth training wage would pay significantly more than the current Job Search allowance. For those under 18, the $114 minimum wage rate is approximately 78 per cent higher and, for those under 20, 69 per cent higher, than the JSA rate, providing a real incentive to get off unemployment benefits and into a job.

For those members of the Government who spent so much time back in July talking about sweat wages and forcing people into jobs of this nature, it is amusing that when, within weeks of our announcement, the Prime Minister finally came out with his package. The actual bottom line difference between our youth training wage and the Government's package was 77c a week. After all that noise, all that performance, all that effort to frighten everybody, and all that determination to demonstrate how the Opposition was made up of ogres who had no objective in mind other than to destroy the future of the youth of Australia, the best the Government could come up with was a differential of 77c. The difference between the Government's figure and ours is this: we have said quite clearly that this is a minimum training wage, with emphasis on the word minimum.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no training.

—It does contain training. Side by side with this package we are also offering the training voucher. The training voucher again opens up to hundreds of thousands of young people training opportunities which they will not get under the Government's current policy.

PARA.TAB: This is of fundamental importance because it is the mixture of on the job training supplemented by academic or technical training which will determine, in time, the overall success of our young Australians in being able to compete, not just in the Australian labour market but also in the international labour market. The point which the Opposition continues to emphasise in this House and elsewhere is that Australia must be able to compete with the rest of the world. We must be in a position where world best practice is applied in Australia, whether it be in training programs, education programs or the way in which we work and, above all, in the levels of productivity which must be obtained from that level of work.

These are the directions in which we want to take Australia. They are different from those of this Government. This Government, as we saw yesterday at the Press Club, is led by a Prime Minister who has nowhere to go and nothing to offer. He spent the whole half-hour at the Press Club condemning, attacking, complaining, whingeing and whining about a set of policy principles outlined in Fightback. This is the document which will lead Australia forward at a time when the best the Government can do is carp about the policies of an Opposition when, as the Prime Minister demonstrated yesterday, it has nothing to offer in its stead. They are not my words or my sentiments; they are the words of those who listened yesterday. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing delineates us quite so clearly from the Opposition as the matter that is the subject of the Social Security Amendment Bill. We are indeed poles apart. This amendment to the Social Security Act is typical of this Government and its ability to respond to people. This amendment is known within Caucus as the Crawford amendment. It should really be known as the Forrester amendment, after a person on my staff, Colleen Forrester. How did this come about? Quite simply, in April this year with the one-off family allowance payment to many families, for the first time many people said that they found themselves in a position to be able to spend a deal of money on winter clothes, school books or other larger items which they had been unable to purchase previously.

PARA.TAB: I might say, for the benefit of members of the Opposition who seem to deride this as welfare, that we in fact see family payments as a right. Australian families are entitled to payments from Australian taxpayers and the community because we believe they are necessary.

This proposal—the idea of flexibility and the option of being able to pay family allowance in a block or simply fortnightly—was then taken to the Minister for Family Support and Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons), who is currently at the table. His ability and compassion were demonstrated in that he was able to respond to the demands of people at large. That is why we have before us today a Social Security Amendment Bill which enables families to make a choice about the way in which they will receive that family payment advance. That is how this proposal came about. It shows the Government's ability to respond to people's demands and to do so with speed and flexibility. We are very definitely about the intervention of government. We are about ensuring that people's needs and entitlements are met.

Of course, Opposition members cannot make a speech in this House without, yet again, decrying the fact that young people are staying on at school. What a wicked, wicked thing it is that the poor should want to stay on in years 11 and 12 when previously this was only the prerogative of the rich! Somehow it was all right if one was tory and one's parents had money. Then one could stay on in years 11 and 12. That is a choice those people have made routinely. But because people who are not rich want to make that choice, those opposite think that it is wrong and bad.

We understand the bottom line in all of this. As I remind honourable members in this House constantly, adults in Queensland over 42 years of age have not even had a high school education because they went to year 8 and did the Scholarship exam, which was later abolished. Honourable members should look at the facts and figures and ask themselves why we have middle aged men in Queensland with so little formal education who are now finding themselves in the unemployment queues because they do not have the skills to meet the needs of the twenty-first century in Australia. It is because formal schooling for very many people in that 40 to 50 age range finished at years 5, 6 and 7 when they went out into these dead end jobs which are espoused by the shadow spokesperson for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

On this side of the House we know about dead end jobs and standards of living. It makes me somewhat bemused when I hear Opposition members talking about standards of living. We know what it is like to live in a community which has no Medicare; when having sick children and no money means that one has to depend on the next door neighbour or watch one's children become terribly ill and hope that somehow they will get better because one does not have a car, telephone or cash to go to the doctor. Do not tell me that that is fantasy land, because we on this side of the House know and understand that that was what life was like for many people in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. Indeed, we had another taste of it with the introduction of the Medicare co-payment, which I took a very prominent role in getting rid of earlier in the year.

I know and understand what it is like for people who have no access to the kinds of provisions and lifestyle which many in this House—and certainly those honourable members in the Opposition—take for granted: the telephone, the car, the ready access to computers, and the ready access to all manner of powerful people. We know and understand on this side of the House what our job is here: it is to represent people who, through no fault of their own, do not have access to such things. It is our job to ensure that they have that access.

Do not talk about the fact that standards of living have not risen, that the poor now have access to Medicare, that the poor now stay on at school in years 11 and 12, or—what is even worse—that they go to universities. We have Labor lawyers and doctors. Is it not wicked—Labor lawyers and doctors? What a hide for us to suggest that we should have access to tertiary places, which were once seen as a prerogative of privilege and which will be so again as we return to full up-front payments for people to enter tertiary sectors if—God forbid—the Opposition ever gets back into office. But we know that will not happen.

We also hear great discussions about the size of the participation rate and the work force and some of the changes that are brought about by changes to the waiting time in education leaving periods. I will give honourable members a few facts about the participation rate in other countries. In this country, our participation rate is somewhere around 64 to 65 per cent. In the USA, it is 54 to 55 per cent and in Europe it is in the high forties. That is the difference. In Australia, irrespective of gender or age, people expect and have demanded the right to work. It is indeed their right.

Honourable members should go to other places and have a look at them. They will see that in some places there is no equal pay for women—in fact, there is not even an opportunity for very many married women to work. In a whole range of places, participation and the right to work are not acknowledged; nor are people paid unemployment benefits. European participation, at somewhere between 15 and 20 per cent less than in the work force in Australia, creates a different kind of unemployment situation. One can also perhaps espouse the American situation. I remind the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) that the population of Queensland—three million people—sleeps on the streets of Washington on any one night under the great Republican President.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's nonsense.

—That is a fact. Three million people sleep on the streets of Washington on any one night. It is a F-A-C-T. That is what people get from republican governments. That is what happens when people are denied houses; when they are denied education; when they are denied welfare. Opposition members should not tell us about comparisons with the great tory governments. They should look at the UK and its levels of unemployment. They should look at the north of Ireland, at places such as Belfast and Derry, and then tell me what tory government has done for unemployment in those places. They will see families that have never had jobs. Opposition members should not espouse those tory principles here, because we know and understand them. We lived with them for 30 years and we know the differences. While Government members decry the unemployment situation here, we endeavour and will continue to endeavour to do every single thing that is necessary. We will continue to provide education and training for all people within our skill share and labour market programs.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate organisations such as the Dusseldorp Skills Forum, who piloted a program called TRAC—training for retail and commerce—in Wollongong, which has a 100 per cent success rate. We are looking at trialing it in my electorate. That is the kind of program for hands-on work which we do with our young people to ensure that they get the very best of opportunities.

I turn to the opening up of the TAFE colleges and the extra places in TAFE—for too long neglected by our State governments. We understand the importance and the meaning of this. We constantly hear the expansion in the tertiary sector decried by people opposite: `Is it not terrible that we are expanding the tertiary sector and letting all these people into universities—and for what? It seemed to be all right for them. The unemployment statistics would bear out that those people who leave school at year 10 have a 100 per cent chance of being unemployed, while people who complete tertiary degrees have a very minimal chance. That is the kind of difference: the change in the labour market. As we would all know and understand, by the year 2010, 70 per cent of the jobs which are currently—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have listened to the honourable member for Forde for about five minutes talking about just about everything but the legislation before the House. I cannot imagine how it is in any way relevant.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—There is no point of order. This is a cognate debate and it seems to me that the honourable member for Forde is in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. When Opposition members examine the facts about the ways in which we as a government address the issues of youth unemployment, our social security system, our education system and leavers waiting periods, as well as the opportunities we provide for young people in our training areas, skill share programs, TAFEs and universities, they will have cause to worry. Let me tell them that out in the community Australians know and understand that a tory government means that they will pay full up-front fees for their university and TAFE courses. Skill share programs will no longer be there. Employers understand that the privatisation of the CES means that they will have to pay—user pays. When honourable members opposite look at the JSA for young people, when they look at applications and the kind of support we as a government philosophically continue to believe is the right of every Australian—to have access to income support and to have family payments paid to them in a way which they will use and choose and develop for the betterment of their families—there is no question about the way they will feel.

PARA.TAB: We can point to tory governments. What do we see? We see the shambles that is the UK, the horror and tragedy of areas that have 90 and 100 per cent unemployment. We can see the kind of homelessness. Only across the Tasman in New Zealand we can see the decimation of the welfare system. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) told us that the Opposition would cut family allowance payments. We can definitely say—there is no question about it—that the philosophies of the Government and the Opposition are not the same. This is reflected in the legislation before us today.

We are a government responding to families, listening to families and listening to their needs, and saying, `We are here as a servant of the people. We represent you and we will do what you ask'. That is what the amendments before the House today reflect. They do not reflect ideology, rampant and rabid, with the zealotry that has been displayed by those opposite. The way in which we operate and what we as a government believe is at the core of these amendments. When we hear people talking about our young unemployed, we too acknowledge that unemployed youth are in need of particular and special services. We believe they should be provided with income support but, more importantly, they should be supplied with training and access to training, irrespective of the costs, not with the kind of full up-front charges that we hear about in this House.

The honourable member for Bradfield spoke about the role of self-esteem, the role of education and the whole role of control within young people's lives. He believes that it is only under a tory government that we can see self-esteem rise. I fail to see how self-esteem can rise when many of these people will not have any payments at all. Young people whose mothers happen to be sole parents will have no income whatsoever because these children will be over 12. A whole range of people will be affected. Women between 60 and 65 years of age will no longer be eligible for the age pension. (Quorum formed)

When one tells the truth, those opposite do not want to hear it. They do not want our young people in the gallery to know that they will need $80,000 to $100,000 to meet full up-front fees at universities. They do not want our families to know that the Government responds to their needs and the demands. They do not want business to know that the privatisation of CES means user pays and fewer jobs in those companies that have to pay for the running of the CES. PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for McPherson has indicated, we are talking about two specific proposals to amend the Social Security Act. The first one that I would like to talk about relates to the amendments to the education leavers waiting periods. This will make a substantial improvement in the opportunities for young unemployed people to access income support arrangements within the community. The main purpose of the education leavers waiting periods is to encourage young people, particularly secondary school students, to remain in education by generally denying them access to income support during the long summer vacation.

The Social Security Amendment Bill introduces four modifications to the existing education leavers waiting period provisions in the Social Security Act of 1991. Allowing periods of part time and casual work to be taken into account when calculating a reduction in the ELWP will provide an incentive for young people to participate in the work force, even if only on a part time or casual basis, and thereby develop an early attachment to the work force. At present only full time work can be taken into account. We are now amending this so that part time and casual work can also be taken into account. That will provide an incentive for students to raise some of their own income.

If, for example, a young school leaver were subject to a 13-week waiting period and worked, say, for 35 hours part time in the first two weeks of those 13 weeks, those 35 hours would reduce the waiting period by a week. Each additional seven hours worked over and above the 35 hours would reduce the waiting period by a day. So we are providing an incentive for young people to seek out part time and casual employment because it will reduce the waiting period that they have to face before they can go on to other levels of income support. For a number of reasons young school leavers are sometimes unaware of the need to register with the CES and apply for the Job Search allowance. This is because they may be badly informed of the requirements, often through word of mouth from other school leavers, may be unsure of their future education plans, or may simply misunderstand their obligation to register and apply. There have been outreach activities by the Department of Social Security, such as school visits, which have been successful in assisting young school leavers to understand their social security rights and responsibilities. I think this is a pattern that we need to encourage and increase.

The first change in the Bill is expected to benefit some 2,000 young people who gain part time or casual employment, and it will cost an estimated $1.4m in 1992-93. The second change addresses the problem of the 13-week waiting period applicable to secondary school leavers, and it will commence from the day after they cease education or on 15 February in the following year, whichever is the earlier. This will, in a way, protect young school leavers from missing out on income support due to their ignorance or misunderstanding of the current requirements. Currently, Job Search allowance and sickness allowance claimants who leave full time education of at least six months duration must serve a waiting period of 13 weeks for single people under 21 without dependants and six weeks for others.

The third amendment will provide that a waiting period will not need to be served when an income support recipient undertakes a course of education of six months or more but returns to income support within 12 months of cancellation of the earlier social security payment. This change will provide an additional incentive for Job Search or Newstart recipients to undertake longer term education without having to serve another waiting period.

The final change will enable a person subject to a waiting period who qualifies for special benefit to go straight onto the Job Search allowance. At present, such a person would be subject to the stringent special benefit income test and be transferred to Job Search at the end of a waiting period. Being required to satisfy the more stringent income test during the waiting period could dissuade people from taking up part time or casual employment. All of these changes are designed to reduce the waiting periods for young unemployed people who have left full time education and who may be seeking to go on to Job Search while they are looking for full time employment. It will enable them to have a much greater opportunity to access the training and income support programs provided through DEET.

The other part of the Bill is related to, as the honourable member for McPherson pointed out, the lump sum advance on family allowance. The honourable member for McPherson tried to outline some great conspiracy theories about the motivation behind this, but he does not understand that this is simply a measure to introduce greater flexibility. The great success of the additional payment that we made in April was that it enabled families to pay off the sizeable bills that often confront them from time to time during the year, particularly bills that relate to family expenses such as for clothing and the schoolbooks that they need to get their children into higher education or even into the non-compulsory secondary education sector.

What we are trying to do here is give families much greater flexibility so that, if they choose—and the major point that we need to stress is that it is a choice for them; they can opt to seek it or they can choose not to—to ask for a certain amount in a lump sum they can then use that amount to pay off a large bill at any one time. We are not saying that we will give them all their family allowance at once. There is a limit—a maximum of $136.50—that they can take, but it means that at least they will be able to use that amount of money to pay off a sizeable bill at that time. The rest of the family allowance will still be paid to them in that monthly instalment so that they can use it for the ongoing costs of feeding and clothing their families. It will allow them to budget, knowing that twice a year they are able to get that lump sum and use it to pay off specific bills. I think this measure emphasises the flexibility that we are trying to introduce into our income support programs.

This Government recognises that the comprehensive network of income support programs managed through the Department of Social Security meets the needs of some 4 1/2 million people. To adequately manage such a program, and to provide for the range of different needs that exist within that client group, the processes and programs that we implement have to be more flexible. They have all supported it and believe that it is a worthwhile measure. I believe that this House should give its full support to it. It is quite consistent with the Government's social justice strategy, and it demonstrates a continued commitment to provide support for families that is much more accessible and which will enhance their lives and their capacity to meet the needs of their families. We need to provide an income support program which gives added incentive for families to improve their budgeting and their capacity to meet their various needs as they arise during the year.

The measure affecting waiting periods for education leavers was part of the youth statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made in July and was contained in the Budget. This family allowance measure was also announced in the Budget and will greatly enhance the opportunities for families to better access their family allowance payment.

I would like to spend a couple of minutes talking about another measure that was included in the social security element of the Budget, and it is something that we will be proposing legislation on in the near future; that is, the extension in the Budget of fringe benefits to part pensioners. This Government has recognised that point by extending all fringe benefits that operate within the Commonwealth sphere—and that mainly relates to the health services that are provided and telephone assistance plus assistance from the National Acoustic Laboratory—to those people who are only part pensioners, who get part of their income from private sources and part from the social security system. That will greatly improve their actual standard of living.

There is another measure that I think we need to be considering which I have raised with the Government, as have a number of other members, and that is the need to examine closely the taxation arrangements for all retired Australians. At the moment pensioners have a concessional tax threshold which is higher than the normal tax threshold, but that is applicable only to pensioners. Many of my constituents who are self-funded retirees have said to me that they believe it is a discriminatory practice that one set of older Australians is eligible for a higher tax threshold than another set of older Australians. The two major amendments that we are dealing with today are good news for Australians. I commend the Government for introducing these measures. I particularly commend the Minister at the table, the Minister for Family Support and Minister for Local Government (Mr Simmons), for his initiative in implementing these family allowance amendments because I think they show a greater level of creativity and flexibility in the implementation of government income support programs. I believe we will find that a lot of Australian families will take the option of being paid a lump sum. Although I do not oppose this legislation, I would far prefer this House to be discussing the sorts of economic reforms which would encourage new investment in Australia and new jobs for Australians.

What do these proposed changes to the family allowance mean for Australian families? The legislation puts into effect a Budget proposal to enable people on the family allowance to request lump sum advances for half their family allowance entitlements at the one child rate for six months up to a maximum of $135.85. Of course, this means that the regular fortnightly payments would be reduced accordingly, but this measure, by providing lump sum payments, undoubtedly will help some people who might be having difficulty budgeting for regular household bills or unexpected financial burdens such as health expenses.

When this measure takes effect on 1 January 1993 the name `family allowance' will also be changed to `family payment', and I assume that the current family allowance recipients will be advised of the changes around that time. One does not have to be too cynical to suggest that the timing of this change seems to fit well with the likelihood of a Federal election early next year. However, coming from a Government hell-bent on reversing its dismal electoral fortunes, the timing and nature of these changes come as no surprise.

The Government has had a whole decade to help Australian families to improve their standards of living, but instead it has crippled the Australian economy, creating the worst recession in 60 years and increasing unemployment to record levels. Now, with an election looming on the horizon, the Government is trying to pull a bunny out of the hat. I am sure that many low income Australian families will take advantage of the new family payment measure. They may even be grateful for the changes put forward by the Government, but they will not be fooled by them. The Australian public knows who is to blame for the mess this country is in.

At the time of the last election the Labor Government presided over an economy which had already seen some 510,000 people out of work. Today that figure has increased by a staggering 86 per cent. There are now some 947,500 Australians who cannot find a job. The figure is getting close to one million. That is just the official figure. We all know that thousands more have given up all hope of finding work and have opted out of the work force, while others have gone into some form of educational training, fearing the worst if they are left to venture into the job market today. Amongst the worst affected are young Australians, with more than one-third of all teenagers looking for full time work and many more hidden by the nature of the official statistics.

As far as unemployment is concerned, Western Australia is one of the worst affected States. Last week's unemployment figures were nothing short of a disaster, the State still reeling from a decade of Labor's economic mismanagement. The unemployment rate has continued to increase in Western Australia, going from 10.4 per cent in June to 10.8 per cent in July, and now rising to a postwar record of 11.5 per cent.

But the true situation is far worse. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has confirmed that more than 19,000 unemployed Western Australians do not show up on the official figures. Some 14,000 people are classified as `discouraged job seekers'. In other words, they have simply given up looking for work, often after months of actively pursuing employment, often with hundreds of applicants for each job vacancy. A further 5,000 Western Australians are recorded as actively seeking work but are unable to start within a four week period. Because of this they are not officially classified as unemployed.

Over 19,000, according to the figures, on top of the State's current level of unemployment gives us a clearer picture of the true unemployment situation, in which around 118,000 Western Australians are out of work. This translates to an unemployment rate of not 11.5 per cent as per the official Government statistics but a staggering 13.4 per cent. Furthermore, this figure does not include the number of unemployed people in job training schemes or small business owners and farmers who are working for no income or, worse still, at a loss. It would not surprise me if the genuine unemployment rate in Western Australia was around 15 per cent and it is only a couple of months before the next year's school leavers start to flood onto the job market and swell the ranks of the unemployed.

This legislation is the best the Government can do to relieve the enormous financial pressures on families, especially those in low income groups and the unemployed. These bandaid measures are not enough, especially when one considers that the Government is unable to put in place the ongoing economic reforms this country needs so desperately to generate new jobs.

The Liberal-National coalition will not oppose these changes, but it is particularly interesting to consider our alternatives for assisting Australian families, especially those on low incomes. We start by considering the family allowance scheme itself, which we accept has become a valuable supplement to a family's take-home pay. The coalition's Fightback plan offers significant real help for families, including a doubling of the family allowance payments for families on less than $30,000 a year and a range of other benefits.

This means that, whereas the Government's changes next January will enable a family on less than $30,000 to obtain lump sum payments of $135.85, Fightback would double this amount. In fact, on current rates the family in this situation would be able to receive a lump sum payment of $271.70 under Fightback. Quite clearly, this will be of far more direct assistance than the amount being offered by the Government.

Other households on higher incomes will also benefit under Fightback. Our intention is to give most assistance to low income earners who have been hard hit by a decade of Labor and Labor Government incompetence; for example, families on an annual income of between $30,000 and $40,000 will be eligible for a six monthly lump sum payment of $203.78 under Fightback compared with $135.85 under the Government's proposals. Even those relatively well off families on incomes of up to $55,000 will gain, as their lump sums will be paid at the rate of $146 rather than the Government's $135.85 payment. The bottom line is that the coalition's alternative for low income families is literally twice as good as the Government's scheme.

Importantly, families in receipt of the family payment should realise that the Government is not increasing their payment under the changes being debated today. The lump sum payments are not additional payments but represent a brought-forward amount. On the other hand, we can be certain that the Government is planning a hidden tax agenda in the highly unlikely event that it is re-elected, enabling it to clawback money from families and businesses to help fund the nation's exploding Budget deficit.

The benefits for Australian families planned under Fightback go much further, as I have described. Families with working parents will be much better off when the coalition's income tax cuts are introduced and their take-home pay is increased significantly. Indeed, Fightback will slash personal income tax by around 30 per cent, saving Australians a massive $13 billion. The tax free threshold will be raised, freeing at least another 320,000 low income earners from having to pay tax at all. Marginal tax rates will be much lower so that an average employee will be able to earn considerably more money without paying a higher tax rate. For example, a person on a typical wage of $25,000 currently pays tax at a marginal rate of 38c in the dollar, whereas under Fightback he or she will pay tax at a rate of only 30c in the dollar.

Furthermore, the same person could even double his wage—not by a secret tax agenda, I might add—at the 30 per cent rate under the Fightback plan, compared with 46 per cent under the Government's present tax scales. It is no wonder that so many Australian workers are reluctant to work overtime to help support their families when, for example, they know that nearly half their extra earnings will be taken in tax. Fightback gives them the initiative to work that overtime by rewarding them with lower tax rates, so that their take home pay will be far greater. Our commitments to double family allowances, to increase the family allowance supplement by 6 per cent, and to index the dependent spouse rebate, are other examples of our commitment to the financial well-being of Australian families. So, too, is our plan to scrap fuel excise, thereby reducing petrol prices by around 19c a litre, or $11 for every tankful of fuel for the family car.

Our decision to put aside $90m for increased child-care support is particularly important for many families with both parents in the work force, and who are currently finding it hard to find suitable child-care for their children. Fightback is totally pro-family. This is firmly demonstrated in our new approach towards health policy, which gives generous tax credits for lower and middle income families to help them afford the benefits of private health cover insurance. For example, families on very low incomes, of below $12,000, will be eligible to a credit of $400 annually. Furthermore, the cost of health care will actually fall under the full impact of the Fightback plan. So while the Government tinkers around with the family allowance scheme, the coalition has come up with a comprehensive package to assist Australian families in a variety of ways.

Another example of how Fightback helps families is by reforming the education system. We believe that parents should be able to play a greater role in the education of their children. Consequently, the emphasis will be on a change from the system which funds the institutions to one which is more responsive to the needs of the individual. In turn, this will promote the quality of education, further strengthening the family unit.

Let us not forget the plight of the many thousands of Australian families which are directly affected by the present unemployment crisis. With 10.9 per cent of the work force officially recognised as being unemployed—and the real situation, undoubtedly, far worse than that—there are few people whose families are not affected, or who do not know a friend, relative, or workmate who has not lost his job.

The legislation before the House today, the Social Security Amendment Bill, does nothing to assist these families in the most constructive way possible—by creating jobs. As I said earlier, this will not happen until major economic reforms are put in place. Nor will the Government's measures in this legislation do anything constructive to relieve the various side-effects of the chronic unemployment we suffer in Australia today.

Families are becoming increasingly affected by the spiralling crime rates, for example, as many people become more frustrated and more desperate and turn to crime in the face of long term unemployment and lack of genuine opportunities. The key to helping families and creating job opportunities is to restart the business sector—especially, small business.

Australian enterprises desperately need a reduction in operating cost to improve their viability and, in many cases, to prevent actual bankruptcy. Instead, the Government has fired a barrage of new costs at the business sector, including the superannuation guarantee charge, which will add 3 per cent to payroll costs, rising eventually to 12 per cent. It has been estimated that this will result in 60,000 to 100,000 jobs losses over time.

Certainly, from my discussions with a range of business proprietors, I am aware of many instances whereby businesses cannot support these extra costs and, as a result, must allow some employees to go. Businesses have cut their own operating costs to the bone to keep afloat. These extra costs cannot be absorbed in any other way. It is hardly the way to promote job security and to assist families. As well as that, there is the ridiculous training levy, which will do little to promote a comprehensive national training effort, but which has impacted adversely on business cash flows.

The fuel excise tax, which now raises $7.26 billion in revenue from private and business motorists, imposes significant costs on the business sector, as do other taxes, such as the wholesale sales tax and the capital gains tax. The answer to reducing business costs and generating new employment opportunities is to ease this burden on business. This is why the Fightback plan abolishes fuel excise, scraps sales tax, gives capital gains tax concessions, throws the training levy out the window, and pegs the superannuation guarantee charges at the rate applicable at the next election. All in all, seven taxes on business will be abolished, and total savings of $20 billion will be passed on. One tax which will go completely, of course, is payroll tax. This is nothing more than a tax on employment, which has contributed towards the nation's current unemployment crisis. There is no rhyme or reason to why payroll tax can be supported any longer, but there are plenty of good reasons for getting rid of it.

To start with, it has been estimated that 175,000 new jobs would be created. That would take care of nearly 20 per cent of the nation's unemployment, and have more impact on family living standards than any reshuffling of Government programs, such as family allowance.

As before honourable members on the opposite side scoff at any assessment of the impact of the proposed initiatives. Let me remind them of what the Prime Minister once said. He is reported to have boasted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Labor would solve the immediate problem of unemployment by taking at least 150,000 to 200,000 people off the dole queue with its reduction in payroll tax.

That was 15 years ago, and, quite clearly, the impact of a total abolition of payroll tax today would be far greater. Recently, in response to Western Australia's continuing unemployment climb, I called on the Premier, Carmen Lawrence, to take steps to scrap payroll tax. It would show genuine courage if she were at least to put the interests of Western Australians before her own political objectives by enabling bipartisan support for the aim of the coalition's Fightback plan—to abolish payroll tax. After all, it was Premier Lawrence who pointed out how payroll tax is so unfair, saying:
It doesn't matter how profitable the business, payroll tax simply relates to the number of people that you employ.
She has even described the tax as bizarre, and has labelled it as a tax on employment. But paying lip service to the problem is not enough. Australian families deserve more than this.

PARA.TAB: The second piece of legislation being debated today concerns various changes to free up access to benefits in the wake of the July Youth Summit. While these measures may encourage a number of young people to remain in education, they will do nothing to resolve the fundamental problems facing our youth today. With statistics showing that one in three teenagers is out of work, and that many more are frightened to take chances in the labour market, it is imperative that the Government take action to create new job opportunities for our youth.

Today's legislation is tinkering at the edges. Meaningful inroads cannot be made until the reforms that I have mentioned earlier are put into place. Also, to encourage youth training and employment, it is essential to reform the nation's industrial relations system, which all too often discriminates against young people. For example, why would a hotel manager employ an inexperienced 21-year-old when the present system requires the same wage to be paid as if the employee had been an older and more experienced person. This is just one anomaly in the system which discriminates against youth, and has helped create a vacuum in youth employment.

Fightback sets out to free up the present system of industrial relations and presents a comprehensive approach to vocational training to encourage employers to take on young people, train them, and give them permanent jobs. This has to be better than the fiddling around the edges of the present system.

All in all, the coalition does not oppose this legislation. But we make the point that much more needs to be done to help Australian families, to give the young people of this country the opportunity they are entitled to and which we on election to Parliament as their elected representatives owe them.

The last speaker for the Opposition, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), talked about the Fightback proposals for family allowance as if they were going to be some big deal. All of a sudden these families are going to be rich because of Fightback, that magic document which is going to fix everything. Let us have a look at the Fightback proposals in so far as they affect the question of family allowances. Those opposite would introduce tough income testing arrangements, slashing the upper income limit for family allowance from $64,000 to $55,000 for a family with one child. In this scenario, some 107,000 families would lose under the Opposition's proposals—and this is just a conservative estimate.

Those opposite would knock off 15 per cent of families who are trying to feed their kids and lay on an impost of 15 per cent in the form of a tax that would take more food out of the mouths of the needy and put it in the mouths of the well off. Under Fightback those remaining on the family allowance would face a more complex means test which would be difficult to administer and difficult for families to understand.

This would introduce disincentives for some middle income Australian families to increase their income.

In summary, the coalition's family payment proposals are the classic three-card trick. Those opposite talk about us tricking. The Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) will help people during their times of need by improving client services, which I will talk about in a second—in this case giving families a much needed advance to buy school books, uniforms and other items that come in a cluster at a particular time of the year.

The honourable member for Forrest brought up another matter which I need to address. It did not really have a lot to do with this issue. Nevertheless something needs to be pointed out. These Bills are yet another example of how this Government targets those most in need, as distinct from those opposite, who intend to turn social security recipients into targets and knock them off the Job Search allowance, and to abandon the great record in client services that this Government has achieved over the past few years. I want to talk about the question of client services within the Department of Social Security. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) has just walked in. She was on the same committee with me when we were backbenchers. We were on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I remember going around the country with the Minister looking at these things and checking the situation out for ourselves. As part of this inquiry we looked at the way the Department of Social Security delivered its services. I have to admit that at that time there were a lot of deficiencies in client service delivery. We came down with a report which was later known as the O'Keefe report, named after our chairperson. No-one likes to have to go to the Department of Social Security to ask for help, but it is a fact of life these days. People would walk into this particular office and be very upset. I am told that people now get dressed up to go to that same office because the surroundings are so nice and because they are treated so well by the staff. The whole staff arrangements have been restructured in such a way that decision makers are now at the counter. We have been able to introduce such things as on-line processing. We have done all sorts of things. We have computerised the whole Department. We have in the Department one of the best computer systems certainly in Australia and probably in the world. We have been doing these things because we understand that people taken out of employment or retrenched through no fault of their own sometimes need help. There has to be an income support system to act as a safety net.

I have been involved in a number of client service initiatives in the Department of Social Security. One of the ones that I am the most proud of is our current youth pilot projects, where we try to get our services to young people in the community. I am not talking about the street kids. I am not talking about those children who have a home to go to but do not want to go home, who want to do whatever they want to do around the streets; I am talking about the genuine homeless youth. I am talking about those kids that leave home because they are forced to. Believe me, Mr Deputy Speaker, there are thousands of them. For better or for worse, that is the way things are at the moment. The fact is that there are a lot of single parent families, marriage breakdowns, divorces, and that sort of thing. Sometimes the children are forced to leave home because of breakdown in the relationship, breakdown of the marriage or simply because a new partner comes into the home.

I can assure honourable members that the vast majority of fair dinkum homeless youth—I am not talking about street kids; there is a difference—are kids that have been forced to leave and are not welcome to come back into the home. What happens to these children, some as young as 13 or 14? Not long ago I attended the official opening by the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, at a place on the Gold Coast called MacLaughlin House, which is a sort of halfway house.
