This Bill will amend the taxation law to implement personal tax cuts from 1994-95, and for subsequent income years, as outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the One Nation statement of 26 February 1992. This gives effect to the Government's commitment to deliver on these tax reductions without resort to the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax. It adds to this Government's unparalleled record in introducing progressive reform of the taxation system and confirms Australia's position under this Government as a fair and low tax country. In 1990, taking account of all levels of government, Australia had the third lowest tax burden in the OECD. Only the United States and Turkey have a lower burden of taxation.

The reductions in the tax rates will be implemented in two stages from 1 July 1994 and 1 January 1996. New scales of personal tax rates for incomes within the range $20,700 to $50,000 will operate from 1 July 1994. Further reductions in those rates will apply from 1 January 1996. The Bill contains the rate scales to apply for 1994-95, 1996-97 and subsequent income years. As the second reduction in personal tax rates has effect from 1 January 1996, the Bill also contains a composite rate scale for the 1995-96 income year. That scale is obtained from an average of the tax rates to apply from 1 July 1994 and 1 January 1996 respectively.

The reductions will result in the current 38 per cent rate for the income range $20,700 to $36,000 being reduced to 30 per cent over a two-year period. The income range will also be widened. After two years, the new 30 per cent rate will apply to the income range $20,700 to $40,000, some $4,000 wider than the current range.

The current 46 per cent rate for the income range $36,000 to $50,000 will be reduced to 40 per cent over the same period with a corresponding reduction of $4,000 in the income range to a range of $40,000 to $50,000. This means that for someone earning $28,000 a year, for example, the tax cuts will increase disposable income by about $11 a week. The tax cuts will be reflected in lower pay as you earn deductions from 1 July 1994. For the forward estimate years, the cost to the revenue of the personal tax cuts is estimated at $3.2 billion in 1994-95 and $5.2 billion in 1995-96. The measures I am introducing today are an integral part of the Government's tax reform agenda as detailed in the statement on tax policy which I propose to table today.

In the Budget, the Government indicated its desire to reduce the deficit in 1995-96 to between half and one per cent of GDP after allowing for the cuts to personal income tax. It is possible this outcome could be achieved without resort to any additional revenue measures. The Government did, however, identify three possible measures which could be considered, if necessary, to yield in excess of $2 billion.

In the statement on tax policy the Government outlines measures which will have the net effect of reducing the deficit by $2 billion in 1995-96. But in order to put this issue beyond doubt, the Government has gone further and by advancing the date of implementation of those measures the deficit will be reduced by $4.5 billion over the two years 1994-95 and 1995-96. In this way the Government will pursue sensible tax reform based on fairness and efficiency but will also bolster the stance of fiscal policy. The consequence of this action is that the Government is confident that the deficit reduction program implicit in the Budget will be exceeded during the course of the forward estimate years.

Since 1983, the Government has radically transformed the taxation system into a more effective, more efficient and fairer system. In the 1990s, the Government will maintain the effectiveness of the existing tax system to meet new challenges and to fund the vital activities of government in providing for the security and development of our nation and the well-being of the people. The Government's taxation policies have consistently produced more equitable sharing of the tax burden and lower marginal tax rates. These policies have been pursued both through changes to the design of the income tax and through the continuous improvement of tax administration and compliance.

In 1985, we considered and rejected the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax and opted instead to make taxes on the income base more efficient and equitable. In particular, we introduced the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, which are directed at previously untaxed income received by predominantly high income individuals. Other reforms have been introduced progressively to increase the effectiveness of tax administration and to improve tax compliance. This program has included the introduction of self-assessment of income tax—supported by substantially upgraded audit programs—the introduction of the tax file number system and other information reporting, modernisation of tax compliance through a major new computer acquisition program matched with organisational changes in the Tax Office and the reorientation of the Tax Office towards a revision of information and advisory services to taxpayers to assist them in meeting their tax obligations.

The Government's policy approach has resulted in a broader income base and reduced tax evasion and reduced tax avoidance. This approach has enabled the Government to reduce, substantially, marginal tax rates. Since 1983 the top rate has been lowered from 60 per cent to 47 per cent and the bottom rate has been cut from 30 per cent to 20 per cent.

Since 1983, the Government has introduced a range of measures particularly to assist low income earners. For example, cuts to personal income tax rates in January 1991 raised the threshold at which tax is payable from $5,100 to $5,400 and reduced the bottom marginal tax rate from 21c to 20c in the dollar. At the same time, the income level up to which the bottom rate applies was extended from $17,650 to $20,700. By contrast, when this Government took office in 1983, the tax free threshold was set just below $5,000 and the bottom marginal rate of 30c in the dollar applied to incomes up to $19,500, and above that level the rate was 46c in the dollar.

This Government introduced the family allowance supplement, which provides substantial support for low income families. In the One Nation statement, the Government provided further assistance for low income families by way of increases in FAS of $3 a week per child from the first payday in April 1992. FAS boosts the disposable income of eligible families by up to $60.80 a fortnight for each child aged up to 13 years and to $85.90 for each child aged between 13 to 15 years.

In addition to the benefits to taxpayers, income tax rate reductions effected by this Government have supported other initiatives by reducing the incentive to avoid or evade tax. In keeping with this broad tax policy strategy since 1983 of making the income tax fair and of reducing evasion, the Government is now undertaking two further initiatives.

The introduction of the fringe benefits tax significantly improved the equity of the tax system because it provided a means of ensuring that income provided in kind was taxed. The FBT was designed with a variety of administrative considerations in mind. The Government believes that it is now appropriate to improve the effectiveness of the FBT, and considerably enhance the fairness of the tax system, by changing the method of calculating the value base of the tax by making it as near to that of income tax as possible.

Other legislation I am introducing today provides that, from April 1994, the fringe benefits tax will be levied on the FBT inclusive value of the fringe benefit and FBT payments will be deductible to the employer for income tax purposes. This is equivalent to the tax treatment of salary, where the employee pays income tax on the gross amount of salary and the employer has a tax deduction equal to the gross amount of that salary. The change to the valuation of the FBT base will raise about $2.5 billion over the two years 1994-95 and 1995-96.

The early introduction of this important legislation will ensure that employers and employees have ample notice of the significant changes to the fringe benefits tax structure. A significant share of the revenue yield of the changes will come from tax exempt government sector employers who have benefited from lower taxes on fringe benefits until now. The Government will discuss this issue with State and Territory governments and local government in the context of the general purpose funding and the next Premiers Conference.

The Government is not considering any other changes to the FBT. In particular, we do not propose to alter the classes of FBT exempt organisations, so that religious institutions and public benevolent institutions will continue to be exempt. Special arrangements will be provided, however, for non-government organisations that are non-taxpaying bodies which are subject to FBT at the moment. The Government does intend changing the various special rules that apply to such benefits as education of children of Australians employed overseas and foreign residents employed in Australia.

The Government will not alter the methods of calculating FBT payable on cars. Neither will the Government reduce the existing concessions applying to particular benefits, such as remote area housing. The Government will ensure that the exemptions for recreational and community facilities will cover such facilities provided to the residents of those communities whose work requires them to live in remote areas of Australia, distant from many such community facilities.

The second source of additional revenues will be a substantial enhancement of the Tax Office's compliance strategies, designed both to further help taxpayers meet their obligations and to enforce greater compliance where necessary. I note in passing that the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee is examining, amongst other things, the help and enforcement aspects of the Tax Office's compliance strategy. The Commissioner of Taxation has provided a report to the Government on means of enhancing tax compliance. I seek leave to table that report, together with my statement on tax policy.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Australian Taxation Office, income tax compliance/ enforcement strategy, 15 September 1992; minute No. 221 from Mr J.P. Boucher, Commissioner of Taxation, to the Treasurer, 15 September 1992; and my statement on tax policy.

PARA.TAB: The Government has endorsed the strategy outlined in the Commissioner's report. We will provide the Australian Taxation Office with the resources necessary to implement that strategy, that is, $114m over the three years from 1993-94 to 1995-96. The strategy involves minimal investment of additional resources to achieve a very significant improvement in revenue and equity.

The enhancement strategy will include an extension of the role of information reporting, using the tax file number system. Legislation to achieve these objectives will be introduced following consultations with the Privacy Commissioner. In addition, there will be enhancement to the record keeping and audit programs of the Tax Office. The existing exemptions for pensioners from the tax file number system will continue. Such pensioners will not be affected by the extended reporting requirements.

The strategy builds on the unprecedented action this Government has taken over the past 10 years to close the net on tax evasion and avoidance. It will result in the collection of substantial revenue that would otherwise remain uncollected. It is estimated that an additional $1,700m will be collected over the two years 1994-95 and 1995-96.

The vast majority of Australians are honest and pay their fair share of tax. The measures I am announcing today are directed at those few Australians who avoid or evade their tax liabilities. Those who choose to oppose these measures are choosing to allow those who are cheating on the tax system to continue to do so at the expense of honest taxpaying members of our community. The combination of help and enforcement strategies as outlined is designed to promote voluntary compliance.

While it is designed to benefit the community rather than to impose additional burdens, I am mindful that the proposed enforcement strategy will involve some additional compliance costs. Accordingly, the Government will ensure full consultation on the proposals for enhanced compliance. We will also ensure that taxpayers, particularly business, are given adequate notice of changes and time to adjust systems to such changes.

In the Budget Papers, the Government referred to possible extensions of the domestic interest withholding tax and the prescribed payments system, measures which would have been aimed at improving compliance. If implemented, such measures would also have significantly brought forward revenue for the Government. In adopting the Commissioner's proposed strategy, the Government accepts his advice that the compliance objective can be met without resort to these two measures.

The two initiatives I am introducing today will together raise more than $4 billion over 1994-95 and 1995-96. The projected Budget deficit will be reduced as planned to between half and one per cent of GDP in 1995-96. As provided by this Bill, substantial personal income tax cuts will be implemented in two stages from July 1994.

This Government is committed to maintaining and enhancing its fundamental approaches to taxation policy. We will not increase the overall burden of tax. We will not introduce a broad-based consumption tax. We will continue to design tax policy to support saving and investment, responding as necessary to new opportunities and changing circumstances. In particular, this Government will take to a further stage our commitment to the fundamental strategy of broadening the tax base and reducing tax rates.

The tax rates set out in this Bill provide for substantial reductions in the marginal rates faced by the great majority of working men and women in Australia. The marginal tax rate of people on average earnings will fall from 38c to 30c in the dollar. I emphasise that this will be achieved without resort to any new taxes, let alone the imposition of a crushing tax on the necessities of everyday life and almost everything else consumed by Australians and their families.

—Today the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has brought down a statement on tax policy which is an attempt to deceive the Australian people about Labor's intentions to increase taxes. In the short time available to me today I propose to expose the bankruptcy of the tax policy introduced today. I will very quickly respond to the claim by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that whenever we are under a bit of pressure we have the same policy as the Government, and that this is an explanation for the fact that I have been alleging that Labor would introduce a GST after the next election. He is plain wrong to say that on that issue, on the basis of our claim, there is no difference between the parties. There is a very clear difference between the parties: we will say honestly what we are going to do and these people will lie and cheat to the next election to save their own political skins.

If people find it a bit incredible—as did one journalist interviewing me this morning—that we should allege that Labor would introduce a goods and services tax after the next election, they should not forget the Government's record. These are the people who said, `There will be no capital gains tax' and then introduced a capital gains tax. These are the people who supported and took political benefit out of advertisements in the last campaign which said that Labor would never privatise the Commonwealth Bank, and proceeded to do exactly that.

This is the Prime Minister who said, `There will be no recession', when he and his senior economic Ministers knew that their policies would in fact see Australia fall into a recession. These are the people who in the last Budget only a month ago came into this Parliament after having concocted a story about taxes and said, `There might be some more taxes but then again there might not be. It won't be for many years that we will be able to tell you whether there will be or there won't be'.

A month later, simply because we have been hounding the Government, it has finally come up with part of its story as its blocker to the claim that this measure popped out this morning as a new additional tax. There is one last very clear reason why one would be mad to believe the Prime Minister today, who says that he is not going to introduce a GST. That is simply this: in 1985 he was in favour of it and, if he had the opportunity, he would so introduce it.

I am sorry the Government will not give us more time to debate this issue, this most incredible statement brought down today by the Treasurer. On the question of the black economy we have an incredible turnaround, with Labor now claiming that we can spend $114m in the Taxation Office over three years and suddenly, hey-presto, abracadabra, $1,700m will come into the Federal Treasury, into revenue, as a result. What is even more extraordinary is that since Fightback came down Government members themselves have been saying that one cannot quantify the level of the black economy and therefore one cannot put a revenue estimate on it.
They have been in the Parliament day after day with a Treasury minute which confirms exactly that point. This minute, dated 16 December, which was part of the Government's attack on Fightback, said:
Any attempt to quantify the size of the black economy is subject to significant uncertainty and it is not possible to produce a reliable revenue estimate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty obvious what has happened: Laura Tingle wrote her article; it hit the front page of the Australian yesterday morning; the Government had a sort of crisis strategy meeting in the Prime Minister's office; and he said, `What we have to do is run a line'—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't draft legislation in 12 hours.

—That interjection reveals that on Budget night when the Budget came down he was not ready to go. Here we have a massive turnaround: a figure which is in no way substantiated, which the Government got out of the Taxation Office only yesterday, and the Taxation Office minute which itself is contradictory. I would like an explanation from the Treasurer as to how it is that in one paragraph Mr Boucher, the Commissioner of Taxation, is saying:

PARA.TAB: Earlier this year, when addressing the question of a domestic withholding tax on interest I made the general point that it is a tenet of income tax administration that the most efficient and effective mains of gathering tax is to have it deducted at source.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, how is it that Mr Boucher said that? What was in fact being advised to the Government earlier this year? After all these denials that it was looking at it, can the Government firstly give us an explanation as to what its intentions have been, particularly in light of the fact that we do not accept its `ironclad' guarantee that there will not be any extension later on? Secondly, how does one reconcile that statement with Mr Boucher going on to say virtually the opposite, which is, `I do not recommend such a change to the tax system'?

PARA.TAB: The second point worth making is that not only do we now have this fictional figure that the Government has just plucked out of the air after months of saying that it is not possible to do so, but we also have a massive compliance cost being imposed on small business and individuals. The Government is talking about huge dollars. The hypocrisy of this is just staggering.

The Government has been attacking us for abolishing seven taxes and introducing one new tax, but here it is about to employ an army of tax inspectors to get stuck into the small business community with the compliance measures, thereby justifying its claim. A lot of questions remain unanswered, but the most important question is the one that the Treasurer dodged in Question Time, `How can you possibly justify a major reform of the tax system and provide for 47 per cent of all Australian taxpayers no income tax relief whatsoever? How can you have the gall to stand here and claim compassion for lower income Australians when in fact you totally reject them?'. The Government put them into the recession. They are those most vulnerable to the recession that the Government caused; they are those most likely to be working part time because they have lost their full time job.

Here we have a tax policy which completely abandons those people who in the past the Government has always claimed to be its own and for whom it has claimed a particular interest. This is a fraud, a denial of its own claims—the claims of a traditional Labor Party. The Government has turned its back on those lower income Australians most disadvantaged by its recession. This matter ought to be debated. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

—I am delighted to second this motion and to support the suspension of Standing Orders so that the House can have the opportunity to debate at some length the fundamentals of this issue. Really, this issue is about three things: it is about politics, politics, and politics. It is not about any substance; it is not about policy making; it is not about the future direction of the management of this country; it is not about getting Australia out of its difficulties. It is about politics, politics, politics—nothing else and nothing less.

PARA.TAB: On Tuesday morning people clambered out of their beds and read the Australian newspaper. They saw on the front page an article by Laura Tingle. There, exposed for all to see, was the politics of the tax games that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have been up to—the Prime Minister with his poisoned pen rewriting the Budget for political purposes, designed to deceive the Australian public between now and the next election. There was a 36-hour panic in the Australian Taxation Office, in the Treasurer's office and the Prime Minister's office to cobble together a few proposals and a few claims that somehow a new tax initiative would be produced to try to plug an enormous hole in the Government's budgetary projections, an enormous hole brought about by an earlier political decision—again not a decision based on an analysis of what should be done to help the country, but a decision designed solely to respond to the Fightback program, and nothing else. It still leaves a hole, according to the Government's own figures—and we can believe them if we want—of about $4 1/2 billion in 1995-96 in the Budget deficit or, if we take it on a cumulative basis over five years, the Government is left with something like a $50 billion hole in its cumulative deficit up until 1996.

The Government is really playing games to try to deceive the Australian people to help it get through an election—an election it cannot win and will not win. This kind of fraudulent political behaviour will never deceive people in Australia; they will never fall for this kind of cheap politics, this sleight of hand, this repetition of 10 years of deceit, when the elections are upon us. That is all it is about. A fringe benefits tax extension is to raise another $1.7 billion.

But the Government has been arguing in this place since the launch of Fightback that there was no such thing as a black economy in Australia. Treasurer after Treasurer—there have been a fair few of them since the launch of Fightback—have stood at the despatch box and said, `We have fixed the black economy. That is all fixed. We had all these tax measures in years gone by, but they are fixed; don't worry; it is not there any more'.

That was one of the rationales that used to be used by the present Prime Minister for abandoning the GST proposal that in his heart he so warmly favours and in practice, if he were unlikely enough to win the election, he would obviously go ahead and introduce. The fraudulence of it, as the Prime Minister would say, is so blatantly exposed. The Government does not believe there is a black economy but it is going to raise $1.7 billion from something that it does not even believe exists. Nobody, I am afraid, is going to vote for that.

It is a totally fraudulent game of politics that they play the whole time. They never do anything serious for the country. They never consider the country. —This is not a broadcast day so the folk in the gallery here are the only witnesses to what is a genuine parliamentary tantrum. What we see here from members of the Opposition is a genuine parliamentary tantrum. As Alfred Deakin once described Billy Hughes, they have been dragged kicking and screaming from the tart shop, because they see whisked away from underneath them what they believed would be a capacity on their part to demonise, to lie, to deceive, about the potentiality of the propositions put by the Government in the Budget to raise some extra taxes. In their view, that was partial evidence for them to be able to argue in public that this Government would be as stupid as they would be in seeking to impose upon the ordinary people of this country the most heinous massive tax burden coming out of a goods and services tax.

PARA.TAB: The tip-off in the speeches made by the Opposition spokesmen in this debate was not all that they had to say about whether or not they had answers on the propositions contained in the Bills that have been introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). They fall back to an argument about something back in 1985. Since then there have been a couple of elections, about eight or nine Budgets and no appearance or a whiff of a goods and services tax. But they say, `Well, back in 1985 the Government said something favourable about it when it lost hope that it would be able to get back to repair the base of the taxation system through fringe benefits tax and through the introduction of means testing in the welfare area and it thought that it might be able to make up that hole with a goods and services tax'.

Well, I am afraid that that will not wash. Eight Budgets and two elections since that point in time are not enough evidence; nor was what those opposite thought they had before enough evidence. But, like any drowning people, they will cling on to whatever lifebelt floats past. Well, one of the lifebelts has just floated past forever as far as they are concerned, and they are left more and more exposed with the propositions that they have put forward on the goods and services tax.

I will nail one other little lie which is peddled around this place by Opposition members from time to time when they put forward the point of view that the Government acts in a manner that deceives the electorate. I will go to the capital gains tax, because I think it is terribly important. I will talk about one or two other secret taxes on the part of the Opposition. It is true that in the 1983 election campaign Mr Hawke went to the public and said, `We will not introduce a capital gains tax'. Then in 1984 there was another election. In the course of that election campaign, Mr Hawke was asked the specific question, `Will you introduce a capital gains tax?', and he said, `I will give you no undertaking on that in this election; I will give you none. We are going to have a tax summit. We are going to consider the introduction of a range of measures, and among them will be a capital gains tax'. This is the myth that the Liberal Party has lived with ever since, and is yet another piece of nonsense that Opposition members want to run around with and say, `Please believe that the Government is going to introduce a goods and services tax'.

Opposition members forget the little inconvenience of the initial election in 1983 and the subsequent introduction of a capital gains tax. Mr Hawke made it absolutely clear to the Australian electorate in 1984 that he would indeed contemplate a capital gains tax and took whatever political damage there was to take on that issue when it was subsequently demonised by members of the Opposition. They have taken a long time to come around to the view that people who get their earnings in capitalist gains, as opposed to simply getting their earnings through being PAYE taxpayers, ought to be equally treated. It has been a very long time before they have been able to get round to accepting that. They have been cheerful enough about demonising us in the electorate on capital gains tax in that intervening period. But there ain't no evidence in that example either!

Those opposite are desperate to try to prove that, somehow or other, the Government is going to introduce a goods and services tax so that the horror of finally having to go to the Australian electorate to explain to the small businessmen in this community the massive impact that compliance with a goods and services tax will impose on them is obviated. Then they must explain to the poor people and to middle income people in this community the massive impact that a 15 per cent tax will have on all their necessities of life and on their capacity to survive.

They also have to go to that electorate and explain one or two other little secret taxes of their own that they will have to think about. I will name two. One of them is road user charges. Opposition members tumbled horribly on that, and they are twisting slowly on that spit. Quite rightly, the National Farmers Federation has said to them, `As much as we like a goods and services tax, if we have to cop something on that to fill a $4 billion gap, then we are well and truly dead. Therefore, we want to get a few assurances on that', and assurances they cannot get because there are $4 billion worth of assurances that cannot be given.

The second secret tax that Opposition members will not discuss, but which must be dealt with by this Parliament, by the general public and by the media in political debate, is the payroll tax substitute. They have failed to explain how they will take this tax off the States and compensate them. Will they give the money back on the basis of what they collect now, so that they reward the profligate, or will they give the money back so that those who charge huge payroll taxes get rewarded for it? Is that the basis on which it will be distributed back to them? If it is not given back to them on the basis of the profligate, how much will they cut off those States which are regarded as profligate, and what effect will that have on that service? What will they do with the States when they inform them that they are to remove 30 per cent of the States' tax base and tie it to the Commonwealth?

I will tell honourable members what they will do with the States, because they have already said that they would do this in a most unguarded moment. They would give them a guaranteed proportion of income tax or a guaranteed proportion of the goods and services tax which they can subsequently choose to manipulate up or down as they see fit. That is another massive secret tax that is waiting out there in the public domain to come back and whack the Opposition over the back of the head by the time the next election comes round.

Honourable members can bet their bottom dollar that the States will not allow them to remove unfettered 30 per cent of their tax raising powers and the flexibility they have to manipulate that up or down according to their States' economic needs without giving them a similar capacity to determine particular levels of income tax at any time. That is the second secret tax those opposite will have to explain. They will have to explain their road user secret tax and their payroll substitute secret income or additional GST tax.

Above all, when it all boils down, when we look at the impact of all these propositions from the other side on the ordinary people of this country, it makes laughable the crocodile tears they allegedly cry on behalf of those people in regard to any propositions the Government is putting forward. In the final analysis, whatever difficulty 15 per cent causes small business, it is nothing compared with what it will cause the ordinary people in this country as they are economically destroyed by a piece of pure political lunacy—imposing a 15 per cent consumption tax on an economy in recovery, imposing a tax that increases the inflation rate and imposing a tax that will create industrial trouble. That is why this ridiculous motion ought not to be carried. (Time expired)

For Australia and Australian wheat growers, that immediately meant that the price of wheat would drop. The simple fact of that announcement meant that the wheat market weakened immediately. It also meant that the market share for Australia's wheat internationally was being further and further restricted because the United States had indicated the tonnages available to Australian wheat exports for the future—or those tonnages available without competition with the United States and its subsidised exports. It means that, from a country that was producing 15 million tonnes of wheat for export, Australia is being forced back to producing only 10 million tonnes of wheat for export, with all that that means for wheat growers' incomes and Australia's balance of payments.

It revealed what a useless arrangement this Government has in place with the United States and President Bush, and what terrible political and market intelligence we have in Washington. Instead of the first information about this announcement coming through to Australia and the Australian Government from the White House to our embassy in Washington, as it should have done, or from the US embassy here to this Government, it came from a private tip-off.

The announcement indicated that the US considered that it was under no pressure whatsoever from this Australian Government. It highlighted the complete failure of this Government and its wheat policy. It also highlighted the correctness of the coalition Opposition to be stronger in relation to the need to maintain pressure on the United States, to seek access for Australian products to the United States and other restricted markets, and to have a stronger bilateral presence in seeking alternative markets.

The announcement also revealed the extent of the US trade war against Australia. What was the response of the Government to President Bush's announcement? It basically bought the United States line: `Don't react. Nothing may happen. No need to worry immediately. What we need is quiet diplomacy—softly, softly. Don't upset anybody'. The best—or worst—example of that softly, softly approach was the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in Washington two months before. On the advice given to me, he went so softly, softly that the matter was not even raised in the United States. Certainly in the areas of fruit and dairy products, there was no representation at all.

What about the reaction of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? It took him six days after the first announcement of President Bush's new policy initiative with EEP to formally reply. Compare that to the response of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who immediately wrote a letter to the President. The charge d'affaires was not called in while the US Ambassador was absent. There is no evidence that the US Ambassador has been called in here. There is no evidence of any official protest in the United States. All this Government did was bring on a matter of public importance debate in this House about a week ago, still trying to justify its failed softly, softly approach. For a day or two it even conned some of the media and a few people in the industry.

What has happened? The Pakistan wheat sale. No-one should be surprised that that sale has occurred, because the new system that has been put in place for EEP is the opposite of the line that this Government has been pushing. It has opened up the whole EEP market, the whole export tonnage of the United States, to grain traders from day one. Those grain traders have not been slow to get into action.

There still has been no significant response from the Australian Government. There was no decent intelligence that told the Australian Government that this Pakistan sale was about to occur. If anybody wants any confirmation of the feelings the United States has about this Government and its lack of reaction, it is that at the very time that that announcement of the wheat sale to Pakistan is made, and also of the second and third sales of canned fruit to Japan under the same program, the chief EEP operator for the United States is in this country and will be in this Parliament House in about an hour's time. So much for the sensitivity of the United States to what has to be done with regard to this Government on this issue.

The next thing, and I think the most significant thing, is that the Pakistan sale delivers all the worst signals possible for the Australian wheat industry. Firstly, it is a new market that has not been in EEP before. It is a traditional commercial market for Australia; it has always been a commercial market in the past. There is no European Community wheat of that type going to Pakistan. It is a white wheat market. The US claims that it has heard some rumours that something may be happening, but it is well known that the EC does not have that type of wheat. It is an unnecessarily large subsidy. That subsidy has effectively reduced the world price for wheat by 20 to 25 per cent, with all the implications that means for our wheat growers. Remember, at this stage the United States has its lowest wheat stocks on record and does not have an over-large harvest.

That is not the end. Next week there is a tender to be determined from Pakistan for twice the tonnage—over 400,000 tonnes. The United States is the only one that can respond to that tender. What action has this Government taken with the United States to get some sense back into the market to create a more commercial price? What about Egypt, also out there bidding at present, which is one of our markets too? Let us see what the Government is doing. In this morning's Australian our Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: `It's our view that this matter needs to be taken further—needs to be taken to a political level where the assurances were given.'

PARA.TAB: He said the Government would be seeking to make sure Mr Bush honoured his recent commitment to Australia that it would not be directly targeted.

SPEECH.PARA: Everything is in future tense. The Government has not taken one positive, purposeful, high level protest or action in relation to what has taken place and what is happening now.

PARA.TAB: It has also exposed the wider implications of the US trade relationship with Australia. It highlights the sense and purpose of and necessity for the statements being made by the coalition Leader, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), the shadow Minister for trade, the honourable

SPEECH.PARA: member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), me and others on the problems of restricted access to the United States and to other markets. They restrict us and then go out with their subsidies and knock us out of other markets. There is no point the Prime Minister saying in relation to the US, as he said in the debate on access to Japan, `After all, we have a trade surplus with that country'. We do not have a trade surplus with the United States; it has a very good trade surplus with us.

PARA.TAB: Along with the European Community, the United States is the main sinner with regard to domestic production subsidies for a whole range of agricultural products and export subsidies that are necessary to flog the stuff overseas. The third point concerns restrictions to access for our products—those same products—to its market. Japan has as many or more domestic production subsidies and restrictions to access for our agricultural products.

The United States actually has a whole range of domestic agricultural policies which are similar to those of the European Community. In recent months our farmers and exporters have seen the fury of US export subsidies, with canned fruit being included in that export program for the first time. Now the third sale has taken place to Japan at a time when the United States is already increasing its market share in that market, a market in which canned fruit and a range of horticultural products attract not only EEP assistance but also another subsidy program called the MPP.

The US also has a dairy export program. So far this calendar year it has built that up to $70m. It has taken market away from us in Saudi Arabia, while at the same time Australia is virtually denied access to the United States market for our dairy products. We have a small quota on cheese, and every other product is basically excluded. It even had a dumping measure against canned pears brought in in 1972, and it has never been removed because there is no opportunity under its laws for industry to have it removed and because of lack of pressure from this Government to do anything about it.

Let us look at the restrictions the US placed on Australia's access to the beef and meat market half way through this year and the havoc that has created in our industry. Perhaps the worst example of the lot is sugar. The US is gradually restricting access year by year, down from 800,000 tonnes to 96,000 tonnes. The Government took it to the GATT a couple of years ago and won the case. Nothing has happened in the United States since then, and this Government has not maintained pressure on it to do anything. That says a lot for how sensible and useful taking the wheat problem to the GATT will be. Only three weeks ago the US further restricted our sugar access. All the Government could do was bring in the Mexican furphy on sugar, put up by its own front organisation, the Evatt Foundation. Even the Minister, when he found out the facts, had to admit that Mexico is an importer of sugar.

What about the Prime Minister's reaction to no restrictions on access to Japan? I have a document which has three pages of restrictions by Japan on agricultural products alone from Australia—over 50 different situations in which it either has an embargo, such as on rice, or a virtual embargo, such as on fresh milk or UHT milk, right through to quotas and quarantine restrictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And tariffs.

—Including tariff quotas. One can go on and on about the Japanese restrictions. Here is a beauty. It has been said that there is no barrier to fresh milk—but it cannot be accepted if it has been pasteurised or heat treated. That, effectively, rules out any fresh milk. Butter or skim milk powder can be sold in Japan only when there is a shortage and when that great organisation, the LIPC, determines at what price and under what arrangements it will come in.

PARA.TAB: We have all these problems confronting our agricultural exports, of which the worst is EEP and wheat. But all these problems go far beyond that. There is still no urgency from this Government and still no determination in its mind to do anything significant. The Prime Minister is going to Japan next week. In his discussions there, as a minimum he must raise all of those restrictions that are placed on our exports to Japan.

With regard to the United States, there is still $US500m available in the EEP kitty to be distributed. The way President Bush is going at present, it will be distributed. What pressure is this Government putting on the US Administration to stop a further widening of the EEP into more and more Australian products? What is this Government doing with regard to getting a more sensible price arrangement with the United States on that Pakistan tender for next week? This Government gives no hope to our wheat growers and to our agricultural exporters.

We, as the alternative government, do give hope with our Fightback to reduce costs; and with our greater pressure on access and alternative markets. We have a wheat policy. This Government has no policy whatsoever for this vital Australian industry. I challenge Government speakers to say what their wheat policy is and what they are going to do. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Overseas Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The last two weeks have convinced me of absolutely one thing: heaven help Australia if the Opposition were ever to get into government and put into place all the contradictory, naive, stupid things those opposite have been saying on trade and exports. Their trade policy is a combination of hiss, wind and back to traditional Country Party abuse. I suppose the poor old Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), thought he had to come in here and say these things. I thought he was quite right on the analysis of the US position when he said, `We have to do something. There is a lack of pressure and we have to take these things up'.

PARA.TAB: That is what we come up against every time we seriously debate this whole question. World trade is distorted. It was the United States that kept agriculture out of the GATT, with the GATT waiver exercised in 1954. It is Australia and the present US Administration that have forced agriculture into the GATT Round.

A lot of this started when the US packaged its EEP in one year, in an election context, rather than announcing initiative after initiative. A lot of this debate is taking place because the National Party is mightily embarrassed, with the Queensland State election coming up, about zero tariffs for sugar. The matter of public importance today reads:
The continuing failure of the Australian Government to promote and protect Australia's trade.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not say anything about wheat, although wheat is part of our trade. But all we got from the honourable member for Murray was a tirade about wheat and the United States.

PARA.TAB: We are quite happy to take on this question of Australia's trade promotion and protection. The Opposition, quite frankly, still has not been able to divine what has changed in the world; what international forces are now at work; and what the US policies and strategies have been and now are. It has not been able to work out what the EC's policies and strategies are and may be, and what the realities of the interests of trading areas are. From all of this it does not understand what Australia's interests and strategies should be at this time. There is a harking back to the past and, as I said, more of the old Country Party approach of abusing people.

Calling the United States our No. 1 trade enemy is okay for a National Party conference, but those opposite really cannot do that if the next day they say that they want to join an unspecified North American Free Trade Arrangement; the next day they admit that they do not know how they would do it; or claim that a naive letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has somehow immediately changed Republican Party trade policy, as if the Opposition can write campaign speeches. It is totally hypocritical for the Opposition to raise this matter of public importance after it has fundamentally done so much damage to our relations with our major trading partners and allies by saying, `US—No. 1 enemy', by making false claims about President Bush's reasons for action and by sending off a rude letter. If that works then those opposite should write a letter every day. Maybe they should have written another letter today. The US announced an EEP yesterday on wheat to Pakistan and there is another one today. I think those opposite ought to write a letter a day if they think that is going to work.

With respect to Japan, the matter today is really aimed at protecting the decaying National Party in Queensland. But in the process all the Opposition did was to offend our biggest trading partner with whom we have a $6 billion surplus. A $6 billion surplus does not mean that we ease up. I just spent a week in Japan, even to the extent of talking to LDP members on the island of Kyushu about rice, about coal and about our products. The pressure from Australia never stops.

It is absurd to talk about rice with Japan in a bilateral context. Only the Leader of the Opposition thinks that he can control the US congressional system, US politics and, at the same time, the Japanese political system. Even if the LDP were able to get arrangements to purchase rice bilaterally from Australia through its lower House, its upper House could not resist the temptation to block it. It is nonsense to think we can do anything about rice, in the bilateral context, with Japan. As I pointed out the other day, with a $45 billion trade deficit and with the United States providing the defence umbrella and massive leverage, the United States can do nothing bilaterally on rice. But the Leader of the Opposition, who has just discovered this issue and all the restrictions that apply from Japan, somehow thinks that, if he talks about it and makes us feel warm inside, it will solve the problem.

We also had another mission impossible suggested by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) with respect to Northwest Airlines when the capacity for retaliation by the Americans would have been enormous. Of course, the Leader of the National Party is going to cross that bridge when he comes to it. It is also absurd that the Opposition raises this issue when it has no policy in this area and when our trade performance is a success story that all Australians can share in and be proud of. My colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) will outline this success to the House when he speaks on this matter of public importance.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party spoke mainly about the United States, EEP and wheat and did not address the matter of public importance as such. Everything that the Republican Administration has said through the Reagan years and now under President Bush in principle has been about trade liberalisation. The US practice and tactics in a distorted trade world are at odds with the US Administration's stated principles. Perhaps we can understand what was in President Bush's Detroit speech if we accept that fundamental fact.

For the Opposition to talk about trade blocs, about Australia being left out if we do not join the North American Free Trade Arrangement, the EC, or the Arctic Circle trade agreement is ignorant, malicious scaremongering and nothing else. The Government's position on the recent EEP announcements is well known. I will be stressing our disagreement with the US analysis of the Pakistan market when I am there next week, especially regarding the level of subsidy. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and I talked with the US Ambassador last night, we were briefed by Stephen Censky, and there is simply no way that we did not hammer those points forward. I will be hammering those points forward with Secretary of Agriculture Madigan and trade representative Carla Hills in Washington next Monday.

As long as we are in a power based system and do not have a rules based system for world trade we will suffer at the sidelines of the trade war between the two huge subsidisers of agricultural production in the world today: the United States and the EC. The Opposition has no answers; it is just bluster aimed at Queensland voters in the State election this weekend. If those opposite were allowed to act as a government the way they act as an Opposition, the Americans would not be coming here for talks on trade the way they are; they would be hurting our farmers and our steel makers even more. The US interests do not hesitate to act out their interests; nor does Australia hesitate to act out our interests.

On all this the Opposition is a joke. It is 100 per cent humbug and it is 100 per cent sham. More importantly, the Opposition is dangerous to our trade and economic interests. The Leader of the Opposition attacked Japan in response to US action and that is what was nonsensical about it. It was unprecedented for the US and the Japanese embassies to come out and say, `The Leader of the Opposition is plain wrong'.

Further, for the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) to claim that the speech of President Bush in Detroit last week was as a result of the Leader of the Opposition's letter was also shown to be plainly wrong. There is not a sensible, informed commentator in this country who has agreed with a word of what the Opposition has been saying on trade policy over the last two weeks. Today, in a question at Question Time, I picked up the point again in Fightback that the Opposition is going to slash Austrade; it is going to slash aid—and aid is commercially directed in part these days, and that is very important; and it is going to go for zero tariffs and wreck the car industry.

I think this is also unprecedented: there is an article in the Bulletin today headed `How the Liberals would kill our billion dollar car industry'. That industry is now worth $1.2 billion a year in exports, so where is the Opposition's trade and export strategy? It is going to kill it. It is an industry worth $8 billion all up. We do not know how much is going to be left, but there will be a big import bill as well. Is the Opposition going to import cars all second-hand from Japan? Luxury cars will get a bit of relief from the GST. I suppose that is a good thing for Liberal voters.

It is absolute nonsense to talk of all these things on trade when the Opposition has policies which will wreck our bilateral trade instrument, Austrade, which will persecute Australian exporters, and which will really wreck one of our major manufacturing industries. Today the Leader of the Opposition said that he might put more resources into trade. The National Party does not know what to say, whether Austrade should be wiped out or not.

One big point is always missed in this debate: governments can only facilitate trade. It is not just simply having a trade policy that facilitates trade and exports. Economic policy, industry policy, and industrial relations policy are all just as important. Governments export very little. But trade can be facilitated, and simply thinking that trade approach is based on only one area of government policy is a complete nonsense.

The Opposition then said that we should join the North American Free Trade Agreement. Again, not one responsible trade commentator anywhere has supported the Opposition in this. NAFTA, from what we do know about it, is about concessions. It is not really a free trade zone like the EC, but a series of separate bilateral relationships between each of the three, especially with respect to agriculture. So what have we got to offer? The US has access to our markets now. How can the Opposition negotiate and how can it bargain if it has got a policy of zero tariffs? It has nothing to bargain with unless agriculture is in it. The way the Opposition is carrying on is simply nonsensical.

NAFTA looks more and more as if the United States is going to act as a hub and take countries one at a time. Why do honourable members think that in his speech in Detroit President Bush is saying that he wants to get central Europe into some free trade arrangement—the same countries that applied to join the EC? What is he saying about the Pacific? That is directed towards Japan, just as talking about central Europe is directed towards Europe; it is putting pressure on in the multilateral context. There are all kinds of strategies and tactics implicit in those statements of President Bush's vision for his next term if he is elected. NAFTA has nothing for Australia compared with the Asia-Pacific trading area; it has nothing for us compared with regional trade liberalisation, bilateral trade liberalisation, all hopefully under the umbrella of multilateral trade liberalisation.

Why multilateral? The real world of trade today is non-tariff barriers; it is some of the barriers that the honourable member for Murray pointed to in Japan. If one gets those, in the terms of the jargon, `comprehensively tariffed'—all measures of protection and restriction expressed as a tariff—and one gets a multilateral solution, then in one fell swoop one will wipe out all those thousands of non-tariff barriers. If one gets a multilateral solution in the Uruguay Round, and if one looks at the Dunkel text and takes into account the access arrangements, Australia gets access to markets of all the GATT contracting parties—some 103 to 108 countries—and again we can prosecute bilateral trade far more easily.

Let us look at the history. Quite apart from the fact that agriculture has never been in multilateral trade negotiations before, at other times we always found we had very little to offer, and we had nothing to buy any concessions with. When Doug Anthony went to the last round of trade negotiations he came back saying that he did not have to cut a single tariff in Australia. That is because of the situation where we had the strong orientation of all our exports to agriculture and natural resource based products, world markets where commodity prices fluctuate, and we really had nothing to bargain with unless agriculture was in the round. So that is why this Government formed the Cairns Group; that is why this Government formed APEC. The idea behind APEC was to get regional trade liberalisation, and to have a forum where economic and trade matters could be discussed.

There is no lack of pressure on any front with respect to our trade approach. Now there is the invitation for the Prime Minister to raise these matters in Japan. Of course he will; he always does. The honourable member for Kooyong says that we have only got a single pronged trade strategy—some would say that the honourable member for Kooyong has a single pronged approach to many things in politics—but I do not share those views. Let me quickly identify the prongs—if that is the word—of our trade policy. Multilaterally it is via the Cairns Group; regionally, it is APEC, and there are sub-regional approaches; bilaterally it is country to country—whether it is Vietnam, Japan, Korea, Kuwait or New Zealand. Of course there are sectoral trade policies, and we are prosecuting these multifaceted approaches in all of those areas.

Let us look at Austrade, the main facilitating body with respect to bilateral trade. This is the organisation that members of the Opposition are virtually going to wipe out, although I understand that now their Leader is having second thoughts about that. We have the national trade strategy between the Australian Government and the State and Territory governments, and the results are there, as my colleague will explain. I thank members of the Opposition for this matter of public importance. I thank them for the whole debacle they have brought upon themselves by raising the issue of trade policy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this matter of public importance raised by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd), namely:

PARA.TAB: The continuing failure of the Australian Government to promote and to protect Australia's trade.

SPEECH.PARA: It is one of the ironies that, in this chamber in Question Time, the premium debating chamber in the land, when there is no debate we are swamped by public support from the public galleries. Frankly, when there is no debate in this chamber, and there is nothing but theatre, we see the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at his best.

PARA.TAB: Day in and day out he comes and delivers a tirade of abuse at the Opposition. It is as if the thespian in him comes to life: lights, cameras, sound, action! The Prime Minister, be-suited, fits the role he has been set to play. But take him out of here, to the point at which the real decisions have to be made and the real negotiations have to take place—take him, for example, to the National Press Club—and Australia has to face the reality that the man who leads the Government is nothing more than an actor. The reality is that, in terms of the words penned by Shakespeare in Macbeth, he is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a poor player,
That struts and frets his hour upon the stage,
And then is heard no more it is a tale
Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,
Signifying nothing.

We have become accustomed to the sound and the fury. We have become accustomed to a Prime Minister who comes in here and struts this stage and frets his hour, but whose sound and fury signify nothing.

PARA.TAB: In this debate on Australia's trade performance, the Opposition wants to focus on how little has been achieved by the Government in trade and on how much, as a result of the sound and fury and emptiness of the Prime Minister and his Government, we now have a burden being carried by every Australian exporter and, particularly, by Australia's wheat growers.

As a South Australian, I have to tell honourable members that the Prime Minister reminds me of a formula one car revving up in the pits, making all the noises but never getting over the finishing line. On the world stage in trade terms he is seen as nothing more than an empty vessel. What did the Prime Minister say to Laurie Oakes in an interview conducted in October 1991 when he was a pretender to the role of Prime Minister? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: But I'm not going to be in a position—
this is the Prime Minister speaking, if you please—

and wouldn't be, where I spring to attention the moment an American President picks up the phone. I think Australia's got the right to the dignity of an independent view and I've taken a glove to the Americans when it suited me.

Well, Mr Prime Minister, this MPI is all about asking the question: why does it not suit you now? Let us see the Government perform on the issue of tariff barriers, non-tariff barriers and world trade. Australian farmers are being adversely affected by the inaction of the Australian Labor Party, the inaction of the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) and the velvet glove of the present Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: What have we seen? We have seen the American President, Mr Bush, in an action of blatant political pragmatism, promise to his farmers at a meeting in South Dakota, simply to buy their votes, that he would offer them the support they needed—and the Prime Minister snapped to attention in his thespian role.

What the Australian farmers seek from the Government are not the sorts of excuses that we have had delivered from the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development in the 10-minute tirade that he delivered in the Parliament, but instead some indication that outside of the theatre of this place they can depend on the Prime Minister, the Minister and the Government to recognise the real demands that farmers have and to recognise that the play is over.

A classic case of the inactivity of the Government particularly, and of the Minister, was the inaction that followed the announcement yesterday morning of the decision of the Americans effectively to send 220,000 tonnes of subsidised grain into a characteristically Australian market, the Pakistan market. There is no way that this action can take place without effectively paralysing Australia's wheat farmers. As the Deputy Leader of the National Party has said, as if that were not enough, as I have discovered in my conversations with Australian Wheat Board personnel, there is another proposal. That proposal is next week to provide the opportunity for a further 420,000 tonnes of American subsidised grain to be dropped into what is a characteristically Australian market, Pakistan.
What else have we had? We have had no response from the Minister—nothing more than empty rhetoric. Most of his speech was spent being critical of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not in government.

—We are not the government, as the honourable member for Curtin so appropriately interjects. It is time the Minister recognised that he has ministerial responsibilities. If the Government had any sense of urgency, which it ought to have in the face of this blatant action of the Americans in pragmatic pre-election vote buying, the Minister would not even be here; he would have already flown to the USA in order to make the point effectively that we, the Opposition, are making in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Why is this sort of response not coming from the Government? It is its responsibility. If it were any group but the Australian farmers—anyone but those who are characteristically represented on this side of the House—being so adversely affected, we would have had all sorts of feigned indignation emerging from the Party opposite.

But what did the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development come in here and say? Far from offering us any solution, he chose to be critical of what the Opposition has done and to suggest that the Government's trade performance has been up to speed. Do I have to read again the words—irrefutable—of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), delivered earlier this week, about the Government's real trade performance?

What do we discover if we look at the document Asia-Pacific Profiles? We discover that in the Hong Kong market China has gone from 20 per cent to 36 per cent but Australia has gone from 2 per cent to one per cent. `What sort of trade performance is that', I ask the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin). In the Japanese market, the United States has gone from 17 per cent to 23 per cent; the European Community from 6 to 16 per cent—and Australia has stayed at 5 per cent. What sort of trade performance is that?

We are not here inventing easy solutions. There is reel after reel of illustrations of how we as a nation have marked time in trade performance. We are not here in opposition suggesting that there is a simple way round. But we are saying that in the light of what has happened, particularly in the last two weeks: why are we not protesting loudly to the Americans and demanding some sort of bilateral trade negotiations so that we can get additional access to the American market to compensate us for what the Americans are doing to us in what have been our traditional markets, contrary to the pledge given by their President in this chamber on 2 January of this year?

Where did we go in this debate? We finished up with the Minister not dealing specifically with the agricultural trade question but instead dragging in the red herring of tariffs and suggesting that all that motivated us was the Queensland election. I have never heard such a blatantly two-faced approach from the Minister. If we wanted to be pragmatists, would we be backing the Government on its tariff line with sugar in Queensland right now? Of course we would not. Far from taking a cheap shot to win the Queensland election, we have taken the responsible view that effectively we have to maintain our present tariff regime.

But we challenge the Government and say to it, `What are you doing for Australian wheat growers?'. The answer, sadly, is nothing. The obligation that the Minister has, representing Australian wheat growers, is to be in America now negotiating a new bilateral deal on behalf of not only wheat growers but also beef growers, horticultural producers and sugar growers in order to get some compensation for Australia's primary producers. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for the contributions that they have made this afternoon because, if nothing else, what they did was to highlight, as the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) rightly pointed out, just the harking back to the future sort of approach to trade policy that those on the other side have.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry to break it to both gentlemen, and particularly to those in the National Party of Australia, but the fact is that Australia's trade has now moved on from simply primary products to other areas. Primary products are important; there is no question about that. They are a vital part of Australia's trade performance and, as the Minister clearly pointed out, at every opportunity this Government has been pursuing, through appropriate forums, ways in which to improve that performance.

As the Minister also demonstrated, the leading role that Australia has played in the Cairns Group—with the Uruguay Round being driven, particularly in agriculture, by Australia and the other participants of the Cairns Group—demonstrates this Government's bona fides and concern for these issues. Interestingly, if one looks at some of the statistics—the honourable member for Wakefield talked of some of those statistics supposedly put around by the shadow Minister for trade, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)—they show some very interesting real world scenarios and pictures of what is happening as far as Australia's trade is concerned.

I will deal briefly with a couple of those statistics. As far as Australia's export performance is concerned, export revenues have actually reached record levels in the life of this Government, despite depressed commodity prices and subdued world economic activity. Export volumes rose by 12 per cent in 1990-91 and by over 9 per cent in 1991-92. Our export volume growth in 1991 was the fastest in the OECD and our manufactures export growth was the fastest in the OECD in both 1990 and 1991. Finally, our export volumes grew almost three times faster than world trade in 1990 and four times faster in 1991.

How did that happen? Is it because the Government has not got a trade policy? Is it because we have turned our back on Australian producers and exporters, as was claimed by those on the other side in this debate? That is absolute rubbish. If one looks at where that performance has come from, the direction of our exports, our trade surplus and so on, one can see clearly that there has been a change in emphasis. The story is exciting.

Rather than sitting back and knocking all the time, as those opposite would do, they should be out there talking up Australia's trade performance. They should be talking about AOTC and what it is doing in Cambodia. They should be talking about AWA and what it has done in getting $20m worth of navigation deals in China. They should be out there talking about Ford Australia securing its first export program for Japan with a $30m contract to supply Mazda with 280,000 cylinder blocks as part of a wider program of parts replacement. They should be out there talking about the fact that our growth in exports of elaborately transformed manufactures almost doubled between 1986-87 and 1991-92 from something like $4.97 billion to $9.66 billion. Are those the sorts of figures of a government, a manufacturing sector and an export oriented economy—which Australia is—that demonstrate that there is no policy and that we are going backwards? I hardly think so.

Of course, when we look at those aspects of our improved trade performance, we also have to give consideration to, quite simply, where some additional growth will come. That, of course, is in the services sector. Two weeks ago I, along with the Minister, was in Japan promoting Australia's trade—I in services and he particularly in agriculture and other matters. The interesting thing was that we were there also to open up the latest in one of Austrade's new offices in Japan to promote Australian trade. We went to another city called Sendai, where we will establish yet another Austrade office. We were talking to Japanese people about buying more Australian products.

A matter of a week later, we had an unmitigated and unbelievable attack on Japan, our major trading partner, from the Opposition. Quite frankly, it is probably just as well that both the Minister and I had left Japan by then, because it would have been rather embarrassing to have to explain to people why we were establishing trade offices in their country, why we were there talking about how we were going to continue, particularly in the area of services, to promote trade from Australia, when at the same time they would be asking, `Why it is that there are people in your country, and a party that wants to be in government, that are attacking your main customer?'. As I said, fortunately we had left and we did not have to face those sorts of questions.

Let me quickly deal with a couple of issues in the area of services. Education services from Australia are now worth $1 billion a year—that is, university, high school and a rapidly expanding market in vocational training. We talked to people in Japan about that. They said to us quite clearly, `Your education standards are superb. We would like to see more of our people go to Australia and train, particularly in postgraduate degrees, but importantly in English language training combined with secretarial skills'. I have taken that on board, and I will be talking to people in the TAFE systems at the State level and to people in DEET and other agencies in Australia to try to promote that in Japan.

I followed that visit with one to Thailand. Exactly the same sorts of issues were raised with me. In fact, four of the outgoing Cabinet Ministers in Thailand were educated in Australia. They are out there working and promoting Australia for its educational opportunities—contributing to the $1 billion-plus per annum that Australia earns from education. Yet we have been told by the Opposition that all we should be concerned about is some statement that President Bush made on the stump in an election campaign about wheat. It smacks like the old days when the National Party was in government and it made announcements on the run in an election campaign. As far as this Government is concerned, we have diversified. We are internationalising our economy and our ability to trade.

The other area where there are some benefits that can flow to Australia in our trade performance—away from the ETMs that I have mentioned, away from education and away from agriculture—is that of services such as financial services, insurance and health care. The interesting thing is that the statistics indicate that a Japanese, for example, could come to Australia, pay for an operation in this country and therefore contribute considerable sums of money to this area, holiday in this country to recuperate and again put money in almost as a tourist, and it would be cheaper than going to the United States. That is a market that again we can tap into, and something that we should be promoting. It is an untapped resource that at the moment is only on the periphery of our interests.

In insurance, for example, the market potential in Thailand, Japan and other parts of Asia is unlimited. We are starting to see the companies that are presently there going more to Western style economies with home ownership and so on. The opportunities for Australian insurance companies to go there and work, perhaps in joint ventures, to promote opportunities in exporting of services are absolutely enormous.

This is part of this Government's trade strategy. We have an East Asia Analytical Unit as part of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It has brought down two reports so far—one by Ross Garnaut and one by Geoff Raby—which have looked at the opportunities in that part of the world. At the moment we are doing a study on South East Asia whereby we will actually have something of an outline, a road map, if you like, on strategies and how to get into those markets. We have talked about training opportunities, the need to get fluent in foreign languages, particularly in those areas to which we want to go, the importance of establishing an office in those locations to promote Australian trade, and the need to get into joint venture operations as well. All of this is part of the Government's trade strategy, because times have moved on. We have moved on from one-off deals. We have negotiated bilateral and multilateral trade deals. Again referring to some of the statistics on this, from the information that has been given to me, bilateral trade economic agreements have been negotiated with 32 countries in recent years by this Government.

We are not sitting on our hands. This MPI today was supposedly about the failure of this Government to do anything about promoting Australia's trade policy. It is not simply about wheat and what was happening in those particular two deals because of an American election campaign; it is wider than that.

It is time that the coalition woke up to itself and, in embracing a trade strategy and a trade policy, clearly looked at all issues associated with this. Those opposite should be joining with the Government and singing the praises of major companies who are prepared to get out there and negotiate. They should be singing the praises of Austrade, which is moving 70 per cent of its resources offshore to promote Australian trade, instead of carping in the way they are. (Time expired)
