SPEECH.PARA: This Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements between Australia and Indonesia, Australia and Vietnam and Australia and Spain. The Bill will insert the texts of the agreements into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as schedules to that Act.

PARA.TAB: The agreement with Indonesia was signed on 22 April 1992; the agreement with Vietnam was signed on 13 April 1992; and that with Spain was signed on 24 March 1992. The agreements allocate taxing rights over all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and those countries. Details of each agreement were announced and copies made publicly available at the time of signature. The agreements generally accord with the other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years.

A feature of the agreement with Vietnam is that it provides for `tax sparing' credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by Vietnam under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment. Where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from the development incentives to be nominated under the agreement, a tax credit will be allowed by Australia for the Vietnamese tax forgone under those incentive measures. By this means, the development incentives will retain their attractions for Australian firms and allow them to compete for business in Vietnam on favourable terms with investors from other countries.

Each of the respective agreements will enter into force when diplomatic notes are exchanged advising that the necessary constitutional processes to give the agreement the force of law in the respective countries have been completed. The enactment of this Bill will complete the processes required of Australia for those purposes.

The Government believes that the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment, and wider relationships between Australia and the treaty partner countries. I am pleased to be able to say that Australia is the first country with which Vietnam has entered into a double taxation agreement. It is not possible to accurately predict the eventual effect of the three agreements on the revenue, but it is not expected to be significant. DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Baldwin, for Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great pleasure in introducing this Bill to the House. My particular pleasure derives from the fact that this Bill provides for further measures to assist frail older people in our community, and particularly their carers. It is appropriate that this Bill should be introduced today because this week has been designated Carers Week. This is a week when we are focusing particularly on the needs of people who care for family members, friends, neighbours or other members of the community.

PARA.TAB: This Government's aged care policy pays particular attention to the needs of carers. The home and community care program lists carers as a special target group for the program. Our residential care program makes special provision for respite care to enable carers to have a break from time to time. This Budget proposes a package of assistance to carers amounting to $89m over four years.

One of these measures concerns an increase to the domiciliary nursing care benefit, DNCB. This Bill contains provisions which, if passed, will enable implementation of that Budget announcement. The domiciliary nursing care benefit provides financial assistance to carers of people over the age of 16 who have been assessed as needing a nursing home level of care. Part 5 of this Bill includes amendments to support three changes to the DNCB to take effect from 6 January 1993.

The first amendment will increase the level of the benefit by $10 to $52 per fortnight from 6 January 1993. The second amendment provides for the Minister to vary this amount from time to time. It is the Government's intention to index the benefit annually on the basis of CPI changes. The third amendment will allow carers to continue to receive the benefit during periods of respite care of up to 42 days a year.

The significant increase of the benefit by approximately 25 per cent and its subsequent indexation demonstrates the Government's commitment to the recognition of and support for carers of frail older people and people with disabilities living in the community. The continued payment of the benefit while the person being cared for is in respite care will provide much needed support for carers and allow them to have short breaks from care without loss of benefit. This provision will bring the DNCB into line with provisions applying to similar payments in the social security area. Respite care is the service most highly valued by carers. The Bill also contains amendments concerning funding for new and rebuilt nursing homes.

As a result of a decision in the 1991 Budget, the Government already provides additional recurrent funding for some nursing homes that are newly built or completely rebuilt. The aim of this initiative was to improve the quality of nursing home buildings, and hence to improve the quality of care. The nursing home industry took the view that this initiative would not efficiently meet its objective since a proprietor could apply for the additional funding only after building the new home. They said that a proprietor considering rebuilding his or her home needed an assurance of the additional funding before construction commenced; otherwise he or she would not be able to borrow the money to rebuild. The proposed amendment overcomes this problem, and introduces a system of approvals in principle.

The recent Budget provided funding for approvals in principle for 1992-93 and 1993-94. However, it is possible that many proprietors who do not intend to rebuild their home in the near future will nevertheless apply for an approval in principle just in case they change their minds or in case the State health authorities force them to rebuild. There is therefore a risk that the available approvals in principle will be wasted. To avoid this possibility this legislative amendment allows the approval in principle to be revoked if no progress is made towards the rebuilding. The approvals in principle will then be able to be reallocated.

The Bill makes provision for a change in date of effect of reviews of resident classifications. Under the current funding arrangements for nursing homes, the proprietor applies for a classification for a new resident or for a current resident whose classification is about to expire. This classification is based on the resident classification instrument, RCI, which measures a resident's need for nursing and personal care. These classifications are used to determine the amount of funding for nursing and personal care that a home receives.

In deciding whether to grant a classification, the Secretary of the Department is guided by principles formulated by the Minister, known as the nursing home classification principles. The Secretary of the Department may at any time review the classification of a resident. If, on the basis of this review, the Secretary decides that the resident has been wrongly classified, the Secretary may revoke the classification and substitute a higher or lower classification. Currently the Secretary is not required to have regard to the nursing home classification principles when reviewing a resident's classification. This is an anomaly, because the purpose of the classification principles is to ensure that all resident classifications are determined by classification principles which are universally applied, according to relative care need. Therefore, this Bill proposes to amend the Act to require the Secretary to observe the nursing home classification principles when reviewing a resident's classification.

There exists a further anomaly in regard to reviews of classifications. If the review classification is lower than the original classification, the review classification currently takes effect from the date of the review. This is despite the fact that the wrong classification has applied from the date of the original classification. This Bill proposes to amend the period of effect of a review by the Secretary so that the review classification is for the same period as the original classification.

This also means a nursing home will not have as long to wait for a further review of the classification. At present, in the case of a reduced classification, the nursing home has to wait until the review classification has been in force for 12 months. This can be up to one year after the original classification would have expired and delays the opportunity for the nursing home to seek a further classification in cases where the resident's care needs have changed.

The proposed amendment will mean that the nursing home will receive a positive or negative adjustment to future funding depending on whether the review classification is higher or lower than the original assessment by the nursing home. This will ensure an appropriate level of funding for the entire 12-month classification period. The nursing home will be able to apply for a further annual classification at the end of that time. The Bill ensures that the new arrangements applying to the period of effect of a review classification, if that review lowers a category, will apply only to classifications determined on or after the date of assent to the Bill.

The Bill also makes amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act designed to increase equity with regard to hostel subsidies by providing higher subsidies for financially disadvantaged persons, or FDPs. The amendments provide for an increase in funding for each FDP hostel resident, offset by a reduction in funding for non-FDP hostel residents who have been assessed for personal care, PC. It is intended that at all levels of care within a hostel there will be a $3.20 a day subsidy difference between FDP and non-FDP residents.

Hostels have a greater capacity to raise income from their non-FDP residents through avenues such as entry contributions and variable fees. These options are generally not available for hostels catering for FDPs. This can present problems in ensuring access for this group and viability problems for hostels catering predominantly for FDPs. Thus the amendments will benefit hostels accommodating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and other disadvantaged groups.

The recently introduced hostel personal care arrangements are based on the assessment of the relative care need of each individual, not their financial status or capacity to pay. This principle is unchanged. Those with higher care needs will continue to get higher subsidies. However, the subsidy at each level will also reflect the financial status of the resident. While some hostels will be disadvantaged in terms of subsidies available, the extent to which hostels will be affected will depend on the financial status of the residents.

As already indicated, hostels with high levels of non-FDPs have access to higher levels of resident charges. The real impact on the resident and the hostel should be minimal, as the changes, in combination with forthcoming real increases in pensioner income through pension and rental assistance increases, largely offset each other. The overall impact is that the income available to hostels from subsidies and resident payments will be better targeted to support those in need.

In addition to amendments to the aged care area the Bill makes amendments to the arrangements regarding payment of Medicare benefits in relation to R-type diagnostic imaging services. The amendment of subsection 16B(11) of the Health Insurance Act provides for the extension by two years, to 1 January 1995, of the sunset provisions. Under the current sunset provision, from 1 January 1993 Medicare benefits will no longer be payable for diagnostic imaging services rendered by medical practitioners who were exempted by the grandparent provisions in the 1991 amendments dealing with arms-length requesting of these services. An extension will allow for the continuation of the payment of Medicare benefits for R-type services in these circumstances. The amendments proposed will provide more time for the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners to develop accreditation guidelines for general practitioners who provide radiology services.

The Bill also amends the Medicare benefits referral arrangements by inserting a new section 20BA in the Health Insurance Act. The main purpose of the proposed amendment is to require that, where a practitioner refers a patient, in writing, to a consultant physician or a specialist and where the physician or specialist renders a specialist medical service to that patient, the physician or specialist must retain the referral for a period of 18 months.

The amendment also proposes that the physician or specialist be required, if requested by the Managing Director of the Health Insurance Commission, to produce to an officer of the Commission the referral or the patient's hospital records for verification of a referral. Following discussions between the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and the medical profession, agreement was reached on revised referral arrangements. This included placing onus of proof that a valid referral took place on the specialist or the consultant physician, that is, the practitioner to whom the patient was referred rather than the referring practitioner. Precedents for the proposed amendment already exist in the Health Insurance Act in respect of requests for pathology and diagnostic imaging services, including the requirement that the referral be retained for a period of 18 months.

The Bill rectifies an error in subsection 129AAA(3) of the Health Insurance Act. The amendment to the subsection omits the second occurrence of the word `pathology' before `practitioner' so that the subsection prohibits an approved pathology practitioner from providing nursing and other staff, not only at the premises of the practitioner but also at premises made available to the practitioner by a medical entrepreneur.

The Bill also reinserts subsection 79(5) in the National Health Act to allow for the cancellation of registration of organisations where the business of all health benefits funds conducted by them have been transferred, in accordance with an approval by the Minister, to funds conducted by other organisations. Subsection 79(5) of the National Health Act was inadvertently repealed by the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inadvertently repealed.

—Do not blame me. The proposed amendments of section 4 in the National Health Act in part five of this Bill relate to the payment of Medicare benefits for visits by participating optometrists to private patients in hospital and approved day hospital facilities. Currently, where a visit is made by an optometrists to such patients, the Medicare rebate is 75 per cent of the schedule fee with the health insurance funds required to cover the remaining 25 per cent for insured patients.

PARA.TAB: While the 75 per cent benefit rebate is contained in the Health Insurance Act, it is linked to the professional service rendered to patients who are receiving hospital treatment as provided for in the National Health Act. When the Health Insurance Act was amended in 1987 to reduce the Medicare benefit for professional services rendered in a hospital or approved day hospital facilities to private patients from 85 per cent (maximum $20 gap) to 75 per cent flat, its unintended application to optometrical consultations was overlooked.

Patients are not admitted to hospital for conditions requiring the services of an optometrist. An optometrist may visit a hospital as a social service to a patient who has broken his or her spectacles and requires a test for new spectacles. Such patients are most likely to be long stay, nursing home type patients. The 75 per cent flat rate benefit provides a disincentive for optometrists to bulk bill such patients—the majority of whom would be aged persons. Currently some 87 per cent of optometrical services are direct billed.

The proposal in this Bill is to amend subsection 4(1) of the National Health Act to exclude optometrical consultations from the definition of professional service for the purpose of that section and as a consequence from the application of the 75 per cent Medicare benefit level provided for in section 10 of the Health Insurance Act. The Bill also closes a loophole which would enable a child, in respect of whom family allowance is not being paid because of the income or assets test, to be declared a disadvantaged person and thus be issued with a health care card and receive pharmaceutical benefits at the concessional rate of patient contribution.

Finally, the Bill makes a number of minor changes and corrections to the legislation governing the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that in November 1991 the parliamentary Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority tabled its evaluation of the NCA in a report entitled Who is to Guard the Guards?. The report supported the continued existence and activities of the NCA and made 11 recommendations. The Government's response to the PJC report was tabled on 1 June 1992. The National Crime Authority Bill (No.2) 1992 amends the National Crime Authority Act 1984 in the manner foreshadowed in that response.

PARA.TAB: The Bill establishes an office of Inspector-General of the NCA, endows it with appropriate functions and powers and provides a mechanism for resolving disputes between the NCA and the PJC about access to sensitive information held by the NCA. It also makes some small but important corrections to existing provisions of the NCA Act.

The most significant change to the NCA Act introduced by these amendments is the new office of Inspector-General of the NCA. Clause 10 of the Bill will insert a new part IIIA in the NCA Act to make provision for this office. The PJC report proposed that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security be given jurisdiction to investigate complaints against the NCA and its staff.

Because the role of the Inspector-General in relation to the NCA will differ in some respects from the role of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, the Bill will establish a separate office of Inspector-General of the NCA under the NCA Act. However, the Government intends that the occupant of the office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security will also be appointed as Inspector-General of the NCA and, with this in mind, the new part IIIA is based as closely as practicable on the relevant provisions of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986.

One major difference between the role of the Inspector-General in relation to the NCA and in relation to the intelligence and security agencies will be that he will not have the broad monitoring function in relation to the NCA which he has in relation to intelligence and security matters. General monitoring of the work of the NCA remains the responsibility of the Commonwealth-State Inter-governmental Committee—the IGC—and of the PJC, both of which are established under the NCA Act. A second major difference is that, in relation to the NCA, the Inspector-General will not investigate complaints which can be dealt with satisfactorily under existing complaints legislation or procedures applicable to a police force from which the subject of the complaint has been seconded to the NCA.

Under new section 55AA, the recommendation to the Governor-General that a person be appointed Inspector-General may only be made after consultation with the IGC. The person so appointed will be able to hold the office in conjunction with another, and section 55AC will preserve the judicial status of a judge appointed to the office. The terms and conditions of the Inspector-General, as set out in division six of the new part IIIA, are compatible with those of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. Under section 55AZE, where the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is also appointed Inspector-General of the NCA, staff may be appointed to assist him in both capacities.

The functions of the Inspector-General are set out in proposed new section 55AD. His principal function will be to investigate complaints about the actions of members or staff of the NCA, whether such complaints are made directly or are referred to him by a member of the IGC or by the PJC. Further, on request by the Minister, he will investigate whether NCA information to which access is sought by the PJC on the NCA is `sensitive information' as defined in the Bill, and will advise the Minister accordingly. Lastly, where the Minister so requests, the Inspector-General will monitor compliance by the NCA with directions or guidelines in relation to privacy issued by the Minister under section 18 of the NCA Act.

Division 2 of the new part IIIA will provide for the receipt and investigation of complaints. It is proposed that the Inspector-General be obliged to investigate all complaints including those which may have arisen before the passage of this Bill. As is appropriate, however, discretions are built into section 55AG which will enable him not to inquire into complaints which, for instance, are frivolous or vexatious or where, having regard to all the circumstances, an inquiry or further inquiry is not warranted. The latter category would include past complaints which, in the view of the Inspector-General, have been dealt with satisfactorily by the informal means of investigation which have existed hitherto.

Division 3 will deal with the conduct of inquiries. The Inspector-General will be required to inform the Minister and the chairperson of the NCA before commencing an investigation. His inquiries will be conducted in private and will not be subject to formal procedural requirements.

He will be entitled to compel production of information and documents and to make such use of the documents as may be needed for the purposes of the investigation. He will also be able to compel people to attend before him and give evidence on oath or affirmation, including evidence which they would otherwise be entitled by privilege, or obliged by law, to withhold. The Inspector-General will also have reasonable access to NCA premises for the purposes of an investigation, and special provision is made for the receipt of complaints from persons in custody.

There will be a two-stage reporting process, with a draft report given to the chairperson of the NCA for comment before the final report is submitted to the Minister and the chairperson. The report should include reasons and recommend any restitution considered appropriate for a complainant. The Inspector-General will be required to advise the complainant—and the IGC or the PJC, if they referred the complaint—of the outcome of the investigation, so far as this will not prejudice NCA security. The chairperson of the NCA will be required to advise the Inspector-General of his action in response to each report. If dissatisfied with that response the Inspector-General will be entitled to discuss the matter with, and make a written report on it to, the Minister.

The Inspector-General will be required to provide an annual report to the Minister, commenting on the investigations he has conducted during the past year. The Minister will be required to table the report in each House as soon as practicable after receipt. Provision is made in clause 9 of the Bill for an amendment to section 55 under which the PJC would examine the Inspector-General's annual report. This is intended to provide a means by which the PJC may better inform itself in the performance of its principal function under that section—that is, the monitoring and reviewing of the NCA's performance. The provision is not intended to suggest accountability on the part of the Inspector-General to the PJC.

The second main aspect of the Bill is the provision of a mechanism for resolving disagreement over what is often termed operational or sensitive information. In its recent report, the PJC sought clarification of its rights of access to information held by the NCA. Disputes about such information in the past have given rise to questions of parliamentary privilege. As foreshadowed in its response to the PJC report, the Government has decided to deal with this issue by providing, in a new subsection 55(2), that in the performance of its duties the PJC is entitled to require the chairperson of the NCA to produce to it any document held by the NCA or to divulge or communicate to it any information held by or known to the NCA—except to the extent that it is or contains sensitive information. `Sensitive information' is defined in an amendment set out in clause 3, as information the disclosure of which might prejudice the safety or reputation of a person, the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence, the effectiveness of an investigation by the NCA, or the operations of law enforcement agencies.

Where the PJC requests access to information and the chairperson of the NCA refuses access on the ground that the information requested is sensitive, as defined, the amendment to section 55 will allow the PJC to refer the request to the Minister administering the NCA Act for written resolution of the dispute. The Bill provides that the Minister may require the Inspector-General of the NCA to inquire into the matter, and the Inspector-General must do so in accordance with the inquiry provisions of the new part IIIA of the NCA Act. When the Inspector-General has reported to the Minister, the Minister will have to decide whether or not the information is sensitive, and notify the chairperson, the PJC and the Inspector-General of his decision. The Bill will also authorise the Minister to include reasons for the decision in the formal determination, where this can be done without disclosing sensitive information.

Of the minor amendments included in the Bill, one affects section 29A of the NCA Act. This section only came into force in January this year and provides that NCA process issued under sections 28 or 29 may include a notation prohibiting disclosure of any information relating to the process. This conflicts with the credit reporting provisions of the Privacy Act 1988, which require agencies to record any disclosures on an individual's credit information file and to ensure that an individual can obtain access to his or her file. Access by an individual to a credit reference file bearing a note of disclosure to the NCA could seriously jeopardise an NCA investigation. Accordingly, clause 7 of the Bill will amend section 29A of the NCA Act to provide that, where the Privacy Act would require that a note be made of a disclosure made in response to NCA process and that process includes a notation requiring secrecy, the requirement to record the disclosure is postponed until the effect of the notation expires. The Privacy Commissioner has indicated that this proposal is acceptable because of the particular circumstances. Disclosure is only temporarily prohibited and the policy underlying section 29A was thoroughly debated during its passage through Parliament last year.

The other minor amendment affects section 12 of the Act. As indicated in its response to the PJC report, the Government and members of the intergovernmental committee have considered the position of subsections 12(4) and (5), which were criticised as unclear by the South Australian Supreme Court in the 1989 case of Carbone. Clause 9 of the Bill repeals those subsections.

In conclusion, I would like briefly to reiterate some of the general points made in the statement tabled by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) on 1 June. I believe the work of the NCA over the past eight years has by and large been very successful and that this reflects both the qualities of those who have worked in the NCA and the essential soundness of the legislative scheme into which Parliament put so much effort in 1983 and 1984. Nonetheless, there will continue to be a need for fine tuning of the legislation from time to time and I take this opportunity to thank the PJC again for the important contribution it has made to this process through its report Who is to Guard the Guards?. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a cognate debate on the Social Security Amendment Bill 1992 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, which is in fact the resumption of the debate that was adjourned just prior to lunch. As my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) said this morning, the coalition does not oppose these Bills. However, I want to confine my remarks to the Social Security Amendment Bill 1992 and specifically to the amendments to section 695 of the principal Act, the Social Security Act 1991. This section deals with the claims for sickness benefits.

PARA.TAB: The amendments deal with what is described as the education leavers waiting period, which is the deferment period to be served by an education leaver claiming sickness allowance. I want to say at the outset that I am pleased the Government has brought this legislation down at a relatively early stage in this parliamentary session so that there has been and is now still time for due consideration and debate. Sadly, such was not the case back in May 1990, when the Government amended the social security legislation to set a deferment period equivalent to that imposed on claimants for unemployment benefits for anyone leaving the education system and claiming sickness benefits. That amendment, encompassed in the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, was rammed through the House under guillotine in less than one hour. At the time, the then Minister for Social Security stated:

SPEECH.PARA: People who would suffer severe financial hardship through this initiative may claim special benefit.

While that sounds fine in principle, the practical application of the Minister's statement is another matter. This is the reason why I have entered this debate. The Social Security Amendment Bill 1992 contains the following amendment to section 695:

(4) A person is not subject to an education leavers waiting period if the Secretary is satisfied that special benefit would be payable to the person during the waiting period if the person were subject to the waiting period.

However, satisfying the Secretary to the Department of Social Security that a special benefit is warranted can be a harrowing experience. While it may be the Government's intention to honour its often stated commitment to social justice and the provision of a social welfare safety net, the Department of Social Security's way of assessing applications for special benefit has, in at least one case with which I am very familiar, worked against giving effect to legislative intent.

PARA.TAB: It is a very serious matter, and I would like to show just how serious by drawing the attention of the House to the personal experience of one of my constituents. Back in April 1991, this young woman, whom I will not name in this House for reasons of privacy, was forced to withdraw from tertiary study as a result of extreme ill health. At the time it was evident that she faced a long term incapacity for work. Therefore, on 16 April 1991 she applied to the Department of Social Security for either sickness or special benefit.

The way in which that application was handled was documented in a Social Security Appeals Tribunal finding dated 11 June 1991. In summary, the events were as follows: first, the April application was apparently lost by the Department of Social Security, although a note on the applicant's file confirmed that she had been interviewed three days later; second, another file note indicated that she was advised by phone on 9 May 1991 that a deferment period of 13 weeks would be applied to her application; third, on 13 May 1991 she completed a new application for special benefit; fourth, a record of decision on her file indicated that special benefit should be rejected as a result of the application of the short term assets test—no written advice was provided on any of these decisions, information was given to her over the phone; and, fifth, a new decision not to pay sickness benefit was made on the basis that she had not suffered any loss of income as a result of incapacity.

Not surprisingly, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal described the Department's case as `somewhat confused'. On 19 June 1991 the SSAT found that my constituent was entitled to the payment of special benefit from 13 May 1991. The Department, however, decided to appeal against the findings of the SSAT and, on 15 July 1991, it took the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Again, the Department's appeal was unsuccessful. The Department then decided to take the matter before the Federal Court. By this time my constituent had raised her concerns with the Ombudsman and, on 27 May 1992, Senior Assistant Ombudsman, M. J. Williamson, from the Canberra office of the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman, made the following statement in a letter to my constituent:

SPEECH.PARA: We are convinced, as I know you are, that DSS's overall performance in your case has been unsatisfactory, to put it modestly. Your file is replete with examples of poor administration, including repeated failure to reply to your enquiries or to keep you informed in any other way. With the exception of one or two officers, the Department appears to have ignored your right to be treated with courtesy and consideration. It is disturbing, for example, that you found out that the Department intended to appeal to the Federal Court from Mr Hedges—
who is from the Ombudsman's office in Perth—
and not from the Department.

On 30 July this year, the saga which began back in April 1991 came to an end when Mr Justice Lee of the Federal Court dismissed the Department's appeal. Throughout the whole of this process the Government would have incurred tens of thousands of dollars in costs—all over the matter of some $900. In the judgments of both the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court, reference was made to the case, turning very much on its own special circumstances. The point of this is that the Department's pursuit of this matter can hardly be regarded as an important test case. After all, a special benefit is just that; it is a benefit granted in special cases of severe hardship, with each case being judged according to the individual's particular circumstances.

PARA.TAB: For this reason alone, it is not unreasonable to describe the Department's pursuit of appeal after appeal, to the point of legal exhaustion, as a monumental waste of taxpayers' money and government resources. I would be interested to know whether the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett)—he can take this on notice—could tell the House what the case actually cost, including the cost in time of officers of his Department who could not perform their normal functions while appearing before the SSAT, the AAT and the Federal Court, not to mention the cost of flying departmental people and legal representatives to Perth. Although my constituent's case was eventually resolved in her favour, her experience has been a traumatic one. The stresses and strains of being involved in three appeals and waiting some 15 months for a final resolution have aggravated the ill health which forced her to withdraw from her studies in the first place and have severely retarded her recovery.

The problems which she experienced were in large part due to the short term available funds test used by the Department in assessing claims for special benefit. Under this particular test, the Department considers that a person is in severe financial hardship only if he has less than the equivalent of two weeks benefit. For my constituent that amount was $154.10. This short term available funds test is seriously flawed and totally unbalanced, as it does not in any way take account of any financial commitments and liabilities. In this particular case, just one liability amounted to $52 per week. That was the sum of money needed by my constituent each week to meet ongoing medical expenses not covered by Medicare. Perhaps this test was designed for people experiencing a one or two week waiting period. However, a 13 week waiting period can hardly be described as short term. Mr Justice Lee of the Federal Court said in his finding:

SPEECH.PARA: The direction vested in the Secretary was provided for the clear purpose of alleviating hardship or ameliorating what would otherwise be unnecessary harshness in the operation of the Act.

These concerns which are reflected here are ones I share, and that is why I have raised them in this debate. It is all very well for the Government to legislate to overcome hardship, but it must ensure that its Department administers its legislation in a way which is consistent with meeting that objective. The extremely harsh, short term available funds test is not set out in legislation; it is contained within departmental guidelines and is defective as a result of ignoring liabilities. This deficiency was highlighted by P. Johnson, Deputy President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Page 18 of the AAT's finding against the Department's appeal states:

. . . the Tribunal notes that the Special Benefit Claim Form makes no provision for off-setting liabilities and to that extent does not provide a basis on which an accurate assessment can be made of the claimant's actual financial circumstances.
The Federal Court judgment of Mr Justice Lee also drew attention to this problem. Page 21 of that judgment states:

The printed form provided by the Department for application for a special benefit requested a claimant to supply details of monies to which the claimant had access. The form did not request a statement of any of the current liabilities.

Clearly—and this is the thrust of my case—it is up to the Government to ensure that this situation is remedied and that departmental guidelines accord with the substance and spirit of the law. My constituent and her family have been through a very trying experience. It is their earnest desire—and I speak on their behalf—that no-one else should suffer the same fate. In order to try to help others who might be caught in a similar bureaucratic trap, they have researched and written two detailed and well-balanced papers which offer constructive comments on legislative and administrative arrangements for income support. The first of these papers was submitted to the Government's task force on management improvement within the Australian Public Service and it has been very well received. The other has been forwarded recently to the parliamentary inquiry into legislative and legal drafting by the Commonwealth. This inquiry is currently being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

PARA.TAB: As far as the circumstances surrounding my constituent's case are concerned, I sincerely hope that both the task force and the Committee will take good account of the submissions before them and that some good will come of this family's unhappy experience. The amendment to the social security legislation which is currently before the House has the potential to make life a little easier for those who, like my constituent, are forced to withdraw from the education system as a result of ill health. However, this potential will be realised only if both government legislation and the administrative arrangements within the Department are in accord. Unless legislation and administration work in harmony the Department of Social Security will be unable to meet the terms of its charter, which are:

SPEECH.PARA: To deliver social security entitlements with fairness, courtesy and efficiency.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are dealing with certain social security amendment Bills which, ostensibly at least, are designed to assist people during these very difficult times. The Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 proposes to allow people access to half of their family allowance payment as a lump sum. This no doubt will help people; although I worry a little that it is another example of this Government's Bankcard mentality. Certainly, people do not have to borrow this money, but by getting it in advance they naturally will find it more difficult once they have spent the money. One might wonder in that regard whether this has more to do with an election date and giving people a little more spending money to maybe affect some statistics around Australia than it has to do with people's welfare. If that is the case, I would certainly condemn this action.

PARA.TAB: But, as has been said by previous speakers, the Opposition is supporting these measures. I certainly agree with that situation. However, it brings to the attention of the House, in a more general sense, the very difficult circumstances confronting Australians today. I feel the blame has to be laid right at the doorstep of this Government.

It was announced in the media last night that the Catholic bishops of Australia would today release a major statement criticising Australian society entitled Commonwealth for the Common Good. It draws to our attention the fact that in today's society the country's richest one per cent are now owning one-quarter of the nation's wealth. The statement goes on to say that that is the fault of both political parties, community attitudes and so on. But the statistical fact is that that situation has occurred now and this Government is in office now. In terms of those who pull the levers—which is a common statement in these places—the blame must be laid very squarely with the Government.

It is a statistical fact that throughout the administration of this Government the so-called poverty gap has widened. The rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer. One may wonder how a party which claims to represent the less well-off in our society in particular and which constantly throws criticism at the coalition parties, claiming that they have a different view of these things, can live with that.

But the situation is even worse for the Government. In the Canberra Times of Tuesday, 15 September an article refers to an employee of government, Ann Harding, as having published a particular report. I will read some of the article because I think it should be understood by all. It states:
The Federal Government's own social and economic policy analyst has concluded that its indirect-tax policies are hitting struggling families hardest.
The findings, by the Centre of Social and Economic Modelling, undermine the Government's attack on the Coalition's plans for a universal goods-and-services tax.

The analysis contradicts the Government also on the implications of the Fightback package, suggesting that it would not be difficult to compensate low-income households for the impact of the GST, and concludes that taxes such as the petrol excise, which would be scrapped under Fightback, were the most regressive taxes of all.

SPEECH.PARA: As a representative of people who live in more remote areas, I would say that those taxes are doubly regressive for those people. Of course, there is plenty of evidence that they were among the first to be hit by the economic recession and depression simply because of their isolation and the recent downturn in the rural sector. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: The analysis of existing wholesale sales tax and excises was conducted by the director of the centre, Ann Harding, in June.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not so long ago. It continues:
It is a unit in the portfolio of Health, Housing and Community Services.
which is under the control of this Government. The article goes on:

PARA.TAB: Dr Harding said that in 1991-92 wholesale taxes and excises had been estimated to provide more than 20 per cent of total government revenue, or nearly $19 billion. However, the burden fell more heavily on low-income households, including those virtually exempt from income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on:

PARA.TAB: The ranking assumed—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the ranking of families—

that a family of two adults and two children would need an income of $540 a week to reach the same standard of living as a single adult with an income of $200. On the basis of this "equivalent household income", Dr Harding concluded that the Government's indirect taxes were highly regressive.

PARA.TAB: Families in the lowest ranking paid an average of $31 a week in indirect taxes, or eight times as much as they paid in income tax.

"Indirect taxes appear more regressive when households are ranked by an income measure which takes account of their needs," Dr Harding said. "Indirect taxes as a percentage of gross income fall from 10.75 per cent for the bottom decile . . . to 5.1 for the top decile.

SPEECH.PARA: Further on, the article states:

PARA.TAB: Dr Harding's figures showed that the bottom 10 per cent of households paid almost 6 per cent of their gross income in excises, and the top 10 per cent only 2 per cent.

In relation to the impact of Fightback on various family types, Dr Harding used a Treasury analysis that showed that the indirect-tax burden would increase by a net $16 a week for a single-income family, with children, in the lowest income bracket. A similar family in the highest income bracket would pay an extra $44 in indirect taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point, Dr Harding is talking about Fightback. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Although concluding that indirect taxes in general were regressive, Dr Harding suggested that it was possible to compensate low-income earners for the impact of the GST, as proposed in Fightback.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking about somebody who earns his or her living from politics; we are talking about a highly respected adviser to government who wrote the Government a letter and said: `You've got it wrong; please do something for the poor people'. What she has said is most significant in all of this is that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should read the report.

—I have read what has been quoted. The Minister for Family Support and Minister for Local Government is interjecting on me, Mr Deputy Speaker, and there are rules about that in this place. The simple fact is that I have read what has been quoted, and not denied, in our community newspapers—in the Canberra Times, in fact. It is a pity that the Minister wants to be a smart alec about a matter as serious as this.

PARA.TAB: The researcher has criticised both forms of indirect taxing as being regressive. She has been very even-handed in this and I did not try to hide that fact in my presentation. But she said—and it is patently obvious—that we can compensate for a GST but we cannot compensate, or this Government has certainly never attempted to compensate, for the burdens of its indirect tax system.

It is very easy to see why we can compensate for a GST. It is out in the open; it is up-front. It will be printed on every docket, be it at the supermarket or on a docket received for some other things. It is clear for people to see in the first instance. Down at the bowser there will be no more of this business of ripping 26c a litre off people and not telling them. We will no longer see the price of petrol go up and not know who is getting the money—be it the Government, the retailer or the wholesaler—because it will be shown separately. The coalition is determined to ensure that that occurs at every level. The first thing the public will be able to do is make a judgment as to what would be appropriate compensation.

The other fact of life is that the Treasury has made it very clear that there will be a CPI effect of 3 or 4 per cent. It is interesting to note that on 26 May in this place the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said that the effect would be 4.7 per cent and on the same day the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said it would be 5 per cent or 6 per cent, which does not say much for their figuring. In other words, they are grabbing numbers out of the air.

But even if the CPI effect is 3 or 4 per cent, or one of those other figures, the Opposition has set out in its policies to make sure the compensation is available. It recognises the fact, as identified by Dr Harding, seeks to identify what the problem might be, and offers highly identifiable compensation.

There will be substantial tax cuts for wage and salary earners at the low end of the market. If, for instance, one had a taxable income of $10,000 a year, the tax rate would be 5c in the dollar. At the more recognisable and more typical income of $20,000 a year, the tax would be 10c in the dollar. There is a substantial reduction in the tax burden at the income tax level, giving people money to take home to confront a 3 or 4 per cent increase. But it does not stop there. I found it interesting when I was shadow Minister for health to have identified to me how many single mothers have private health insurance. They do it because they are terrified of the current system. We had someone lauding it at Question Time today.

I want to relate a story about the Swan District Hospital, which I think is in the electorate of the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). A 21-year-old girl, a close friend of my daughter's, fell off a horse early on Saturday morning and broke her arm in a very bad way above the elbow and below the shoulder. She went to the Swan District Hospital, which gave her some aspirin, sent her home and told her to come back on Monday because orthopaedic surgeons no longer worked on weekends. The outrageous part about that is that they did not even have the decency to ask her whether she had private health insurance—which she did—and direct her to a private hospital, where she certainly would have received assistance. They might also have told her to go to the casualty section of Royal Perth Hospital. I became aware of this on Saturday night when the young lady was vomiting through pain, and we were able to assist her.

These sorts of things happen, but the tragedy of that example is that the young lady accepted it. People have lost so much confidence in the health system that she believed the system could not look after her on weekends. She just went home. She is not dumb—she has a highly paid position in a solicitor's office—but she believed that people cannot be fixed up in Australia on a weekend. That is a great indictment of the system. That is a matter of fact. The young lady's name is available if anybody wants to try to disprove what I am saying. I did not know what to do. I was devastated to think things were so bad in Australia.

These are the sorts of problems we have, but what do we do about them? Supporting mothers, on very limited incomes, are taking out private health insurance because they do not trust the health system. What is the Opposition saying to those supporting mothers? We are saying, `We'll give you a $400 a year special rebate. It is a tax rebate, but it applies even if you have no income. We will send you a refund cheque'. To the elderly we are saying, `If you are on a pension, we will put it up by 8 per cent to compensate a perceived 3 to 4 per cent increase in your cost of living brought about by our consumption tax'. What are we saying to all the other pensioners—supporting mothers and unemployed mothers? We are saying, `We'll increase yours by 6 per cent'. What are we saying to the elderly? We are saying, `We'll give you $800 a year if you buy private health insurance and do your non-insured colleagues a favour by getting out of the road and giving them greater opportunity to get into public hospitals'. We are doubling the family allowance to $40 a fortnight per child. Why? It is because we believe in giving the compensation necessary, but we can also identify the tax burden. The Government rabbits on in here day after day, saying, `But your tax is going to tax food'. We do not resile from that; we admit to it. We have given the figures, confirmed by Treasury, as to the overall economic effect of that.

But the people Dr Harding is talking about, and the people the bishops are talking about, seldom hire lawyers or expensive accountants. They will not be taxed on that. They will not be taxed on their mortgage; they will not be taxed on their income tax. We are talking about a 3 or 4 per cent increase to about one-third of their income. We are giving them a 30 per cent tax cut, doubling their family allowance and increasing the dependent spouse rebate, et cetera. While the Government gets on with the idea of withholding taxes on their meagre interest earnings on their small savings accounts, we are saying that they can have some interest income free of tax. We have identified that there is a burden. We do not resile from it; we provide the appropriate compensation.

The Government says there is no tax on food, yet we draw to its attention the fact that just in the area of transport an owner-driver truckie pays about $1,000 a week in one consumer tax or another, starting with close to $1,000 a month in lease payments associated with the sales tax on his truck. Then there is the fuel tax that we will eliminate and the payroll tax component that is built in all the way back from the iron ore miner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get back to the Bill, Wilson.

—If the Minister is not caring for the people on these low incomes that his officer, Dr Harding, has identified, and if he does not think that is associated with what he is doing with his miserable little family allowance, he is a very poor member of parliament. He is a member of parliament who represents a country area and says, `I want to tax your petrol'. The honourable member should go out to his electorate and say to his constituents, `I'm happy to tax you $10 a tankful when you have to drive 30 or 40 miles just to take your kids to the next town to have a football match'. The honourable member should have the guts to go and tell them. He does not; he snivels and tells them fibs about how the system will work. Let us get back to that loaf of bread, because a bit of wheat is grown in the Minister's country. He should know better. He should support Fightback in the interests of his constituents.
—You don't even support the GST.
—Yes, I do.
—You didn't last year.

—I did not, but I support it in the context of Fightback. I did not buy a pig in a poke. That is all I did not do. I studied it, as the Minister should have, and came to the conclusion that it is in the interests of the people I represent.
—You caved in.
—No, I did not cave in; I just had the guts to tell my Party colleagues that I wanted to know that it was to the benefit of my constituents before I would do it. The honourable member does not care.

PARA.TAB: Government members say there is no tax on bread, but how many times is a truck involved before we get a loaf of bread? I can tell honourable members quickly, because we have done the research, how many times payroll tax, sales tax and fuel tax impact on a package of butter: 220 times. And Government members say there is no tax on it! The trouble is that they find it extremely difficult to calculate and, as Dr Harding reminds them, they therefore do not compensate. Only a GST can be clearly identified. As a result, it is only then that governments can give proper compensation, as the coalition properly provides.

We will support this legislation, but we do not perceive that giving people in receipt of family allowance a bit of money in advance and then letting them be poor six months later is the solution. We will double the family allowance. We will increase the family allowance supplement. We know what Government members are up to: they want to feed out this $100, or whatever it is, to people so that for a brief period they will feel a bit more comfortable—about the time the Government has an election. It is very cynical, because this is a serious problem.

The bishops tell Government members the problem, and their own public servants tell them the problem, but they get up here and say, `There is no tax on a loaf of bread'. If there is 10 per cent tax on that loaf of bread—and I believe there will be by the time the freight aspect is considered—and 15 per cent is added after that tax is taken off, the increase is 3 or 4 per cent. That is exactly what we, the Federal Treasury and everybody else says will be the CPI effect of our introducing this tax. Yet Government members stand up whenever they think there is no-one who is competent there to criticise them and start telling people that everything is going up by 15 per cent. Their own public servants say something different.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not saying it.

—Not saying it? May lightning strike you dead, because the next time you say that I hope it happens. Just think about it. Zap! He would make a very small heap of ashes—one puff and he would be blown away. The simple fact is that the Government's own public servants have told it where it has put the poorer people in our community. The Government gives them no tax cuts. Those opposite just want to pick up the ones they think they do not already have. No justice, no decency, and it has a consumption tax system for which its own Public Service says one cannot compensate for. Of course, while the Government has all that burden on it, that $19 billion, what are those opposite talking about a lousy $100 for? It is a waste of time and it is a disgrace. Government members should be ashamed of themselves because they are not doing anything.
—I am glad you support the Bill.
—I like Ministers who laugh at the difficulties of poor people. Isn't it wonderful?
—I am laughing at you.
—No, the Minister is laughing because he thinks this is all a joke. (Time expired)
