TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has raised the same matters as I want to raise in this debate on Social Security Amendment Bills Nos 1 and 2 of 1992 because I think it brings to the fore the absolute hypocrisy of this Government. This is a government that talks about social justice, and rushes out there to the poor and says, `We represent you; we represent the poor; we represent the families on low incomes; we represent the workers'. Well, that is a lot of hogwash. This must be the most hypocritical government on record. The Government states in Social Security Amendment Bill No. 2 that it will allow families to take part of their family allowance up-front—
—Optional.

—I said `allow', I did not say `had to'—as a special consideration. Quite interestingly, this option commences on 1 January 1993. I notice that the extra gift to pensioners will start in March 1993. This echoes the Wills by-election when there was suddenly $125 extra given to families just before that by-election. This would not be part of an election strategy would it, Minister, to fool those low incomes earners that they might be a little better off? But they will not be because once they spend that $100-odd up-front they will not get it later. When low income earners go down to the deli to pay for their baked beans, their butter or whatever, the money will not be there because it was spent earlier.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what this so-called Labor Government has done to the poor people in this country, to families in this country. Figures taken by the Social Policy Research Centre of the University of New South Wales show that between 1983 and 1990 families with average incomes or below experienced a drop of 4 per cent in real disposable income. Between 1983 and 1991 the percentage of children living in poverty actually increased, with 1.85 million Australians now living below the Henderson poverty line and 1.1 million living in absolute poverty. In 1982-83, the average after-tax earnings of an average family with a dependant spouse and two children was $24,891 in 1989 dollar terms. In 1989, after six years of a Labor government, that family's after-tax earnings dropped by $1,291 to $23,000. That is what this Labor Government has done for the families of Australia.

But they are not the only figures available which show what has happened to families in Australia under this Government. Let us look at some work done by the School of Economic and Financial Studies at Macquarie University in an article by Marc Lombard entitled `Income Distribution in Australia 1983-1989'. One table in this article tells us what has happened to the top one per cent, 5 per cent and 10 per cent of income earners compared with the bottom group of income earners. In 1982-83, the top 5 per cent received 13 per cent of income but by 1988-89 that had risen to 18 per cent. These high income earners had increased their percentage of income quite considerably. Over the same period the bottom 20 per cent decreased; they went from 8.24 to 6.79. In other words, the rich got richer and the poor got poorer.

If we further examine some of these figures that Mr Lombard has produced, we see that in 1983 the top 5 per cent of income earners had a 1 1/2 times greater share of the national income cake than those in the bottom 20 per cent. That was bad enough; however, what happens after six years of Labor Government? By that time, the top 5 per cent had increased their share of the national cake compared with the lowest 20 per cent by 2 1/2 times. That is under this so-called social justice government, the Labor Government which is supposedly for the poor, for the lower income earners. Again I say, what hypocrisy. Mr Lombard's article states:
The major finding of this study is that there has been a significant widening of the income gap in Australia during the period 1983 to 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: This is probably best illustrated by the fact that, in 1982/83, the top 1% of income earners earned as much as the bottom 11.09% of income earners. By 1988/89, that same top 1% earned as much as the bottom 21.19%.

SPEECH.PARA: The rich got much richer and the poor got much poorer. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Translated into numbers of taxpayers, it means that, in 1982/83, some 61,000 high-income earners had a taxable income equivalent to that of 672,000 low-income earners. Six years later, the 79,000 taxpayers representing the top 1% of income-earners were earning as much as the bottom 1,666,000 income-earners.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the matter that the honourable member for O'Connor raised, which is the statement by the Catholic bishops entitled Common Wealth for the Common Good. An AAP release reads:

. . . the bishops found a `great and increasing inequality of wealth and income in Australia' with the rich getting richer, the poor just maintaining their position, and middle income citizens getting significantly poorer.

That is exactly what I read previously in the article by Marc Lombard, and it was also displayed in the study conducted by the University of New South Wales. So it is not just one study that brings this up. Everybody who has studied what has happened under this Labor Government has found out that the poor have been hit. They have been hit coming, going and everywhere. While the rich have got richer, the poor have got right down there and are a lot poorer. According to the bishops, one of the main causes of poverty is unemployment. From Justice Trends, which is published by the Catholic Church, I will quote what else the bishops found:
. . . the bishops have found:
*In 10 years—
that is, the 10 years of this Labor Government, the so-called social justice government—
the number of people on social security payments has more than doubled.
*In the same time, the proportion of national income reaching middle-income people has dropped significantly.
*Recent research suggests that three in 10 Australians not only own no wealth, but owe more than they own.

That is, back to the Bankcard mentality fostered by this Government, which puts $20.5 billion of its Budget on Bankcard. Australian poor families are forced proportionally to do the same. The article continues:
*Other research points to a shrinking middle class, with sole parents, unemployed, disabled people and families who lack a breadwinner making up the bulk of the growing new poor.
The next point states:
*Income of the nation's most wealthy may have fallen slightly over the past three years—
due to the recession induced by this Government—
but has more than trebled over the past eight.

Does that statistic relate to lower income families? Does the Minister tell the workers in the factories that, under his Government, the poor have got a lot poorer, those in the middle classes have almost disappeared and the wealthy have trebled their income? What a great Labor Government! Finally, the article says:

. . . over 200,000 households are on public housing lists, refuges for the homeless are stretched, charities face funding shortfalls and many people are now unable to afford legal and medical costs, the Bishops say.

The Minister does not seem to be taking any interest in this. I take it that he does not care what has happened to the poor and to the 200,000 households that are on public waiting lists. As we have mentioned public housing lists, let us have a look at what has happened under this Government to the affordability of housing. I refer to the Affordability of Australian Housing by the National Housing Strategy. What does it say this Government has done to housing affordability? If we look at 1982, we see that families on lower average weekly earnings spent $117 a week in 1990 dollars on their house payment. By 1988, that had risen to $129, which is a considerable portion of a family's income. However, when we look at the base that is needed for people to buy a house—the deposit they have to pay—the situation is considerably worse. In 1983, the deposit for an average house required 109.6 per cent of the average income. By 1990, that had risen to 215.8 per cent; it had doubled. That is what has happened under this Government.

PARA.TAB: Families who 10 years ago could have hoped to have owned their own house can no longer do it; they are on the public housing list. They cannot have a house that will belong to them and that their children will grow up in. It has become a hopeless dream for most people—or one might call it a nightmare.

I turn now to an article mentioned by the honourable member for O'Connor entitled `The Incidence of Wholesale Sales Tax and Excises in Late 1991'. The Minister asked the honourable member for O'Connor whether he had read the article. I will be quoting from that article. Let us look at what happens to families' incomes because of this Labor Government's hidden taxes—not all its taxes, just the wholesale sales tax and the excise. What does that do to the average family or, more importantly perhaps, families on low incomes? Of a gross income of $290.70, it takes $31.30 per week; that is, 10.8 per cent of a family's income goes on the Government's hidden consumption taxes. The GST, which those opposite like to say is a consumption tax, is going to hit poor families. The Government omits to say that it already has hidden consumption taxes hitting those families: $31.30 per week, which is 10.8 per cent of their gross income.

How do these taxes hit the richer families? We are talking about equity. What do we really mean by equity? How do these taxes hit them? An amount of $81.85 is spent by upper income families with a gross income of $1,622, which is 5 per cent. What a regressive tax system. The Government has hit the lower income people: 10.8 per cent of their gross income goes in hidden consumption taxes, while the rich have only 5 per cent. I want to make it clear that those figures are rated for families on lower incomes. That table takes into account the number of children in the family.
I will quote briefly from the article mentioned by the honourable member for O'Connor. Ann Harding refers to the GST—the consumption tax that the Government keeps attacking. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Treasury analysis that showed that the indirect-tax burden—
this is the GST—
would increase by a net $16 per week for a single-income family, with children, in the lowest income bracket.
That is the same family I was just talking about, the family that paid $31.30 in hidden taxes. The article continues:

PARA.TAB: Although concluding that indirect taxes in general were regressive, Dr Harding suggested that it was possible to compensate low-income earners for the impact of the GST, as proposed in Fightback.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what Fightback does. We have said that low income earners will be hit by the indirect taxes, but we can overcome that. We make some attempt to compensate them, but the present Government does not. The present Government has reduced families to poverty.

PARA.TAB: For the edification of the Minister, as he does not seem to be aware of it, I will briefly go through what Fightback offers to families; what this Liberal Government will give to families to help pick them up from the shambles that 10 years of this Labor Government has left them in. First, family allowances will be doubled for families with combined incomes below $30,000 per annum. For a low income family with two children, currently getting $41.80, that amount will be doubled; they will get over $80—an increase of over $40. It makes the Government's lump sum payment of $100-odd pale into insignificance.

Fightback is weighted towards the lower income earners, because families with combined incomes between $30,000 and $40,000 will have their family allowances increased by 50 per cent, while families with combined incomes of over $40,000 will receive a 6 per cent increase in their family allowance. A family allowance supplement will be maintained and increased by 6 per cent. The independent spouse rebate will be increased by $300 per annum. That again will phase out as incomes rise over $75,000. We have $90m set aside to help lower income families cope with the problem of child care. Family crisis care is needed because those opposite have put families into crisis. The Government has sent them to St Vincent de Paul; to the local community church—to whoever will give them a handout to help them get through the week. We are going to help those people. We are going to help my local churches that are absolutely inundated with requests. We will be giving $50m to help those voluntary organisations help the people that those opposite have sent into poverty.

On the subject of taxation, the honourable member for O'Connor dealt with the way that we will cut taxation for the lower income people. I remind the Minister that One Nation did not cut their tax; it cut the tax of those people in the next income bracket. So, under this Government, people on the lower incomes will still pay 20c in the dollar. Under our proposal they will pay only 16.2c. What is more, under our proposal, the tax threshold will rise from $5,400 to $7,000, which will be a boon for lower income families.

With the first home owners scheme, families earning up to $40,000 and saving to buy their first home will be eligible for a one-off payment of $2,000. There will also be a health rebate for those families paying private health insurance. Finally, for young people trying to buy a house, to increase housing affordability $1,000 of interest on new savings will be tax free. This Government cannot even come close to any of that. The best it can offer is to take some of its child allowance up front and pay it back later.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SIMMONS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Support and Minister for Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It is interesting that this debate today on the Social Security Amendment Bill and the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2) has been extraordinarily wide ranging, covering a series of issues that have very little to do with the legislation, I must say. But I want to concentrate on some of the specifics that have been raised in the debate before I get on to the more general points made by Opposition and Government members.

PARA.TAB: I begin with the very obvious statement, to counter some of the nonsense that has been uttered by the Opposition today, that the Keating Government is very much committed to the notion of social justice for all Australians and these two pieces of legislation, along with some of the other changes that the Government has made over the last few years, amply demonstrate that commitment. It is significant that very few of the Opposition members were prepared to knock in any way the propositions being put forward in the legislation dealing with the options for family allowance payment and with the education leavers waiting periods.

In opening the debate, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) said that he saw family allowance as not being intended as a series of lump sum payments. This is certainly not the proposal that is in the Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 2). The point is that it is an option to receive the payment as a lump sum. It is all about flexibility in terms of providing options to people who wish to take advantage of them. It is interesting that in his contribution he referred to the education leavers waiting period, yet there is no specific mention of that notion in Fightback. He went on to say that the Opposition has reduced the waiting periods in its employment strategy, but he was not talking about the education leavers waiting period. As I understand it, he was talking about people on Job Search allowance who get a job and lose it within a period of three months; they will not be required to serve a further waiting period for the Job Search allowance.

Aspects in Fightback relating to changes in family allowance were also raised by members of the Opposition and I would like to make some comment about them. Finally, there was the usual rhetoric we have come to expect from Opposition members about the benefits of the 15 per cent consumption tax.

Right throughout this debate there was a theme about families and really, I suppose, an attempt to stereotype families within the community. Some of the speeches from Opposition members today showed that they are very much aligned to the stereotype view of what constitutes a family. Indeed, the Fightback! document presents an image of an average Australian family story, with Mike, the housewife, Sally, and their two children. I for one do not deny in any way that that constitutes a family. But I point out that that stereotype view of a family within Australia represents about 22 per cent of all households. For example, tonight in Sydney there are probably upwards of one million people living alone in houses. Those people surely would see themselves as part of a family, but they do not fit this picket fence stereotype view of a family that we have come to expect from the Opposition.

It is worth while pointing out some of the down sides in the Fightback material because they have not been brought out in this debate when we have heard notions of social justice echoed by some of the Opposition speakers. For example, during my time in the House during the debate, I heard no mention of any of the Opposition's proposals to slash $10 billion from government expenditure. There was no mention of the fact that part of that $10 billion involves cuts in the social security budget of about $2.4 billion. Of course, all of this would be compounded very much by the extraordinarily regressive consumption tax that would be put on a whole range of products and services that people use.

We heard a lot of rhetoric about the changes in family allowance proposed in Fightback. But, again, I do not recall hearing anything about the fact that under the Opposition's arrangements no family allowance will be payable once a family's income reaches $55,000 per annum. There are about 115,000 families with a joint gross income above $55,000 who would lose about $10 per week under the Opposition's proposal. With average weekly earnings now at over $30,000 a year, one can quickly do the sums and work out that a lot of two-income families would receive not one cent under the Opposition's proposal.It is also a little unclear as to whether the proposed income threshold is in 1991 dollars or 1994 dollars. If the $55,000 is to apply in 1994, its relative value is even less. What those opposite are really saying is that people on salaries over $46,000 would not be paid any family allowance. That would mean that about 300,000 families would get not even one cent of family allowance.

The other interesting aspect of the Opposition's proposals is that there would be very significant poverty traps for families at the $30,000 and $40,000 thresholds. For example, a three-child family earning $29,900 would receive $120 per fortnight in family allowance but, if the income increased by just $100 per annum to $30,000 the family would face a $30 per fortnight drop in the family allowance. Significantly, that would disadvantage a lot of middle income families.

Another interesting part of the debate related to the issue of sole parent pensioners in our community. Again, there was no mention of the fact that under the Opposition's Fightback proposals once the youngest child of a sole parent pensioner turned 12 years of age, the pensioner would no longer be eligible for that pension. Again, some 30,000 people would clearly lose their entitlement to the sole parent pension. Many sole parent pensioners within the community represent the very low end of the socio-economic spectrum within society.

Again, it is a case of this stereotype image; the Opposition tends to move in very quickly on the sole parent pensioners. It forgets about the jobs, education and training scheme and the fact that JET has assisted more than 80,000 sole parent pensioners since its introduction in 1989. The proportion of sole parent pensioners on earned income has increased from 9 per cent in 1983 to 21 per cent in 1992. Similarly, labour force participation for sole parent pensioners rose from 44 per cent to 55 per cent. In other words, the very positive steps that this Labor Government has taken have had a remarkable impact upon the sole parent pensioner client group within the Department of Social Security.

I turn to the goods and services tax. We heard a lot about the 15 per cent consumption tax during the debate. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) claims that the GST would result in price rises of a little over 4 per cent. But again, when people go through the Treasury analysis of some elements of the GST, I think they can make their own judgments as to the way in which it would impact upon families—that food prices would rise by about 8.9 per cent overall; dairy products by 9.6 per cent; clothing by 11.2 per cent; electricity costs by 10.7 per cent; and health services by a staggering 22.6 per cent.

All of those particular goods, all of those particular services, are the sorts of goods and services that families in Australia have to deal with on a day by day basis. The Opposition claims that all social security pensioners and beneficiaries, family allowance supplement recipients and education allowance recipients would receive adequate compensation for the price effects of the goods and services tax. However, the Opposition's compensation promises are really dependant upon the achievement of its estimated price rise of just over 4 per cent from the package. Under the Opposition's proposals, Australians would be committed to a permanently higher rate of inflation. The impact of that on housing would, of course, be fairly dramatic.

I turn to some of the individual contributions made by other members during the debate, and in particular I wish to comment on some of the extraordinary claims made by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). In the course of the debate he talked about the proposal of allowing people the option to bring forward $135.85 every six months as a `grubby little bribe'. I challenge the honourable member for McPherson to go out among his constituents and suggest to them that what the Government is proposing is some `grubby little bribe'. What we are doing is allowing people the option, the flexibility, to make their own judgments. That judgment, that option, is based on research that has been conducted by the Department of Social Security into representations that have been made to us by government and, I am sure, by Opposition members, which have very strongly endorsed the option of providing this form of payment to families.

We heard some very strong rhetoric from the honourable member for McPherson in attacking the notion of sole parent pensions and benefits, again to reinforce his image of the family within our community. It gets back to this extraordinarily narrow definition that Opposition members continue to use about families in the course of this debate. I thought the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) gave an extraordinarily strong reply to the challenge issued by the honourable member for McPherson to address the ALP's commitment to families. In my view, he did so admirably, not that there was any great challenge from the contribution by the honourable member for McPherson to do so.

Similarly, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) made a strong contribution, particularly with respect to the option of bringing forward the family payment from 1 January next year. The honourable member for Forde made very strong representations on this particular issue in the course of the year, and I certainly would not deny her some sort of ownership of the $135.85 optional up-front payment on the family allowance from January next year.

The issue of the notification of the changes was raised by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) during his contribution. I would certainly like to assure the honourable member—and indeed other members of this House—that the Department of Social Security is very much aware of its obligation to advise clients. In fact, we are probably the biggest single user of Australia Post services in terms of client advice letters. Certainly, clients will be advised of those changes well before 1 January.

The contribution made by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), again indicated his very strong interest in matters affecting social justice within this House and I think contrasted rather sharply with the rhetoric and, at times, bizarre comments of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). I guess most people here are fairly used to the histrionics of and the great amateur actor in the honourable member for Cowper.

The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) raised an issue about a particular constituent who had been affected by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. I am not sure of the specific details because when I was coming to the House I missed the first part of his contribution. I will certainly undertake to provide the honourable member for Tangney with what information I can on the particular costs of the appeal case that he raised.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was fairly typical in his contribution. Again, I guess we are all pretty used to his histrionics with respect to any debate within this House. In fact, I was extremely provoked—as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker—during his contribution and could not restrain myself from commenting on some of the extraordinary claims that he was making during the debate.

The honourable member for O'Connor talked about the Harding study on the GST, as did the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus). Generally speaking, of course, indirect taxes are reggressive but, importantly, our wholesale sales tax system exempts most food and clothing, while taxing luxury items at a much higher rate. It is certainly less regressive than any notion of a 15 per cent goods and services tax on virtually everything one cares to name.

It is also very clear that the Fightback package would see a very dramatic shift to indirect taxation in this country and would certainly change the nature of the very progressive taxation system that we have. There would be a greater share of tax revenue, which would come from the indirect tax—a 15 per cent tax on food, clothing, transport and other necessities of life.

Opposition members referred to Dr Harding's paper. What they conveniently forget to mention is that her analysis of the Fightback package also found that not everyone would be worse off as a result of the GST. Only 70 per cent of members of the population would be worse off, and they are the ordinary wage and salary earners that many people sometimes forget. Those who would gain the most are higher income earners. For example, families earning $90,000 or more would be up to $105 a week better off, while struggling families would certainly bear the brunt of the goods and services tax.

Overall it has been a fascinating debate in one sense. We have heard very little about the education leaver waiting period. We have heard very little criticism of the option of allowing people to bring forward their family allowance payment. Clearly, most of the Opposition members in the course of this debate ranged fairly widely in their remarks. In many cases, their remarks were very much at odds with the specific aspects of this debate. Nonetheless, it is worth while to reflect on those comments and for people to make their own judgment. As we get closer to the next election, people will certainly make their judgments about the relative merits of the contribution of this Government with respect to social justice and those notions of social justice that we hear about from the Opposition.

Clearly, there is an incredible gap between those respective policies. The family measures that were announced in the Budget and in the recent One Nation statement continue to reflect this Government's continuing commitment to social justice, and indicate that that pattern has not changed in any way since the Labor Government was elected in 1983. That is in stark contrast, I would suggest, to the Opposition's Fightback package and to some of the notions of so-called social justice that we hear there.

The choice for Australian families has never been more stark. Only the Keating Government can deliver the sort of society that we want for our children's future. These two particular, very specific measures in the Department of Social Security are a further indication of the progressive changes that this Government has been making, and I commend the Bills to the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Martin)—by leave—proposed:

(1)the resolution of appointment of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act be amended by omitting paragraphs (1) and (16) and substituting the following paragraphs:

TAB.TAB: `(1)That a joint select committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, be appointed to inquire into and report on:

(a)the provisions and operation of the Family Law Act 1975 and, where the committee thinks appropriate and necessary, make such recommendations for amendments to the Family Law Act and other action in respect of:
(i)the role, funding, effectiveness and availability of the services of:
(B)approved organisations providing marriage counselling and family mediation services;
(ii)the proper resolution of custody, guardianship, welfare and access disputes;

(iii)the proper resolution of family law property disputes, including the question whether it is desirable that the Family Law Act be extended to property disputes arising out of de facto relationships;
(iv)the effective enforcement of rights and duties under the Family Law Act;

(v)the exercise of discretion by the courts, including the question whether it is desirable to better structure the exercise of the discretion of the courts in making orders determining disputes in relation to children or property;

(vi)the adversarial nature of proceedings under the Family Law Act and their associated legal costs, including the question whether amendments to the Act or other actions are desirable to require or encourage greater use of arbitration, mediation or other forms of alternative dispute resolution;
(vii)the prohibition in the Family Law Act on the publication of accounts of proceedings which identify parties, witnesses or other persons associated with the proceedings; and
(viii)the retiring age for judges of the Family Court of Australia; and
(b)the administration of the Family Court of Australia to assess:
(i)the base level of funding required to enable the Court to undertake its statutory functions at a level that will meet the reasonable expectations of the Parliament; and
(ii)the effectiveness of present expenditure by the Court towards undertaking those functions and meeting those expectations.
(16)That the committee report to each House of the Parliament, for term of reference (1)(a) by 17 December 1992, and, for term of reference (1)(b) as soon as possible.'; and

PARA.TAB: (2)a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting its concurrence.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I just indicate that as far as the Opposition is concerned it will be supporting this motion. You will be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act was an initiative that came from the Opposition. It was first moved in the Senate and, after being passed by the Senate, came into this House.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the motion that is being moved now, the terms of reference for that Joint Select Committee will be expanded. They will be expanded to include a term of reference to allow the Committee to look at the administration of the Family Court of Australia, and to assess levels of funding and the effectiveness of present expenditure by the Court. That is a welcome development. It is something that we believe will prove quite fruitful for the Joint Committee.

There is no question that the administration of family law in this country is a matter that is of deep concern to many people. The breakdown of marriage, custody and property disputes, as a consequence, can be enormously dislocating to individuals. It is an area where emotion runs high and, of course, where social dislocation occurs.

We hope that the Joint Select Committee will come forward with resolutions and recommendations that will go some distance to improving our family law system and the operation of our Family Court. It is a matter where there is certainly a great deal of room to improve things. One would have to be deaf and blind not to realise that there is deep concern about the operation of family law in this country at the moment. We certainly look forward to positive recommendations coming out from the Joint Select Committee. The Opposition will support this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill makes a number of changes to the Development Allowance Authority Act to widen the scope and increase the flexibility of the development allowance provided for in the original legislation. The amendments contained in this Bill will allow the aggregation of new productive facilities with other projects, consisting of the expansion, upgrading or improvement of existing facilities where the new and existing productive facilities are vertically integrated.

PARA.TAB: Two new types of scheme are introduced with this legislation and are described as an individual project scheme, and a joint venture project scheme. These new types of schemes will allow projects involving new productive facilities to be added to projects involving such things as the expansion of existing productive facilities to qualify for the allowance, and meet the $50m threshold test.

The Bill provides for greater flexibility in combining purchased and leased assets in a project to be aggregated so that it can meet the $50m threshold test for the granting of the allowance. A mechanism is also introduced whereby a lessor can claim the development allowance benefit by way of a pre-qualifying certificate that has been issued by the Development Allowance Authority to the lessee.

There is also to be a new vertical integration test, and a number of other consequential amendments to the original legislation. The development allowance and the Development Allowance Authority that administers it are both creatures of the Government's `One Nation: One Job' statement in February of this year. It was one of a host of Government initiatives that seek a solution to Australia's problems by throwing taxpayers money around in an attempt to get the economy moving again.

As was predictable, it is the various one job initiatives that have been one of the major contributors to the blow out in the Budget deficit which is itself one of the country's main economic problems. The Government is thus trying to cure our economic difficulties by exacerbating one of the elements of the overall economic problem, for which it is largely responsible. This is a strategy that is

SPEECH.PARA: bound to fail, but it is the only one the Government could stitch together, given its limited imagination in these matters.

PARA.TAB: The `One Job' statement and the many initiatives associated with it, such as the Development Allowance Authority, have since largely vanished from the political arena. The `One Nation: One Job' statement lasted all of one day, before being buried under the weight of its essential irrelevance to solving of economic problems.

Members opposite are very proud of the One Job statement and are in the habit of stuffing letterboxes with leaflets showing their constituents where all the upgraded roads and railways are going to be. This must come as great news, I suppose, to those of their constituents who are currently unemployed as a result of their Government's policies.

Australia's unemployed could do without a government that is obsessed with railway tracks and all the other infrastructure white elephants being promoted by this Government as the solution for our problems. The whole idea of having an economic recovery led by public sector infrastructure projects would be a joke, if it were not for the serious nature of our economic difficulties.

Australia's public sector infrastructure is a chronic under-performer by world standards, and throwing more money into public sector investment is not going to deliver a reasonable return without fundamental micro-economic reforms on the railways, the water-front and in a host of other areas. It is little wonder then that the response to One Nation has been so underwhelming. This Bill can be seen as a forlorn attempt to revitalise one of the `One Job' statement's taxation initiatives.

As I shall demonstrate, the development allowance is a complete failure as a means of revitalising and sustaining business investment in this country, which has reached a record in the low levels attained in recent years. The coalition opposed the development allowance legislation when it was first introduced in the autumn sittings this year. There is nothing in this Bill that would cause us to modify our original evaluation as to the establishment of the development allowance and the Authority that will administer it. There are numerous problems with this whole concept of government administered development allowances which grant concessional tax treatment for the cost of acquiring new plant and equipment.

The `One Job' statement laid down a number of criteria that an investment project must satisfy to qualify for the development allowance. In order to receive the allowance, a project must be shown to be world competitive—in the language of the `One Job' statement—as to the proposed practices of employers and employees and the practices of all levels of government under which the project must operate. World competitive projects are to be identified, in terms of the legislation, on the basis of an absence of industry assistance or protection; positive facilitation by local and State governments, with the Commonwealth Government providing complementary action where required; and world best practice in industrial relations.

It is doubtful, however, whether the investment projects which may attract the development allowance will exhibit these qualities or live up to these criteria in the manner suggested by the Government. Despite the legislated injunction against industry assistance, the requirement for positive facilitation by other levels of government is virtually a standing requirement that State and local governments provide assistance of one type or another for projects within their jurisdiction in order that those projects might qualify for the allowance. The allowance thus encourages, and possibly effectively requires, State and local governments to get into the business of picking winners and introducing a mass of distortion into the economy as a result.

All this begs the question: why do these projects need special tax breaks if they are indeed already world competitive? After all, that is one of the criteria for getting the allowance. World competitive projects run on the basis of best international practice should not require any assistance from the Commonwealth in the form of tax breaks which must ultimately be paid for by other taxpayers who will be required to bear a heavier tax burden as a consequence. If these projects were less than world competitive, we should be even less inclined to support them in this way.

There is reason to believe, however, that the Government intends to use the development allowance as provided for under this legislation to do exactly that and support under-competitive investment projects by Australian industry. For a start, the competitive test is to be waived completely for the first round of applicants for the development allowance if they apply before the magic date—the end of 1992.

In any event, the criteria for the competitiveness test are given scant attention in the explanatory memorandum to the original legislation, although they are mentioned in clauses in the legislation itself. This suggests that the Government will be giving scant attention to these criteria when it comes to interpreting the legislation.

Descriptions in explanatory memoranda often reveal the Government's true intentions with legislation it proposes. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Baldwin) noted in his second reading speech to the original Bill that the allowance will provide firms with additional leverage to negotiate progress against a broad best practice agenda. Again, this suggests that allowance recipients are less than fully competitive at the time of granting of the allowance if they have progress to make in achieving so-called best practice.

Overall, this legislation reeks of the now thoroughly discredited practice of governments attempting to pick winners. This is made abundantly clear in the descriptions of this measure provided by the Government. The Minister, in his second reading speech to the original legislation, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Put simply, the development allowance rewards success and represents a conscious rejection of those policies of the past which underwrote loss and failure.

So this legislation is designed to reward success, which sounds just like another attempt at picking winners to me. Furthermore, what the Minister conveniently forgets is that those policies of the past that he rightly observes underwrote loss and failure also sought to reward success in much the same way as the development allowance intends. The fact that those policies of the past ended up underwriting loss and failure was an entirely unintended consequence of those policies.

PARA.TAB: As I have already indicated, the Government has no business underwriting success, in any case. Successful businesses can and do look after themselves. Unsuccessful businesses should be allowed to fail. It is as simple as that. The Government says that the development allowances are not to be allocated on the basis of preferred industry sectors and therefore will not benefit preferred projects or enterprises.

But, in making such bold statements, the Government is ignoring the fact that any such scheme inevitably requires that the Government make judgments as to how these allowances are to be best allocated. The preferences and judgments of the bureaucrats who administer these schemes and make these decisions will inevitably enter into the equation so that the Government cannot avoid falling into the trap of picking winners in its administration of the development allowance.

Needless to say, governments have a lousy record in making these judgments. Bureaucrats isolated in Canberra, or anywhere else for that matter, are hardly in a position to know or to judge the commercial and marketing imperatives driving a particular investment project by a competent business enterprise. For bureaucrats to be telling Australian businesses what constitutes world best practices is, for the most part, simply laughable. The public sector has little to teach and a great deal to learn from the private sector in this country.

Only the entrepreneur in the marketplace can make the necessary commercial judgments and, even then, the entrepreneur is not infallible, as we all know only too well, given the excesses of the 1980s. But, at least when the entrepreneur fails, the cost is borne by himself and the shareholders who mistakenly invested with him and not by the general public who, under schemes such as the development allowance, have no role in the decision-making that might lead to the failure of the investment and their consequential loss as taxpayers.

There are a host of other problems with the development allowance as it is presently constituted. The total capital cost threshold of $50m is arbitrary and obviously highly distortionary. It encourages the vertical integration of production processes for the purpose of claiming the allowance, even though such integration may not be optimal in terms of a particular production process. Highly efficient and productive capital projects which just happen to fall below the $50m threshold do not qualify for the allowance. The result is a potential misallocation of resources in favour of larger investment projects at the expense of smaller, potentially more productive, projects and at the cost of overall economic efficiency.

The Government shows little or no appreciation of the difficulties that confront an initiative such as the development allowance, despite a wealth of experience and analysis that points to the repeated failure of such measures. But it would be naive to think that this was of any real concern to the Government, in any event. The Government's real objective with the development allowance is to get a few big ticket capital projects registered with the Development Allowance Authority before the end of 1992, so that they can be touted by the Government at the next election as evidence of some sort of recovery in business investment. That is why the competitiveness test has been waived, but only until the end of the year. The Minister gave the game away in his second reading speech to the original legislation, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Encouraging projects of this magnitude will induce confidence in our economic future.
It sounds very much like a line from an ALP pamphlet for the next election, to be accompanied by photos of projects that might benefit from the development allowance at some stage in the future.

PARA.TAB: This amendment Bill is obviously designed to maximise the number of companies that will qualify for the development allowance, if only on paper, by increasing the scope and flexibility of the existing legislation. Many of these projects can then be knocked on the head, after the next election, when they no longer have any political value for this Government.

The political import of this legislation is perhaps indicated by the fact that it was left to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Brereton) to deliver the second reading speech to this amendment Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?

—So what, he asks. Usually it is left to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) to present Treasury Bills to the House and usually without his understanding anything in them. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister also found occasion to address the development allowance, in one of his rare speeches to the House, when he spoke to the original legislation earlier this year. The Parliamentary Secretary demonstrated in that speech that he understood nothing about the criticisms that have been made over the years of the practice of picking winners. He said of that legislation, to which this Bill is closely related:

SPEECH.PARA: It is assistance not about picking winners but about rewarding and encouraging the proven winners, the people who create wealth for Australia.

But who is it that decides, according to this legislation, who are the proven winners who are to be encouraged and rewarded? It is the Government that decides. If that is not picking winners, then I do not know what is.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary then spoke about the need for `selective industry assistance', and said that we must look at the Asian tigers, Germany and Japan `to find the way forward'. He completely ignored the Industry Commission's detailed criticisms of selective industry assistance made in its 1989-90 annual report. There is a chapter in that report entitled `Strategic Trade Theory and the East Asian Experience', which demonstrates exactly why the approach taken with this legislation is precisely the wrong way to go. The Industry Commission concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic success in Japan and the dynamic Asian economies (DAEs) cannot be closely associated with strategic Government interventions . . .
Industry specific assistance, far from being a prerequisite for success is likely to be harmful, especially if it is extensive and maintained over long periods.

The Parliamentary Secretary also spoke of some of his experiences with the major projects facilitation unit, in the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. He spoke of a mineral development that apparently depended for its viability on the availability of this allowance. This is just further evidence of the fact that the allowance will be used by the Government to underpin marginal investments that are undercompetitive in the normal course of events. The naivety of the Parliamentary Secretary in this matter is alarming, and one would hope that in future he will pay more attention to the Industry Commission than to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in such matters.

PARA.TAB: The way ahead for Australia is not down the path of `selective industry assistance', as that assistance is commonly understood. The way ahead for Australia lies in relieving industry and Australians more generally of the burden of Government at all levels. When Australian industry is relieved of the burden of paying for the special privileges of the few industries and firms favoured by the Government, then Australia will be that much more competitive.

It is about time we realised that it is not within the capacity of government to identify investments, businesses or industries that are likely to be successful in the future, and then to go about trying to underwrite that success no matter how inconsequential that underwriting may prove to be. Governments and their bureaucrats have no special insight in considering these matters. More commonly, governments are thoroughly ignorant of the market and the demands it places on industry. If governments have no special knowledge in these matters, then they have nothing to contribute to the judgments that entrepreneurs already make in a market context, on a daily basis. For the most part, the private investor himself is unsure about the future success of a project.

The knowledge required to make such a judgment is dispersed in the marketplace and only becomes available to the investor after the investment has been made and a product or service marketed. Even then, there is no accounting for what shifts will take place in the market which will completely change the viability of the underlying investment.

Government has no business in underwriting or otherwise contributing to investments made by the private sector. If the Government were serious about revitalising investment spending on plant and equipment, whether it be for small or large projects, then there are a host of things it could do. It could start by removing indirect taxes on businesses, such as wholesale sales tax, fuel excise, payroll tax and the Government's various levies, such as the training guarantee and superannuation guarantee levies. It could lower business costs by reducing tariff and non-tariff barriers to imports, so that Australian business could access goods at world prices. It could tackle industrial relations issues such as work practices and the centralised wage fixing system to enable workers and managements to link wages to workplace productivity.

The coalition has said that, when in government, it will be looking to introduce special tax measures to benefit large scale investment projects, from which income is delayed, and the capacity to distribute accruing tax losses to shareholders. The difference between our proposals and the Government's development allowance is that our tax measures will be available across the board and not to a select few projects favoured by the Government. Our facilitation of major development projects will not be driven by pre-election politics in the manner of the Government's `One Job' statement initiatives. We will instead work to lower business costs and provide tax incentives across the board, to the great benefit of all Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MARTIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1992, which was introduced into the House in August. Essentially, its purpose is to allow applicants for the development allowance to elect to aggregate two or more joint venture projects or specified projects and bring expenditure incurred in the long term lease of certain new units of plant within the ambit of the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992, the principal Act, which was passed in this place some time ago.

PARA.TAB: The One Nation statement of February this year—and I am pleased that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) referred to that document—contained an announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that the introduction of a development allowance for selected large scale investments would be included. In fact, it was given effect to and the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 provided a vehicle for advancing that issue.

The Government's objective was to promote an early upturn in investment in new plant and equipment for projects which offer benefits to our competitiveness in world markets. As has been indicated, this particular amendment goes a step further, in that the Government is concerned about providing assistance for industry, where necessary and deemed appropriate, so that the pace and process of economic recovery in this country can be enhanced.

I found it most interesting that the honourable member for Curtin was somewhat critical of a number of issues associated with this Bill and, more importantly, across a range of different issues. For example, he talked about many of the investment projects which were mentioned as part of the infrastructure projects in the One Nation statement as being white elephants. I think he talked about the rail and the road proposals and so on. If it is a white elephant to improve the rail gauges so that freight can be moved around Australia without having to change trains and without delays being occasioned, I guess it is a white elephant. The micro-economic reforms to which the honourable member referred, particularly on the waterfront, have seen a reduction in manpower of 47 per cent and enormous improvements in turnaround times in comparison to what occurred in years gone by. Obviously, that is the white elephant that he is talking about. Maybe we need a few more of those sorts of white elephants.

Opposition parties always paint themselves as being the pro-business parties. They paint themselves as being the ones that are out there to help, although, in light of some of the comments that Opposition members have made about BHP and its managing director, the car industry and the people who are running it, and anyone else that disagrees with their policies, one starts to wonder whether that is still the case. When I went back and looked at some of the criticisms that had been levelled at the original legislation when it was introduced into this Parliament, I wondered why the Opposition chose to vote against it. I thought to myself, `Why, if this is a pro-business party or selection of parties, would it vote against measures which would give some impetus to investment and try to stimulate jobs and the economy?'.

On looking back, I found that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Reith), in a press release dated 26 May 1992, indicated exactly why those opposite were against the legislation. Interestingly, they were not against the spirit of the legislation; they were against it because it did not go far enough. In fact, three things come to mind about this press release. First, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that those opposite opposed the legislation because the development allowance would discriminate against projects with a capital cost of less than $50m, so the $50m threshold we had was not good enough; secondly, he said that it would not be available for investment in plant and equipment in all areas of the economy; and, thirdly, he said that it did not apply to projects commenced prior to 31 December 1992.

Here we have the reasons advanced by the shadow Treasurer as to why those opposite were opposing the legislation: not because they disagreed necessarily with the concept of industry assistance, but rather that it did not go far enough and did not cover all sectors of the economy. Yet this evening we have had the honourable member for Curtin arguing that governments should not pick winners. I find it very interesting that he would dare to contradict some of the suggestions made by the shadow Treasurer, but then again it seems that quite a few people on the other side of the House are doing that these days.

I dispute the assertion that this Government is into a `picking winners' scenario. If one looks at the history of the assistance given to business generally by this Government, one sees that it has been applied across the board with equity and fairness. The changes that have been occasioned in things such as company tax rates have applied across the board, rather than picking winners and going into certain areas. If one looks at some of the other issues associated with taxation generally, one sees that they are applied across the board and not in specific areas. It is a hallmark of this Government that it is prepared, in an industry policy sense, to suggest that, if an industry of any nature is to survive in the Australian economy, to be internationally competitive and to have a domestic base it has to stand on its own two feet, it indeed has to be internationally competitive, and it has to have all the things going for it which the honourable member for Curtin remarked upon.

I thought it was somewhat strange that the honourable member for Curtin, in the course of his contribution, said that government had no place in industry policy and that the Government should not target any specific industries for assistance under any circumstances. I represent the south coast and the industrial cities of Wollongong and Port Kembla. If it had not been for this Government intervening in 1983 and bringing down the steel industry plan, we would not have a steel industry in this country. If it had not been for this Government, through Senator Button bringing down the car plan, we would not have a car industry in this country. What will happen if the zero tariff proposals of the Opposition are imposed, if it ever comes to government? That prediction will come true, anyway. We have already heard what the car companies have to say about that. That analysis, which appears in the Bulletin this week, underlines that.

If it was not for the TCF plan of this Government, with specific assistance measures put in place to ease the burden of becoming a more competitive industry, we would not have any TCF industries in this country. So it is nonsense to say that particular areas of assistance should not be forthcoming from government and that government does not have a role to play.

I found it a little laughable when the honourable member said that business could learn from entrepreneurs. He did qualify it by saying that one would not like to learn a great deal from some of those in the 1980s, and I could not agree with him more. But it is a view—and one which is widely shared on this side of House—that industry and government have a role to play—a cooperative role, as we have always sought. I think this legislation takes us towards that level of cooperation.

I did find it a little disturbing that criticism was levelled at the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Brereton), firstly for having introduced this legislation and, secondly, for some of the comments that he made in debate in respect of other aspects of his portfolio responsibilities. It does not matter whether a Parliamentary Secretary or a Minister introduces legislation on behalf of the Treasurer or any other Minister. What is important is the content of that legislation. But to say that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister has no level of expertise in terms of major infrastructure projects and does not have anything to contribute was a little unfair.

I think this has now been proven in New South Wales. His tenure as Minister for Public Works, with the development of Darling Harbour and his vision for a new tunnel under Sydney Harbour, has clearly demonstrated that he had not only a knowledge but also a thorough understanding of infrastructure needs for a major metropolitan area such as Sydney. Many people, not only Australians but tourists from all over the world, are reaping benefits from it now. It is amazing, is it not? At the time there were so many critics of his endeavours with the Darling Harbour project, but now I do not think one would find too many around.

There was another thing that I found interesting, in a general sense, about the comments by the honourable member for Curtin in relation to the One Nation statement and the infrastructure spending as was announced and as has now come forward in this legislation. If he took the opportunity to read the newspapers from New South Wales today, he would find that his colleague from New South Wales, the Premier, Mr John Fahey, and the Treasurer, did exactly the same thing yesterday in the State Budget. They brought down a Budget which contained a massive infrastructure stimulatory effect, for the simple reason that governments, whether it be us or the other side, have a legitimate role to play in stimulating the economy. Interestingly, the State Government's Budget did not offer much in relation to health—it did not have much else of much worth in terms of looking after social issues—but, in terms of trying to put people into employment, it built on the lead given by this Government. To that extent, I suppose, we should give thanks for small mercies.

It is important that legislation such as this be approved. It is important that it go through so that individual projects and joint venture projects in areas such as mining and other developments right around Australia can receive some assistance, provided they meet the strict criteria and guidelines laid down in this legislation. Clearly, it is not a matter of simply saying that an almost unviable or almost viable project will or will not get up for want of some assistance. That is not it at all. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions—and certainly at a major dinner in Sydney—that if projects are not viable governments cannot be expected to give them handouts to make them such.

In this legislation we have clearly identified the fact that criteria have to be met, but we have taken a sensible approach as well. We are saying that industry assistance, in certain forms, is necessary and desirable and, from what I have seen, some of the major peak employer organisations and others believe that it is not too bad at all. With those brief comments, I commend this legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill which is before the House this evening is nothing more than a blatant attempt by the Australian Labor Party Government to be seen on paper to be assisting business investment. In fact, it does no such thing. Whilst this Government dallies, major investors are leaving our shores in droves. Take, for example, Watties brand baked beans. My good friend and colleague from Queensland the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) well knows the Watties company and its brand of baked beans.

PARA.TAB: Watties, a food processor, sources its navy beans from Kingaroy in Queensland. However, the beans then hightail it out of Kingaroy and go across the Tasman to New Zealand where they are processed, given a quick injection of tomato sauce, promptly canned and shipped back to the supermarket shelves of Australia. Watties has concluded that the cost of producing its baked beans in Australia is too great. The spirit of this Bill will not encourage Watties to process Australian-grown food products in Australia for consumption in Australia.

Unfortunately, there are countless cases similar to the Watties baked beans scenario. This Government has been the great architect of missed opportunities and job losses. In fact, job exportation is one of the Government's greatest growth industries. Testimony to this fact is our double digit unemployment level. Business investment has dropped in 1991-92 for the third successive year by a massive 16.3 per cent and is forecast to remain negative in the forthcoming year. Private and corporate confidence has been crushed by high interest rates, accumulated debt, industrial relations inefficiencies and unreasonable government taxes and charges. If this Government were serious about investment in Australia it would abolish payroll tax, wholesale tax, fuel excise tax and cut personal income tax. But quite clearly it is not serious about seeing investment prosper in Australia.

The Government must put the Budget in order. Ask any Australian housewife when she has a budget to do and she will say that she has to keep the budget in order to keep the family together. The Government then has to bring down real interest rates and cut business costs through micro-economic reform and industrial relations reform. Instead, the Government recently handed down a $13.4 billion Budget deficit—a clear indication that it has had to step in where the private sector fears to tread while this Government has the treasury bench. The private sector fears to tread because it is offered no long term reliable industry policies.

The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill has come about as a result of constraints and inefficiencies in the principal Act. The principal Act provided for the establishment of the Development Allowance Authority which determines the eligibility of projects with a gross capital cost of $50m or more. Furthermore, the development allowance provides a deduction equal to 10 per cent of eligible plant expenditure in the first year that the plant is used or installed ready for use.

However, an applicant has to meet certain arbitrary qualifying criteria, including an industrial relations arrangement which promotes the achievement of world best practice. I am not quite sure how we will get that under this Government. This requirement is waived for the first round of applicants who apply before the end of 1992.This point on its own raises serious contention within industry. The managing director of North Broken Hill Peko Ltd, Mr Peter Wade, argued that this exemption defeated the whole purpose of the legislation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why should we have one set of rules for a project which starts this year, and another for the next?

Mr Wade said that world best industrial practice in the mining industry may be to have no union, rather than single union coverage as proposed by the Government's guidelines for the allowance. He continued:
I don't mean to be facetious but it's almost an impossible series of situations to measure up to.

This is one of the nation's major investors talking. It is not the Opposition; this is a major investor who wants to invest in this nation. Lo and behold, business leaders require long term reliable policies, not ad hoc, one-off government wonders.

PARA.TAB: The coalition opposed the principal Act on the grounds of the concerns I have raised, alongside the fact that the $50m threshold discriminated against smaller investors. Now, a mere four months after the establishment of the Development Allowance Authority, the Government is proposing amendments. It is back in the House with an amendment to this Bill. This further confirms the incompetence of the Government. It could not get it right. Had it taken the advice of the coalition parties in the first place, this debate this afternoon would not have been necessary.

The Government amendments are designed to overcome the $50m threshold and blatantly serve to maximise the number of companies which are eligible for the development allowance prior to the Federal election. This is a desperate government in its death throes. I think the most desperate person is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—Mr Desperado himself—who this time last year was doing desperate deals on the back bench to secure the prime ministership.

At best, the Government's development allowance has been described by industry as pretty modest. A spokesman for MIM Ltd, Mr Colin Myers, said that it was not the sort of benefit that would make the difference between projects commencing or not. Further concerns raised by industry related to the unnecessarily complex guidelines. The very modest benefit that such an allowance would provide to industry must be contrasted with the coalition's Fightback program, which provides $20 billion in tax relief for businesses, which will encourage investment and create jobs. Most important of all, it will be a benefit which will flow through to all businesses, whether they are large or small.

Furthermore, the Fightback! document gives a pledge to review the business tax arrangements with a view to ensuring that sustainable, non-discriminatory incentives are available in order to encourage investment in the latest technology and ensuring that Australian workers have access to plant and equipment to produce output which matches the best in the world. In order to fulfil this commitment, a panel of leading businessmen and taxation experts has been established to advise the coalition on the arrangements it should implement when it comes to office.

Coalition policy does not discriminate against investors with less than $50m to spend. Let us take, for example, the North Coast Regional Meat Co-operative based in Casino, New South Wales. That meatworks is the largest single employer north of Newcastle. The co-operative, which is also the largest integrated meatworks in Australia, would save $3.32m in government taxes and charges under a coalition government. Taxes and government charges exceeded net profit for the co-operative by nearly $1m, representing an unequivocal condemnation of the present Government's taxation regime. The Government's policy is stunting regional development, growth and employment.

The meat co-operative paid $1.54m in payroll tax, $1.15m in sales tax, $330,000 in the compulsory training guarantee levy and $300,000 in fuel tax—all accounts that it will not have to pay under a coalition government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should hear what Qantas has to pay.

—I would be interested to hear, and I am sure the House would be interested to hear. The National and Liberal parties will abolish such taxes on business, providing industry with an incentive to create long term employment opportunities outside the major metropolitan areas. Furthermore, the meatworkers at the Casino co-operative would receive an extra $73 in their pay packets per week under a coalition government. That is $73 more that those workers will take home to their families in their pay packets. The coalition policies are designed to restore incentive, opportunity and reward to the workplace.

PARA.TAB: The 1991 Mount Isa Mines Holdings Ltd annual report to shareholders gave a further unequivocal condemnation of the present Government's taxation regime. Taxes and government imposts on the MIM group in 1990-91 greatly exceeded net profit. Sales tax alone accounted for a massive $5m, fuel excise a further $5.5m, and payroll tax an exorbitant $19 1/2m. The total cost, $30m, represents the potential savings that Mount Isa Mines Holdings would make under a Liberal-National Party government. This $30m that the Mount Isa Mines company would save equates to more regional employment, growth and development. It is money that it will have to spend and it will decide where it spends and invests it.

Australian investors are calling out for comprehensive, reliable and rational reform. The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill, which is before the House tonight, cannot offer businesses any such thing. It is just a blatant attempt by the Government to woo a few votes before the next election. The clear choice for Australian businesses, large and small, and for families right across the nation is a coalition government.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BALDWIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill is designed to amend the Development Allowance Authority Act, which was carried by both Houses in the Autumn sittings. It aims to introduce a greater degree of flexibility into the scheme by enabling new projects to aggregate, together with the upgrading and expansion of existing projects, subject to those new projects being vertically integrated with the existing projects, and to improve the flexibility to combine plant or equipment acquired through either lease or purchase to meet the $50m test.

PARA.TAB: The Bill is designed to provide a greater degree of flexibility. I gather that Opposition members do not have a great problem with that. They certainly do not like the overall approach represented by the original Act but, as I understand it, they have not expressed opposition to these amendments, except to the extent that they seem to be saying that, if the amendments enable more projects to qualify, that represents a higher level of government intervention in investment decisions. They say they are against that.

This measure and the principal Act are part of a package of measures set out in the One Nation statement designed to improve this country's economic fortunes. Part of that package was a major boost to the spending on public infrastructure. I note that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was critical of that. I think that criticism is misplaced. I think there is a growing body of evidence in the international economic literature that under-investment in public infrastructure is a false economy and exacts a significant toll in terms of overall growth in economic productivity. I think those criticisms of investment in public infrastructure are misplaced.

I think the criticisms that have been mounted of this sort of approach to provide an incentive for an acceleration of investment by the private sector and the introduction of best practice is also misplaced. The honourable member for Curtin made reference to this being an approach involving picking winners. I do not think that is a reasonable description. We are not identifying particular industry sectors. We are not purporting to make judgments as to the overall prospects of major investment projects. We are doing something far more limited: we are applying a competitiveness test to see whether we have best practice, on a world standard, in labour management relations and to see whether we have efficient industries involved in the provision of inputs. It is much more limited than some generalised attempt to pick winners. I think that characterisation is wrong.

I think the overall comments the honourable member for Curtin made about government intervention in industry policy were also wrong. Economies that have been highly successful in developing highly productive and efficient economies have not been content to allow the market to dictate all investment decisions without any involvement by government. What we are seeking to do is, on the one hand, to secure the bringing forward of major investment decisions, but also, in the process, to capitalise some change in overall culture and practice in Australian industry. As a way of doing that, I think this is a pretty reasonable approach.

The allowance is targeted towards the stimulation of investment in large projects which can satisfy the DAA that they are world competitive and that the environment within which they operate is also competitive. Projects which are heavily assisted are specifically excluded from eligibility. That reflects the approach of this Government of moving to a lower tariff environment and a less protected environment than the one we have now, albeit not going to the zero or negligible protection levels favoured by the Opposition.

In that context, each applicant must satisfy the DAA that the project does not have a nominal or effective rate of assistance—taking the lower figure—exceeding 10 per cent. These measures of assistance will be calculated separately for each project, taking into account all assistance received by the project from all levels of government in a manner consistent with the methodology used by the Industry Commission to calculate assistance. There are a number of key dates in the legislation, the most immediately pressing of which is 1 January 1993, before which date all applications must have been received by the DAA if they are to be considered. I hope that point clears up the degree of confusion that might exist in the industry about the need for individual projects to satisfy that test in respect of not being heavily protected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
