TALK.START.PARA: —This is the twenty-fifth occasion on which I have been in this Parliament when we have debated a Budget. On the first night I was a member of this Parliament William McMahon brought in the 1967 Budget. For the sake of memory I went back and read that speech a few weeks ago. One has to say that the activities of this Parliament have changed quite considerably during that period. For instance, the Budget mentioned a massive increase in health expenditure at that time of $35m that year. It did not mention education because the Commonwealth had no role in education, other than a couple of the 1950 bribes which were still in continuance—science blocks and school libraries—which won Menzies an election.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting that at that time, 18 years after the conservative parties had come into office, one of the major promises they had made in 1949 and fulfilled in 1950 to introduce child endowment for the first child had just seen its first change. The Government changed the five shillings to 50c, with the change to decimal currency, but there was never a change in the amount of money. I make those points because I think it is important that the change that has taken place over a relatively short period in our history in the relationship between the Commonwealth and the States be emphasised.

Until the election of the Whitlam Government in 1972 the Commonwealth largely remained an adjunct to the community in Australia rather than part of it. Its activities were peripheral to the day-to-day life of ordinary Australians. It is significant that the major issues Gough Whitlam put forward when he was the Leader of the Opposition were things such as sewering the suburbs. I can imagine some of our founding fathers turning in their graves at the thought. There were 600,000 Australians who had been let down by State governments, particularly in Victoria and New South Wales, living in half and full houses without such basic community amenities.

Much of that has changed but so has the Commonwealth itself. This Parliament now controls and is responsible for—and, no matter what the Opposition may like to think, is going to stay responsible for—the major activities of communities in Australia. The attempts to withdraw from that are the most dangerous aspects of the Opposition's policies today. We have gone from the period where William McMahon stood up at the table in the old House with galleries full of pensioners and told them that there was no money in the Budget for a rise in pensions this year. I am sure the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) will remember that. He will also remember that a person whom I am sure he supported at the time, John Gorton, was the Prime Minister. When William McMahon became Prime Minister, the first thing he did was give them 50c. It was the only highlight of his first speech as Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty cents was worth something then.

—It was not worth much. It was still what the Government was paying in child endowment for the first child. It was the same amount the honourable member's Government had brought in in 1950, some 20 years earlier, and never changed. Such is the commitment to election promises.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the period of the Whitlam Government, the whole relationship had changed. So had the way the Parliament was conducted, and I have to say we have not changed our procedures sufficiently to deal with the workload we now have. We still use the forms, with more members and less time, that we used in 1900. We adopted the Westminster system. We have not changed it to meet Australians' needs; we have not changed it at all. We still debate everything in the chamber, which is unnecessary. Basically, because of that, we have abdicated our responsibility as a House of Parliament to look at legislation. It has to do with the comfort of members on both sides.

I have been 12 years in government and 13 years in opposition. In that time I have heard 12 years of Liberal oppositions and 13 years of Labor oppositions all complain that they are not getting sufficient time and sufficient opportunity to contribute. But not one of them was prepared to make one single alteration to the procedures to facilitate any change. I have to say Prime Ministers are the worst. They are all the same, if I might say so. It does not matter where they come from. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has advocated change in this Parliament but the only change he has significantly put forward is televising Parliament. I cannot see how that has done anyone any good. I do not think those opposite have a great record on reform.

I want to deal with a couple of real issues. We have before us now another program to change the whole way in which Australians relate to one another and relate to their government and the way in which their government accepts responsibility for leadership of this nation.

The Fightback package is not a tax package and the GST is not a tax package. They are regressive and they take us back to a period nearly 100 years ago when the distinction between those people in our society was great and conflict was even greater. It is 100 years ago since we had the shearers strikes. It is all right to brush that off because that was the past, but attitudes have not changed greatly. The greed amongst some of the people in our community, who see someone being supported because they are less well-off than they are as an imposition on their rights and an imposition on them personally, is still there and it is not far below the surface.

Some of the extremist organisations of the Right in this country are as bad as any of the organisations we have had which have been much maligned in this Parliament over the years. I suppose there is a problem in that if one is of the Left, which claims to represent a broader section of the community—that section which does not have wealth and does not have privilege—then what one is saying is evil and wrong; but if one is of the Right and seeks the proper privilege then what one is saying is correct. This is an anecdote but it is true: the only member ever to get 28 days suspension in this Parliament was suspended for responding to someone who called him a Bolshevik by calling him a Hun lover. The honourable member who called the other member a Bolshevik was not even asked to withdraw; such are the standards which we apply to everything.

The Fightback package we are talking about now is a fraudulent policy which is designed to disadvantage the majority of Australians to the advantage of a small minority. It is a policy which has been tried in England and failed; which has been tried in New Zealand and failed. It has not been tried in the United States but follows the general principles of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, bringing that country to its knees. It is a policy which will reward the top 10 per cent and it is a policy based on a fallacious belief that private enterprise is always better and always more capable.

There is no evidence in our history that private entrepreneurs have built structures in Australia which are lasting, which are successful and which are sound. There are some instances but there is a very poor history of private entrepreneurs going out and doing things in this country. Our managers have only been good on rare occasions. We now talk about the recession; we talk about foreign debt; and we blame governments—naturally. It might be of interest to the House to examine this point: which bank was the most successful in riding out that recession in Australia? The Commonwealth Bank. Which bank did worst?

TALK.START.PARA: —The State Bank of Victoria.
—No, it did not. Who did worst?
—The State Bank of South Australia?
—No, it did not.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—We will not have a guessing competition. The honourable member might tell us and we can get on with the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members might find that Westpac did. I do not think those opposite will find that the State Bank of New South Wales did very well either. I do not think they will find that the major problems which arose in respect of Tricontinental in Victoria—which happened to have a former Liberal Minister as its head at one stage—arose after the State Bank took it over, although that bank did make a serious error of judgment; they happened when it was a private enterprise operation. Who were the people who caused the collapse of that bank? Who borrowed the money? How many of those people were public utilities? What was Bond? Was he private enterprise or was he a public utility?
—He was your big donor.

—He did not do badly with you, either. I think he might have been private enterprise. A few people in my electorate lost their jobs when one of the textile magnates left the country—Goldberg. He owed $700m, I think. I wonder whether he was public enterprise or private enterprise—an entrepreneur.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the House might remember—I am sure that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), who is at the table, will remember—the efforts that were made to get a certain person, the President of the Liberal Party, into this Parliament so that the Liberal Party could have a major private enterprise leader. I want to make one or two comments on how farcical Fightback is. The National Party has had some problems since I have been here. I think he was the first leader it has thrown out in living memory. It then went to a leader who lost his seat, which does not say much for his electoral standing, and now we have the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) who said the other day that the GST can be avoided if one grows vegetables. That cannot be done unless one eats them all because, under the GST, barter is involved. If there are two pensioners, and one grows cabbages and has more than he can eat, if he hands them over the fence to his neighbour and gets a few lemons, they both have to put in a tax form because that is barter trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is untrue.
—That is quite untrue.
—Does it have to be two cabbages or three cabbages? At what stage does it become trade?
—Order! We will have fewer interjections.

—That is the type of thing we are talking about—form filling by everyone in Australia. I heard someone earlier in the day talk about hidden taxes; he was talking about sales tax. There have been 40 years of Liberal governments in this Parliament—conservative governments—during the period sales tax has been in operation, and they have expanded it, not reduced it at any stage. Hidden taxes are the ones that people are not told about and do not know about. I will go back to one of our former leaders and the sorts of tax promises we have heard, and will continue to hear, from those who sit opposite. In 1975, Malcolm Fraser had just assumed leadership of the Liberal Party. Those opposite have gone so far to the right now that they claim he is a Labor member and a leftie, but I can assure them that we still look upon him as extreme right. Malcolm Fraser told us that there would be no more taxation by stealth. I heard that phrase in the last week, `No more taxation by stealth'.

—No, it was your Leader; he was saying the same words exactly as Malcolm Fraser. The reason for those words at that time was that he was promising to index the tax brackets—remember the word index?—so that governments that wished to introduce taxes would have to bring in legislation; they would not be able to use tax brackets. I remember it; members opposite who were here remember it well.

PARA.TAB: I remember that in the 1977 election campaign we had the offer of a handful of dollars. What was that all about? The conservative parties in this House had legislated before the election to index the tax brackets. They fulfilled Malcolm's promise after the Budget, during the tax year, to apply for the next tax year. Then the Australian Taxation Office spent half a million dollars on overtime, answering telephones because the Liberal ads told people to ring up the Tax Office and find out what the tax savings would be. Good stuff—no more taxation by stealth!

What happened when we came back in 1978? The legislation was repealed. Tax brackets became the name of the game and that is how every one of the Budgets was financed. By the end of that period taxation by stealth was a long forgotten thing. Honourable members may remember that in that election we promised to abolish payroll tax and we were howled down about people paying personal income tax. What had we done? We had passed a Bill which we had no intention of ever allowing to operate. It was a fraud.

Let us look at where we were in the tax field at the end of that period. If people wanted to avoid tax they bought a submarine and sat it on the floor at the bottom of the harbour. Some of us still have a copy of the documents that passed between the Commissioner of Taxation and the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), asking the Treasurer to bring in legislation. For two years the Commissioner wrote letters talking about the bleeding of the tax system by the most blatant cheating that had ever gone on in this country—$1 billion worth of tax. The report on the straw companies is very thick. There are letters from the Commissioner of Taxation pleading with the then Treasurer and the Fraser Government to fix up the tax legislation so that it could be applied and the tax system could become honest.

It had not been fixed up when those opposite went out of office in 1983. Fightback! has a similar number of pages—it is just a bit broader and printed on both sides—and about as much substance. It is a fraudulent document and it is not supplied to the public. The public is supplied with the public relations version because those opposite want as few people as possible to see the fine print.

Let us not kid ourselves: Fightback will reward 10 per cent of Australian people whether we have a recession or not. It will create not one job. It will reduce the standard of living of many thousands of Australians and expose others to extreme poverty. It will expose those Australians who work for their living—not those who earn their living by other means; in private enterprise, such as entrepreneurs, stockbrokers, share speculators and the sorts or people who have not done this country a great of deal of good over the years, I might say, but who are still the gods of the Liberal Party—

PARA.TAB: As I have only a short period left in which to speak, I must say that I have been here for 25 years and I arrived at a time when the coalition had been in office for 18 years. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to bring forward a ludicrous situation that makes a sham of the rhetoric we hear in this place from many honourable members who express concern about the maintenance of efficient Australian industry. It was Australia's CSIRO that led the world in developing technology known as counter current extraction which could obtain an extract from citrus fruit peel that would otherwise have gone to waste. Considerable public funds went into the research and development of this, and into subsequent efforts to commercialise it.

PARA.TAB: The National Food Authority will be aware that it is possible, with CCE, to extract from that part of the citrus fruit known as peel a peel extract. That product, known as diffusion extracted juice, closely resembles the juice which is extracted from the flesh of the fruit. In fact, the NFA's predecessor came to the view that orange peel extract, as it was decided to call it, was not only a wholesome and nutritious product but also varied little from orange juice in chemical and nutritional make-up. Nevertheless, for reasons arising from no more than perceptions of customer opinion, the NFA's predecessor came to the view that the products made from the endocarp only, or from the exocarp and mesocarp only, were different, so different that in terms of food regulation one was juice and the other was not for purposes of use in fruit drinks and cordials. There is no evidence in the official minutes of the NFA's predecessor as to the views or opinions of consumers on this matter, although some opinions as to what they might be are recorded. There is also no evidence that the NFA's predecessor ever sought such views or commissioned any surveys on its own account.

The NFA's predecessor considered the effects of mixing orange peel extract and orange juice in fruit drinks, cordials and soft drinks. On the one hand it was established that, because the chemical composition of both products was very similar, the end product was indistinguishable from orange juice. On the other hand, however, it was apparently felt that such mixing would be adulteration and therefore deceptive. It was, however, a deception so undetectable that there was no Australian laboratory test capable of finding it. In an effort to detect the undetectable, the very same CSIRO which developed the original technology has now been asked to develop an effective test.

In the course of its deliberations, the NFA's predecessor considered the situation of limes. It appears that, because lime juice has traditionally been made from the whole fruit, it was decided that lime juice should be exempted from the ban that applies to all other citrus peel extract. It is recognised that lime juice has been made for a long time before that, peel and all.

The point is that the public has been no more aware or unaware of this practice in the case of that fruit, whether from limes or from any other citrus. Such adulteration or deception as may be thought to arise is at best theoretical. It is based on a view of consumers interested in how a product was produced, rather than what it is. At the same time, the Australian citrus industry makes the present application for the authorisation of the use of fruit juice peel in fruit drinks and related products and not for its inclusion in fruit juice. As well, the proposal is that fruit peel juice should be declared as an ingredient on the label.

The above brief account of what is admittedly a complex and technical matter shows that the decision taken late last year, although not yet put into effect, patently requires reconsideration. Industry statistics indicate that 32,816,000 litres of single strength juice, or 64,000 tonnes of fresh fruit, will have to be found to replace citrus peel juice in products such as cordial, soft drinks and fruit drinks if the intended amendment comes into effect.

Insufficient conventional extracted fruit juice is available to fill this gap, and the deficit will be required to be obtained from imports, adversely affecting our balance of payments. I make the point to the House that these imports, possibly using the CSIRO's techniques using the whole fruit, will be competing against our own—a matter of high farce.

An amendment to the Food Standards Code is supported by the Australian Citrus Industry Council, which includes the Australian Fruit Juice Association, the Australian Citrus Processors Association and the Australian Citrus Growers Federation. It is also supported by the Australian Horticultural Corporation, the Australian Softdrink Manufacturers Association and Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd. I therefore ask the responsible Minister, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), under whose portfolio this application is made, to reconsider this issue. (Time expired)

Mr Hoskins made a comment in his article to dairy farmers and shareholders of Norco about the dairy industry changes. In particular, in regard to the changes that were instituted by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), Mr Hoskins made the following comment:

SPEECH.PARA: The plan does respond to earlier recommendations of the Industries Commission, but the strategies to be implemented are far different to the proposals put forward in the I.C. Report. As a result, the future of the Australian Dairy Industry has much greater clarity and is certainly far more secure than it would have been if the I.C. proposals had been implemented.
Mr Hoskins went on to say:

The decision of the Government should be welcomed by all of us in the industry in N.S.W. It will ensure a strong and highly efficient industry and continue to bring economic benefits to many rural cities, towns and communities throughout Australia. Industry leaders agree that Mr. Crean deserves recognition for his support to an industry which is extremely efficient, and which is of major economic importance to this nation. I make reference to an article in the journal of the Australian Institute of Agricultural Science which was published in May 1992. The article I am referring to was written by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Lloyd). In particular, I point to the financial burden that the GST will place on this industry, using the very figures that the Deputy Leader of the National Party has actually published—so I guess they must be right.

PARA.TAB: The example that the Deputy Leader uses is a dairy farm which produces something like 380,000 litres of milk a year. On his own figures, that particular dairy farm would be sending to the Taxation Commissioner, if the coalition were ever to introduce a GST, in excess of $6,000 just in goods and services tax.

This particular dairy farm would probably not be a good example for north coast dairy farmers, because of some of the deductions that would be allowed. In any farming business, the deductions allowed are those which the farmer would outlay and which would have a GST on them. Whether this particular example is high or low, does not stop the farmer paying a GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —He gets a rebate.

—Yes. He would simply be getting a rebate for his deductions. If the deductions were low, he would still be paying a GST on his profit, because the GST that he pays out comes in on the income that he receives. He gets a rebate on his deductions. The deductions that Mr Lloyd uses may or may not be correct; I am not taking up that point.

PARA.TAB: What I am simply pointing out to those opposite, to the dairy farmers and to farm businesses of Australia, is that on the profit that he makes he will be paying a GST. In this particular example, where there are some very generous deductions, it runs out at something like $6,000.

I must also point out that this GST is paid to the Commissioner of Taxation before he can go to his accountant and take into account other things, such as wages that he may pay to someone else, or any other deductions such as depreciation and so forth. TALK.START.PARA: —With Australia's recession being the most severe since the 1930s, there has been a re-emergence of a protectionist sentiment. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—the then Treasurer—said in this House on 15 May 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia once and for all gets out of the shocking period when we believed we could take our benefits and our living standards from a tariff wall. We will get away from that dismal legacy when we thought we could progress ourselves by cutting ourselves off from the rest of the world.
Again, on 9 April 1991, the Prime Minister—the then Treasurer—said:
We are the only Party that has removed the tariff wall . . . If that is not leadership—taking the courageous decisions to open up the place as to funds and goods—I do not know what is . . .

These are the clear statements of Prime Minister Keating. The interventionists cannot give Australia an alternative model to free trade. Returning to the bad old days of high protection in Australia would invite a siege political mentality, and a society that has such a deep-seated inferiority complex about its ability to compete on the world market that it had to again put up the artificial barriers to competition.

PARA.TAB: I have examined some of the shifts in Victoria in employment patterns over the last three years. Clothing and footwear industries employed 39,500 in May 1989. Three years later, that figure had dropped to 31,200. The Industry Commission estimates that the average effective rate of assistance to this sector in June 1989 was 171 per cent. By June 1991, the effective rate of assistance had increased to 176 per cent.

Employment in the motor vehicle and parts sector had declined from 48,800 in 1989 to 37,000 in 1992, whereas there was a fall in effective protection levels from 72 per cent to 60 per cent. Yet the unprotected motor trades sector now only employs 57,000 compared with 62,000 two years ago. Job losses in the unprotected construction industry have hit even harder. There are now only 121,000 employees in the construction industry in Victoria, as against 160,000 in 1989.

If job losses are largely the fault of tariff reductions, why has the construction industry suffered so heinously and so badly. The boom and bust mentality of the 1980s under the Victorian Labor Government ensured that, when the bust hit Victoria, jobs totally unrelated to tariff walls were lost. Some occupations in Victoria have actually recorded increases in employment over the last three years. The glass sector, for instance, increased employment from 2,400 to 3,100. It is protected to a level of only one per cent. Employment rose in the furniture and mattresses industries from 15,500 to 18,400—a gain of 20 per cent. Those industries operate with protection levels of between one and 4 per cent. They managed to increase employment during a recession, and with heightened import competition.

Printing and allied trades increased from 24,000 to 32,800 over the last three years. They have high levels of import competition. Breads, cakes, and biscuit manufacturing increased from 9,400 to 11,500. This sector has no effective protection. Either the recession or a lack of capital investment over the past 40 years are the most important factors in any job losses, rather than any lowering of tariff protection.
The Prime Minister does not tell us about the comments released in the 1991-92 annual report of the Automotive Industry Authority into the car industry, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The [car] industry's productivity remains low by world standards and further significant changes will be necessary if the industry is to survive at a tariff level of 15 per cent by the year 2000.

There is a future for manufacturing industry in Victoria. The car industry will continue as a force, provided it keeps on achieving productivity gains. A Hewson Government will reduce industry's costs through the Fightback program, whilst not deviating from the very necessary tariff reductions over the next eight years. The end result will be a world competitive industry in Australia.

—Prior to raising the matter I wanted to raise in the adjournment debate, I just want to make a comment or two about the remarks made by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), particularly with reference to the goods and services tax which applies to the dairy industry. I point out to the honourable member for Richmond, and anyone else who may be listening or who may care to read Hansard, that regardless of which industry people are in, whether it is a secondary industry or a primary industry, there is no such thing as a goods and services tax that applies to the industry. In fact, whether the industry makes a profit or a loss, any goods and services tax incurred is refunded to the industry. That is a fundamental rule that cannot be escaped and will undo much of what the honourable member for Richmond was saying.

PARA.TAB: Today we have been involved in a debate that somewhat focused on subsidies, particularly the subsidies that we see flowing, as a result of EEP, into what are traditional markets for Australian wheat. It is true that Australian primary producers only survive now by using the best techniques they have available to them. In fact, the Kinsey report into agriculture in South Australia asked the very fundamental question: why is it that the best sheep graziers in the Pinnaroo area of South Australia achieve a lambing rate of 98 per cent, when the average lambing rate is only 68 per cent? They discovered that, for very little additional input, it is possible for a farmer to lift the lambing rate from 68 per cent to 98 per cent and make a real contribution to Australia's export income.

I use that as a backdrop to my remarks tonight because I want to focus the attention of the House on one primary industry which, with very little additional input, has a dramatic opportunity to raise its productivity base, and that is the chicken industry in South Australia. One of the companies in my electorate, Imloson Pty Ltd, which runs a hatchery at Bethel just north of Gawler, had sought permission from AQIS to import chickens from a European destination—Isabrown chickens. AQIS gave Imloson permission on the condition that it accepted a secondary quarantine period for these imports.

Imloson went ahead with the import. It brought these Isabrown eggs in and went ahead with the hatching program. Meanwhile, unknown to Imloson, AQIS had also commissioned a Dr Snowdon to check out the whole quarantine procedure that applied to the chicken industry. Dr Snowdon handed down a report which indicated that EDS, the egg drop syndrome—the one thing that AQIS would be most nervous about with the import of Isabrown chickens—was no longer, in Dr Snowdon's assessment, something that Australia should be concerned about on an import basis, particularly as EDS was already present in Australia and therefore did not pose any greater threat to the Australian chicken industry. Imloson, having brought in the Isabrown chickens and holding them in quarantine, principally because of the perceived earlier EDS threat, sought permission from AQIS, first, to move the birds to an alternative sight—and permission was granted—and, secondly, to lift this quarantine protocol as EDS was no longer seen to be a problem. AQIS refused to lift this protocol.

The picture becomes even more complicated when we discover that, because of the shortage of egg pulp in Australia, there is a proposal to import egg pulp from New Zealand, and under discussion paper CQO(A) 112/92 it has been agreed that EDS is not of quarantine significance. What I want to know is why it is that AQIS still insists on Imloson meeting all of the quarantine protocols that were originally laid down, even though AQIS clearly no longer saw EDS as a problem.

These quarantine protocols are costing Imloson thousands of dollars. That is no exaggeration. There are opportunities for Imloson to move into additional job creation if they could free the birds currently held under protocol, since they no longer pose a threat to the chicken industry. Imloson has not been critical of AQIS. It suspects that AQIS is already being lobbied by its major competitors to oblige AQIS to stand by the protocols. But the fact remains that what could be an even more efficient industry is being frustrated by these present AQIS regulations which, under the eye of AQIS, have already been seen as being excessive. The import of egg pulp and the recommendations made in Dr Snowdon's report would indicate that there is no reason why EDS should continue to be a quarantine problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to express concern at events that have transpired in my home State, where the Speaker of the Tasmanian Parliament has foreshadowed draconian bans on the right of the public to attend the Tasmanian Parliament. What has occurred is that, in response to a number of demonstrations from building workers who are facing involuntary retrenchments, the Speaker has closed the galleries and said that for substantial periods—for at least a full day after any clearing of the gallery—the public will not be admitted to the Speaker's galleries to witness the debates in the State Parliament. Not merely those who have taken part in demonstrations have been excluded, but any member of the public will be excluded unless they have a prearranged appointment with a member.

PARA.TAB: The Speaker's lockout at the Parliament shows a total contempt for the basic rights of all Tasmanians and follows a downward spiral by the State Government, which has seen events move towards greater polarisation of the society. Since the Liberals came to government in Tasmania, we have seen guard dogs and hired muscle used during the APPM dispute, legislation to stop people demonstrating on Crown land, picketers arrested at the Hobart waterfront and members of the public now being effectively locked out of their own Parliament.

I understand that, despite many disruptions that have occurred in this and other State parliaments, this is the only time the people of Australia have ever been precluded from attending, over a substantial period, a State or Commonwealth parliament. I understand from my research of the House of Representatives Practice, the only time there has been a substantial exclusion of the public for any period at all was during wartime in the 1920s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which war was that?

—I am sorry, the First World War. The only defence that has thus far been made of the decision of the Tasmanian Government to exclude the public from attendance at the Parliament has come from Michael Hodgman, QC, now a State member. I do not normally descend to a cheap shot at my predecessor. He did have, at one stage, a very substantial reputation as a man who might make a mark on the national scene. But, over time, I think his lack of self-respect for the issues that he pursued led him to become a caricature of his former self.

PARA.TAB: As his descent from importance has occurred, his volume has grown more strident and the substance of what he says less connected with reality. What he has asserted in the present case is that in his time in the Federal Parliament the public had been frequently barred from the gallery and public areas. A quick perusal of the record, as disclosed in the House of Representatives Practice, indicates that is simply not the case. His attempt to give Mr Page's ruling any credence is simply pathetic.

It is an instance which I think all honourable members in this place ought be concerned about. It is not an example or precedent that ought be followed in this place at all. There are always appropriate measures available to Speakers to ensure that those who are disruptive of the proceedings of the House are dealt with individually without trammelling the right of members of the public to attend and hear the proceedings of their own parliaments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 May 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many businesses in Tasmania have closed down between 1 January 1990 and 30 April 1991 as a result of action by the Commonwealth Bank.
(2) How many businesses in Tasmania are under (a) management by an administrator, (b) mortgagee possession or (c) liquidation sale as a result of action by the Commonwealth Bank.
(3) With respect to how many businesses in each of the categories referred to in part (2) have KPMG Peat Marwick been appointed.
(4) Of the businesses referred to in part (2)(a), how many have been handed back to the owners.
(5) Of the businesses referred to in part (4), how many were managed by KPMG Peat Marwick.
(6) What total sum has the Commonwealth Bank paid to KPMG Peat Marwick.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) operates in a commercially competitive market and became a public listed company on 17 April 1991. The matters referred to in the question are commercial-in-confidence. However, I am assured that the CBA treats its clients based in Tasmania in the same way as its clients elsewhere in Australia. The appointment of an administrator, mortgagee or liquidator by the CBA is based on commercial criteria rather than providing favour to any particular firm.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) On what date was the Western Australian Teachers' Credit Society entered on the Register of Corporations under the Financial Corporations Act 1974.

(2) On what dates did the Western Australian Teachers' Credit Society, under that or another name, lodge returns with the Reserve Bank in accordance with the Financial Corporations (Statistics) Regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The W.A. Teachers' Credit Society Limited was entered in the Register of Corporations on 30 August 1974. This entry (though not the date) was acknowledged in the Gazette, No. S211, dated 17 October 1975.

(2) In accordance with the Financial Corporations (Statistics) Regulations, returns were lodged by the W.A. Teachers' Credit Society Limited, under that or another name, approximately 21 days after the end of the month, beginning July 1976 and ending November 1988.

PARA.TAB: (3) The Department's review strategy for a number of years has been aimed at identifying groups of pensioners where there is a risk of incorrect payments being made. World War I veterans were selected as a payment group requiring special attention during a review undertaken 4-5 years ago of a sample of New South Wales pensioners. As the review did not highlight any incorrect payments being made, it was considered that there was no need to investigate World War I veterans, as a specific risk group, on an ongoing basis.

However, a number of these veterans would be included in the selection of pensioners whose entitlements are to be reassessed or affirmed during the other review activities undertaken by the Department. These activities include annual review of assets and rent verification. Particular categories of pensioners are reviewed on a regular basis where the Department is aware that income or assets may vary. Also, groups of pensioners are selected for review on an ad hoc basis to determine whether correct entitlements are being paid. World War I veterans would be included in each of these groups.
